text: This was an interesting character build.  It has an amazing array of details and I love that they provided alternative faces for the Ultrakatty.  It did not take the kids particularly long to build it and it seems to have them raring to go for the new movie.  I like that the set is a figure although usually I like more realistic sets, this one is cute and the kids loved building it.  Lots of interesting parts!

title: A Cute, Quick Build
text:
We can't wait for the movie and the kids have already fallen in love with the franchise sets. This one in particular is a fun although small set. There are some great pieces used in unique ways, like the swords used in metalbeard's legs. The kids spoke a lot about the pieces the sets hold and and played with it quite a bit after a relatively quick time of building.

Love Lego and love this little battle Pack sized kit. Keep them coming! Movies and sets!

title: Love this build and the parts in the kit
text:
The kids loved making this build and I love the parts. Mostly because my dad has a red 49 Chevy and this truck matches it pretty well. We are trying to mod it to be completely right for his truck. Also, even though I am not a huge fan of facades in kits, I love the Southwest/Mexican theme to the this one.

The kids are familiar with Overwatch and say that it is a very good representation of game and we have the D Va set which they also loved. I think these are the two strongest builds in the Overwatch series and we had fun building this together. There are some great pieces for a growing collection..

All in all, a great set

title: A Little Ridiculous but the Kids Love it
text: We have a few of the Unikitty sets around the house and mostly there are ridiculous sets with disjoint elements rather than a single build.  Personally I am not all the impressed with the sets but this one has some interesting elements and the ice cream cone is actually kind of cute. I don't think this set will be display for long.  Usually the elements get tossed into the bins.  But my youngest loves Unikitty so he loved this set.  It would be a good Stocking stuffer, but without lasting joy like other kits.

title: Absolutely Great Set
text:
These came in the mail today and were built before I even got home from work. The kids, who are not huge Overwatch players, easily recognized them and had a blast building them. The Mech form translates very well to Legos which has had a number of Mech kits over the years, and these stand strong among them.

The kids enjoyed showing me the details of the builds and spoke at length about the pieces used. I like that they are Mechs that don't rely on Bionicle style pieces but do have a number of pieces that seem pretty unique, as is the pink color on D Va.

Quick build that I suspect will stay intact and displayed for years.

title: Fit our age ranges, Tween to Adults well
text:
I love games that can be learned immediately and mastered only after many, many games. This one is close. It did take us a few games to get the gyste of the rules, which are actually not that complicated despite the initial intimidation. We had everything down by the second game, but we are still thinking out the perfect strategies. So it is pretty easy to learn but has enough to learn to make this game come out of the closet in the future.

I really like that it worked well for our age range that spans 11 to 50. Even the youngest were able to play competitively and seemed to enjoy it. I also like that there was no real way to back stab each other which kept quarreling and hurt feelings down.

All in all, a very nice game.

title: Interesting Kit, but Limited Return Play
text:
This kit definitely makes some interesting slime creations, but after a half hour of play, the kids were left wondering if they could ever use the set again. It seems like it is a single use set. Mostly this appears to be the fault of the limited main ingredients. They all got mixed up on the first use, leaving the set to be one and done. We did move a lot of the "beakers" and other things to the general science lab equipment and play bin, much of which was left unused.

This is too bad because the created gooey lumps are interesting and sufficiently gross to live up to the boogers, clots and guts that it says you can make. The Kids did have fun playing with it, but I wish it was something you could get a little more of you moneys worth.

If you have kids who like gross projects, they will love this, for as long as the supplies last.

title: Great Kit, Great Finished Product
text:
Our household loves craft sets like this and my biggest pet peeve are kits that result in kind of worthless end products. This kit makes and adorable pillow which is actually easy to achieve. Our youngest has gotten into several of the Klutz sewing kits like the one where you make cartoonish vegetables and food items and she came up with wonderful little creations. This one was very similar and all the component ideas and templates are in the book to have a successful creation, even for young and lesser creative hands.

When she finished it was amazingly cute and custom and unique. It was immediately added to the pile of plush animals that stay on her bed and she had a definite sense of pride about it. Love this set.

title: Kids had a great time with this.
text:
There was no stopping the kids when this arrived. They were mixing it within 10 minutes of opening the box and sitting in the windowless bathroom twenty minutes later playing with their slime. We actually have made Elmer's slime before so that was not new to the kids, but the glow in the dark part added a lot of interest, on top of the fact that it is slime.

If I had any constructive criticism, it would be that that the packaging is a little much. These could have been put in thin pouches to reduce the plastic and add ease in getting the glue out. Glue bottles are designed to limit the speed at getting glue out. in this application that is a little annoying.

title: A Little Pricey, Mixed Results
text:
We have made a number of forays into this concept with mixed results from DOA ants, to decent tunneling ants. It can be fascinating to watch their progress or frustrating when it is more a lesson of life and death as you ants die one my one without really doing anything.

In this case the biggest differences in the concept is that it can be lit with LED's to give a spacy look at night. This doesn't add anything for the ants and not much for the viewer except for a little coolness.

My biggest beef with this is the current $30 price tag. For that price you should be more than just a piece of plastic with fifty cents of electronics. At the very least it should be free ants with free shipping. It just seems a little steep compared to earlier farms we have had. Also, know that you can refill the tank and reorder ants (which have generally short lifespans - a couple months.)

It's ok and we are looking forward to our ants, just a little pricey for something that is not appreciably better than other sets.

title: Interesting Game
text:
This game feels like a lot of constructs around a simple rummy like card game or maybe Rummycube. It is a nicely skinned game with beautiful and interesting artwork, and the addition of coins and auctions make it a more involved game, but I really like the simplicity of the games core. It is easy to teach but takes some time to get the values of things.

We played four rounds with three and four people and I think that have all four going is the best. It is interesting how the strategies of spending your money works over the rounds. I definitely came out of the gate too fast the first couple games. This is a pretty decent game, but probably will not be a go to game in the future, but definitely good to have in the collection.

title: A Cute Idea
text:
I like the idea, although I am not super impressed by the kit itself. There are not a lot of shrinking ornaments. Our family has been doing Christmas Shrinky Dinks for years, usually just freehanding onto the blank sheets and cutting them out. We tend to do a dozen each with eight to ten people involved so this does not go very far for our family tradition. The tree is also not overwhelming, but it is nice enough. I do like that there are other decorations, but I think with more thought there could have been a better assortment of ornaments.

It's sounding like I'm being a little harsh. I am a little disappointed, but we are definitely looking up to the run up to Christmas and will make this kit with a little added material from our collection. For now, our youngest is displaying the tree in her room so she is ready. Looking forward to it.

title: My Youngest Loves Unikitty and loved this set
text: This is a nice little set for the price point.  It is hits my youngest son perfectly in his love for all things unikitty and gives a good assortment of unique pieces.  I find the build itself a little disposeable although he really loved building it.  I would expect the pieces to be quickly incorporated into his own creations, but for now they have a place of honor on the display shelves.  All in all a small but nice set.

title: This is a cute idea
text:
Our two youngest are absolute plushie addicts and they both approved of this little unicorn although they said it was definitely four, not five stars because it could be softer and cuter. Personally, I think this idea is wonderfully unique, but you need to have a number of these to make the concept reach its potential and we currently only have the unicorn.

The magnets are probably perfectly strong. The limbs are easy to peel off, but they will not come off accidentally. When fully disassembled and stuck to the fridge, the scene is a little disturbing. It will be better when we get more so we can mix and match. But all in all, a cute and well executed idea.

title: Kids Are Drooling Over the Parts
text:
My kids are maybe a little old for this book, but they are also old enough to truly appreciate the collection of gears that come in this set. They did build a couple of the ideas in the book and we all found it interesting that Klutz combined paper elements into their Lego constructions. My kids are somewhat snobby purists so they were not really for it, but I think it is a great idea for more open-minded and younger builders.

Most of the builds are simple science tricks like making a strobing slot movie machine or a spinning image that also strobes when you spin it to blend images. There are also the fan favorites like a catapult and a boxing robot - both of which the kids built. But mostly I think this will end up being incorporated into other home builds. Which is fine because this truly is a great collection of parts. We got the contraption set before and it lit up the boys creativity with all kinds of simple machines.

title: A Decent Game for Younger Players
text:
We got this because my youngest is a nacho addict and it looked similar to a game we play a lot call Guacamole where you try to match a chosen recipe. This game is similar in that you are trying to find an ingredient match but on a single chip. When you get a match there is a lot of giggling and surprisingly few stubbed fingers (thankfully) when trying to grab Spikey to claim the victory.

Our kids range from 10-17 and the tweens enjoyed it but oldest was not interested. I don't think it will be in heavy rotation, but it was fun served with a side of Nachos (Spikey wipes down well from cheese grease.) Fun but probably forgettable.

title: Intimidating Looking at pieces, but Game Plays Well and can be Learned Quickly
text:
I have not played the other games in this series or game designer, but I can say that it does have some rough similarities to Carcassonne, which is fantastic. It is a more difficult than Carcassonne, but easy enough to be able to learn as you go. And like Carcassonne this ease of learning belies a depth of strategy as you try to both build and score and block. We have played it three times and we are still getting the strategies.

This game left out some of our younger players and worked better with 14 and up but a fairly experience gaming tween would probably have little problem. Perhaps one age limiting aspect is that there are many, many small pieces and the game sprawls with lots of pieces to bump. The games lasted a little over an hour, it might shorten with experience of rules and strategies. Don't let the mass of pieces overwhelm you, the basic idea of the game is easy. However, there are lots of ways to score and there are great layers of strategy. This game is not lost on tosses of the dice either.

All in all, I recommend this game.

title: Wonderfully Unique and Simple to Learn
text:
Wow! there are a few things I love in games; easy to learn rules, ability to ages, and uniqueness. This comes up in spades for all of those and you can add a healthy dose of collaboration. It is so much better to see kids working together than squabbling. We played this game through twice and the kids were super engaged. Ages 9=17 and a middle aged parent and we all enjoyed it. It is wonderfully unique along the lines of ICE COOL which we got about this time last year.

The games is super well constructed. I love the lantern, the sturdy trees, and the awesome little woodland animals. I also love the it is play completely in the dark. This is a perfect game for the tent or dark winters evening. It is wonderfully moody.

I don't know that this is a game that will be brought out a lot, but I highly recommend it. This game rocks in its simple uniqueness.

title: Kids Love Them, I'm Tiring of Collectibles
text: In a world of over packaged, often pricey, disposable collectibles these stand on the up half, mostly pushed there by their amazingly impressive scents.  As soon as my youngest son was exposed to them he want some.  And as soon as he had some, he wanted more, then all...then the last series...then the next series.  But I think we will be cutting this collectible short.  They are fun to open (in part because of some egregious over packaging) and they are worth while because of their strong, long lasting, and pleasant scents.  But we have already spent a years tuition on things like this.  My son would give these five stars, I'll give them four because they seem to be better than a lot of these collectibles, although they are rather cheap and tiny plushes for $5 a piece, but kids need to follow the fads.

title: Ridiculous and Fun
text:
Well first, this game is absolutely ridiculous. Some of the challenges with the hands are near to impossible. But it did exactly what we hoping for at our last family reunion. It got several families blended into the fun and laughing hysterically, even those who had just driven 12 hours. The premise is easy, you have to do everything with Tiny or Tinier fake hands from catching a ball to acting out charades. The rules are simple although the rules of betting and scoring were less than clear to us. To be honest, we pretty much abandoned the betting and scoring of each round and just played the cards and the spinner. In the end we just declared the kids the winners.

Some things we learned.
- Put the score card well out of harms way. Ours was trod upon and score pieces were constantly tossed around.
- You cannot hold onto a pen with the hands like a baseball bat and swing it without impaling someone with the pen
- Give yourself lots of room
- The Charades part went over best.

Not sure how often this will come out, but it is a great leveler of ages and abilities and plays well in groups as long as kids are eight and up. It is kinetic, laugh producing and fun.

title: Funny, Laugh Inspiring, but Probably not a Frequently Played Game
text:
We might be the exact target for this game. We have years been playing, guess this smell - usually with candles at boutiques. But the kids, for no understandable reason, think that that Russian roulette game with jelly beans is the greatest game ever. This game plays very much like that one so the kids loved it. They were on the edge of asphyxia laughing and they were totally in the game either gross or good. The Whiff of Shame may now be embeddened into our family lore.

Personally, I could take or leave the game, except that they loved it. I really can't see them playing it again and perhaps this might be best viewed as a one time party came. Perhaps it will come out again, but I think it has had it's day. The app is kind of nice in that you can leverage your phone for timing and it engaged the kids even more. Bad faces are now kept for posterity.

title: Great Minifigures
text:
I feel kind of bad for the reviews that this bundle has been getting. It sounds like most of the issues have been with distribution and order fulfillment more than the quality of the product. The products are very decent and have even won over my Lego purist kids with the detail and quality of the figures. You basically, in theory, should be getting an bundle with six individually packaged mini figures with no or a small bulk discount. That I guess is my biggest fault with this product - repackage the figures and give a decent price break.

I do like the video game tie ins that go into these sets, although my kids like them despite not knowing the games. We have been getting a number of mega construx kits in the last few years and where they would not even look at them twice, they now grudgingly accept them despite the lack of a lego name and they have especially grown to appreciate the C0D line.

Keep an eye on this product, if it gets consistently packaged and delivered, this will be a great set to have.

title: Great Idea, Perhaps needs a 4.0
text:
First, this is one of the greatest ideas I have seen in a while. I had seen a couple mentions of the kickstarter and I really wanted to get my hands on one. At $50 they are in no way cheap, but the idea truly is amazing and plays especially well in my house where my oldest son wants to be a pilot and we have an amazing array of RC planes and drones.

Unfortunately, not all great ideas are easy to pull off. I like that you make your own airplane, but we divvied out the papers and not every plane came out usable. It takes a little crafting and folding ability to get it right. But we did get one that came out perfect (mine.) The parts are small and unfortunately delicate. I am especially worried about the prop and the connector piece that joins the cockpit to the prop. It is a testemant to our engineering abilities to have RC controls and an engine small enough to be carried by and propel a paper airplane, but it also shows that we are testing the material and economic limits of the idea.

We flew it a few times in the house before quickly realizing that it needed a much bigger space. I don't think we damaged it, but we never got a chance to run it through more than a quick turn before a crash. Our attempts at using it outside did not go well because of wind. It wasn't until we brought it into work and flew it in a large atrium that we could really test the controls. They were not super responsive and it seemed like we could get out of range quickly, but I can see the possibilities now.

It is a great little idea that seems like it might need a little more work, but we have had fun with it.

title: A Perfect Kit For Creative and Imaginative Fun
text:
This is a perfect idea for a creative play activity that will have some legs. My sons wore out their capes and there were times when you couldn't get them to take them off. But the capes we had were a little more substantial than this one. This one is decent enough and the masks give a little more creative activity. But it is definitely the cape that is the star of this show.

We actually used this to entertain a friends two year old. Perhaps he was a little young - three or four would probably be a better match, but he truly loved it, to the point that at the end of the afternoon, we let him wear it home rather than add it to the family dress up box. A perfect gift for any youngster.

title: Another Adorable Craft Kit from Clutz
text:
I love Klutz' clay projects. It is so easy to make an adorable little keepsake and the kids love them. This one is a little different than I expected as it actually is a lot like cake decorating. You do not form the entire creation but rather you decorate a preformed foam core. It actually is very much like cake decorating with fondant. The instruction book is both great at showing you how to make different directions and showing you a myriad of creative ideas so you can wing it. Or copy their ideas exactly. Either way it makes wonderfully cute little creations.

The kids really loved this particular kit and quickly had a half dozen donuts to show off. Dollar for Dollar they are very good entertainment and I can't imagine that this one will not be revisited soon.

title: Cute and very soft to the touch
text:
This guy is pretty cute, bordering on too cutesy. It is soft, or at least it's short fibered plush is very soft to the touch. The stuffing is a medium firmness and he makes a soft but not overly luxurious huggable plush. My youngest son has fallen in love with it and it is the plush of the moment and from his reaction, I think it will be for some time (Until his next new plush.)

The construction seems of decent quality and I think it will hold up well. Perhaps small for the asking price.

title: Unique but Functionally not as Good as the Original
text:
I really like the uniqueness of this idea although it has one big problem in function. We have a son who loves the rubiks cube and studied up to figure out how to solve it. Apparently missing the middle piece does not really change his process, but having to rework the turning mechanisms does. He was a little frustrated by the difficulty of turning the sides of the cube. His made cube has been lubricated with graphite and he can fly through the solution. This one takes a little finesse to get the sides to turn and it really slows him down.

If they could make it move like the others, it would be five stars

title: Ridiculous, But My Youngest Son Loved It
text:
What's not to like about a toilet that spews fart noises. Well at least for a young boy. My youngest has always been a sucker for mini collectible figurines and he claims that these are fantastic. I found them to be a bit of a step down in quality than the ones we usually get (minecraft etcetera.) The figures again, very much appeal to the young and scatologically humored.

All in all this is a cute but superfluous toy. It does store a decent number of figurines while being completely inappropriate for a dinner party where your kids can embarrass you. so my kid loves it.

title: Great Pieces and Minifigures, Apparently not a Kit the Kids Wanted to Keep Together
text:
This set has a strangely "Lego Friends" feel to it, with some superhero minifigures thrown into it. This is fine, in fact it brings some very unique pieces to our collection. My kids and I appreciate the reference to the Batman movie and my youngest son is super excited about getting Wonder Dog. My older son went through the model showing me what he planned to do with the parts. The clear pole parts are now supporting a couple of his microbuilds.

The build is pretty straight forward and was completed in under twenty minutes, with a partial tear down and repurposing of pieces nearly immediately. They did keep the DJ station together and put it in their MOC city. I appreciate the more obscure mini figures most of which went immediately into our framed display.

IT is a decent set for pieces, but did not inspire my kids to keep it complete.

title: A Decent Build for an Interesting new Lego Franchise
text:
This is an interesting product line, kind of a Lego Power Miners meets Lego City. It brings a more realistic, but not completely realistic, set of models to the mining theme. There is a little fantasy in the drilling vehicle in this set, but then there are details like the assay table. There are some interesting pieces incorporated in the set, we especially like the gold nuggets and glow in the dark spider. All in all and good set.

Where we are not so happy with this set, this is set at the $49.99 price point which typically has a single large vehicle or building model. This set seems a little less impressive than most models at this price point. I think it is because it lumps a mid sized vehicle with a small vehicle, a small mine façade and some detail pieces. The piece count is there, but there is no single element that really says "Wow!" It seems like a combination of a few cheaper sets.

I am interested to see where this set goes. I don't think it will be a big franchise, but it is an interesting idea. Perhaps a realistic representation of real mining equipment would be nice. At any rate, this is an okay set, a decent build, but we liked it more than we loved it.

title: I wish it was built a little better, Good Concept though
text:
I was hoping to like this a whole lot more than I did. I picked up a 6 dollar plastic Ammo box for my sons collection and this one looked a lot better. But the construction of this box does not stand up well. It is a very basic box with some light precut foam. The sticker on the side has bubbles in it which looks a little shoddy and the whole thing feels a little cheap. I wish the foam was more rigid, although that would make it harder to get all spinners to fit, but as it is, the foam seems a little cheap. The one thing I do like about it is the clasps that hold the case shut, those seem a little more rugged and feel good when snapping the box shut. I wish the rest of the box lived up to the clasps, especially at over $25. For 6 dollars the Ammo can had a way better build, although it did not hold and display the spinners as well as this one.

This is a good concept (well if a box meant to store something as inane as fidget spinners can be a good concept) but it just wasn't manufactured as well as I would have hoped.

I do wish I could give this 3.5 stars based solely on the fact that my kid really likes it, but I can't bring myself to set it at 4 stars.

title: Great Mechanical, Educational Set
text:
This set is kind of like Lego meets Erector Set meets the How It Works series. This is the perfect set for young STEM or any kid with mechanical curiosity. It strips down pneumatic systems to a very visible and basic system and shows how it works in quick little projects. To be honest, I don't know if the other projects will ever be built because the kids are having too much fun with the mechanical arm set, but most look interesting.

I love that the construction was decently challenging for our tweens but clear and easy enough to finish unaided. Wonderfully fun to build, fun to play with and educational through the whole process.

title: Beuatiful Little Game
text:
Alright, the first couple of plays through were a little rough for us. I kept feeling that it was a little like Fluxx, where when you think someone is doing well, there is a sudden reversal. Even when you think you are cornering the market on one of the counters, they are suddenly worthless. It seemed a little chaotic and random. But by the end of the round strategy was coming out. There are multiple things to watch including the rock paper scissors round of what beats what as well as care to watch what pointers people are acquiring. Quickly it became more than just a pretty game.

And it is a very pretty game. The cards are large and well illustrated. I like that everyone gets rules cards to reference. The rules were less than clear, but made sense once they were deciphered. We also went to youtube after struggling a bit and it reinforced that we were doing it right. Perhaps that would have been a better first step.

The game itself is easy and we played with a group from 11 to 49 and we all seemed to grasp it well enough to make sense of things. In the end it actually is kind of a simplistic game with a lot of room for strategy. It is a game of quick rounds so a game is the sum of four rounds. It seems very balanced and is much more than just a luck of the draw game. It was well worth the bit of struggle we had with the first couple rounds.

title: Gross Fun that Kids Loved at Least Once
text:
Our household has a legend of the girl scout taste testing challenge where most of the girls puked after trying pickle juice. This game brings back all the excitement of that experience and puts it into a playful contest. To be honest this perfectly fits the sensibilities of most of our kids. They love that Russian rouhlette jelly bean game for some reason. Personally I can't stand it, but they love the daringness of it.

The game itself is super easy. Basically just a spinner to give you the random concoctions and a handful of chips to count your points showing how brave or non brave you are. I don't know if this game will come out much more but the kids certainly enjoyed coming up with potential ingredients and playing through it once.

The construction of the game pieces is fine for a game that will not be used too much. It is decent but not super high quality.

title: Love these Klutz craft book sets, great outcomes
text:
We have had a couple of these sets including the puppies and the pom pom animals and they are pretty good craft sets. Partly easy, partly a little challenging. Creating the Pom Poms is interesting and I like the little tool they give to make them. Youngsters love wrapping the yarn around the form over and over, but it takes some adult supervision to tie off all the pieces so the poms don't fall apart. There are a few other things that take a little bit of help, but in general, kids can make very nice looking little pets.

We made a couple and we have plenty of materials to make more. Also, like many Klutz kits, you have the tools and idea book to inspire many more creations with a quick trip to Hobby Lobby or Michaels for more materials. We had several hours of entertainment with this set and I would guess we have many more to come.

title: We love these Klutz Kits, but this one needs a little more patience and skills
text:
We adore the Klutz art kits, especially the clay and eraser making kits. We had always passed on this one because it looks like it is a decent step harder than the others and we were right. It takes a lot more patience and hand eye coordination to sew a cute cartoon creation than it does to roll weird shaped balls of clay. But this kit is pretty nice. I would have given it five stars if it weren't for the clay and eraser kits which seemed easier and kept the kids engaged better.

The kit does have all you need to make some pretty adorable creations. Three of the four of us made donuts as our test creations and one tried the lemon. For the most part we made decent donuts, but the lemon looks a little more like a potsticker. We improved our stitching rather quickly, but I suspect our next creations will be considerably better. We did augment the set with a couple of additional sewing needles and some thread to give all four of us a chance to work at the same time. We also will be buying more felt. There is a decent amount in the kit for an introduction, but if it takes off we will quickly run out. (We did the same with bake clays for the clay kit.)

I hope this takes off for a couple of the kids because the end product is very cute.

title: An Abosolutely Great Craft Kit for a Wide Range of Ages
text:
I love these sets and love to see what the kids come up with. It is actually on our default birthday gift list right now. We have bought two sets for our kids and several as gifts for birthday parties, and still, the kids were amped that we were getting another one.

This kit and the clay making kits are great for all skill levels. The books give great inspirations for creations and it is easy to create little cartoony fruits and vegetables or even animals. Likewise if you want to take off with your creativity you are unlimited. Well almost unlimited, if creations get too big or intricate, they can fail during the baking process. We have had a few disasters, but typically they come out great.

I can't say enough good things about this. I think it is one of the best craft sets out there.

title: A Decent Set for a Nice Girl Friendly Line
text:
We are a huge Lego family and my youngest had enjoyed the Friends line and now is Fanatical with the Elves line. The DC Super Hero Girls line falls right in with the friends lines with it's girl friendly themes and figures that lean more toward dolls than action figures. Personally I'm not a huge fan with these sets as many of them, like this one, have elements that are simply furniture or small ancillary builds. Also they have pieces that are more doll accessories than building blocks, for example hair brushes. I prefer the creativity of recombining parts which will not work with a very representational, not studded hair brush.

But these sets are not for me, but for my youngest and he truly loves them, at least the Elves line. The DC line is not quite as treasured which is why I'm giving it four stars, but it has all the quality you expect from Lego.

title: A Great Addition to our Collection
text:
The kids really like Magformers and we wanted this set to help fill out their building possibilities which it did well. Not only does this set come with a decent selection of base squares and triangles, it also added a pentagon shape to help widen possibilities. We were not sold on the TNMT theme, but for practical purposes this only means that there were a handful of removable plates with the characters on them.

We did notice that the construction of the pieces seemed a little less quality than our other MagFormers. They went with a solid opaque color plastic rather than the transparent color of earlier sets. They still worked together well but are not quite as good looking.

title: The Plush Dog is Adorable
text:
I'm not a huge fan of the pet in a bag plushes, but my kid loves this. I have to admit that the pup is actually adorable. It is small but sweet and well formed and manufactured. The donut bag is a little less adorable but it is made fine. However, out of the wrapper the stuffed animal had a strong chemical smell but it quickly disipated.

My son really does love this little plush and would give it five stars.

title: Holy Moly...
text:
This moose has a whole lot of wow factor. It is huge and imposing and since we live in Minnesota, totally appropriate to our kids room décor. It is larger than our two Shepherd mix dogs and may take a little thinking about where to display it. And unfortunately it will probably be displaying rather than cuddling in its future. It is soft, but the standing posture and legs make it difficult for cuddling.

It is fairly lifelike, but as a nature lover, I am a little critical of the way the tines sit on the antlers and the hooves are turned a little. The head is a little misformed for a moose, but it is completely obvious what it is. I'm probably harsher on that than anyone but I am happy with the likeness. I'm concerned long term about the sturdiness of the legs as I have seen a couple kids test out the moose's rideability which seems low.

This seems like I am being critical of this plush, but its awe inspiring size and uniqueness easily make it five stars and treasured. This would be amazing to find under a Christmas Tree.

title: My Son's been Writing in it since He Got It
text:
I was a little wary when the box arrived and it seemed to be just a little product in a big box. But upon opening it, both my youngest son and I were very pleased. It is a decent little diary with everything you need to make it perfect; lock, stickers, and little gem like colored nubs to decorate the book. He loved creating it and has been writing in it all evening, which is everything you can hope for. It is substantial enough that it will not be easily discarded.

The price is decent for what you get. Journals can easily be the same price although perhaps a little better quality and more pages, but all in all this was a wonderful product.

title: I Love the Idea of the Silicone Mold, Wish There Was More to the Kit
text:
Our family loves shrink dinks and we have holiday traditions where all the kids get together and create with blank sheets and sharpies. Often we try to make three dimensional creations with usually disappointing results. So I love the idea of the silicon mold, however... It would be great if there were more than one mold so you could create dozens of hearts at a time.

The kit is a great idea for expanding the possibilities of Shrinky Dinks, but there is precious little material here, a couple dozen strips which should be several sheets of material. The colored pencils are fine, but we ended up using markers we already had. The jewelry chains and connecting rings were nice, but still few in number. Definitely the most exciting thing in the box were the self adhering gems, and it may be the only thing in the box that I felt neared the proper quantity.

So it is a cute idea. We did have fun with the toaster oven, but the set really should have at least double the materials to allow for flexibility and make it more enjoyable for more people...At least two.

title: Simple, Fun, Entertaining
text:
Well, it is what it is. A simple, entertaining game with a touch of grossness. Everything the kids need to enjoy.

We definitely had fun trying out the game. Actually, I found it far easier to talk with the mouthpiece in, only hard consonants and maybe sibilants were hard, but that definitely made the provided challenge phrases challenging. The rules are incredibly easy which is nice. Everyone can be fully up to speed, well basically instantly. Great party game, horrible first date game. No one wants to see anyone's skeletal jaws.

Avoid snack food during the game.

title: Great addition to the basic Starter Pack
text: We got the 3ddoodler starter pack a while ago and loved it. But over time we lost enthusiasm for it.  This simple little kit has brought it out again. I love the templates for making simple shapes, and you can always use a refill of sticks. The stencils is a very easy way to make freehanding shapes easier. In minutes we made better creations than we were making before.  I look forward to many similar sets.

title: Accurate, Sturdy and Fun
text:
This may have been a little smaller than I was envisioning...Glad there are some reviewer photos now, but it is way more sturdy than I expected. This is actually a pretty serious little toy here. It does propel the bolts with some zip, so not good for adding to our nerf gun wars, but great for random target shooting. And comparing this to Nerf, this is definitely more accurate, perhaps because the darts don't deform, but I think mostly because this has a great release.

There is minimal assembly, and I'm glad that they chose sturdiness over some loose click in solution. The action is plenty ease for the kids 8-15, and the fun and challenge has kept them all busy using it. I am impressed about how many creative shooting challenges they have made for themselves.

For the price, this is a very well made toy.

title: Awe Inspiring Build from Lego
text:
Holy Crap Yes! We are a family of Lego Maniacs and this set is wonderful. I have a fifteen year old and we recently got the newest Millenium Falcon and I had a realization that his abilities were quite beyond that set, and most sets out there, so I started looking at the expert and Technic sets. This set was perfect, it is a step up in challenge and scope from the standard sets. It was great to watch him to tear into the bags and deliberately build. Not only was it a little more challenging, but the scope if far more impressive. The set itself is huge, and the architectural elements are involved although somewhat repetitive.

We worked on this over several days and we are quite happy with the results. The build is detailed and has some very interesting pieces. Especially nice are the clock faces that are beautiful. The back printing on the clear disk gives them a gem like quality, they are sharp clean and wonderfully graphic. Absolutely beautiful. Also impressive are the scores of micro figures (usually found in Lego games.) Long term, I'm not sure that we will ever need this many tan microfigures on any build, but interesting piece. Also nice are the literally hundreds of architectural detail pieces from the little teeth pieces to the spires.

We actually looked up photos of Big Ben and we are astounded at the details. It is a wonderful representation of the end of the building. If I had anything negative to say about the build it would be that it is a bit of a façade for that end of Westminster. Which is forgivable given all the detail and how many pieces (and space) it would take to make the whole building.

All in all, this was an incredible build. I'll try to get the time lapse up when I can get it edited.

title: Nice Intro to Scale Modelling that Resulted in a Decent Playable Toy
text:
This is a nice little introduction to Scale Models. You do not need anything that doesn't come in the box, and can easily build the model in a half hour. I grew up making Revell scale models and have tried several times to get my oldest son into them with some success. I wish I had these when I was trying to get him started on the hobby. The construction is easy and with no glue or painting needed it, it is pretty frustration free.

The model is not the finest craftsmanship, but the resulting model is decently detailed and has playability. The inclusion of a sound and light chip makes it more interactive than other scale models. Repositionable wings and removable landing gear also make it fun to play with after the build.

It is still a long way to from here to an actual scale model, but it was nice seeing my son confidently construct the model which has not happened with harder models. Hope this moves him further into the hobby.

title: Great Build of the Warthog
text:
I built this with my partners son who plays his share of Halo. My experience with Halo is limited, but I also appreciated the beloved Warthog. Years ago I remember playing Warthog soccer with a Warthog and some explosives to drive the vehicle down the field so we were both interested in the build.

The design is wonderfully spot on. Obviously they designed some parts to match the vehicle exactly. The details are amazing and the build pushed the eleven year old. The instructions were good, but challenging as to where the parts went on and I think it was a satisfying rather than frustrating challenge. The end product is perfect for play or display and it has been vowed that it will never be taken apart. Right now it sits in a place of honor on a dresser.

We are definitely a lego family, but we have been impressed with the build we have gotten from Mega Bloks.

title: Another Good Build, Not Quite as Good as Others in the Series
text:
We recently got the Mega Bloks Desert Tank and it nearly converted my oldest son who is a die hard Lego evangelizer and a Lego purist. He was very impressed with that build for its detail and its quality. We liked this one for its detail, but we are a little less enamored with the design. The boat is a little ridiculous and the guns are a little less realistic. But the build was still a challenge and he welcomed having some more Call of Duty elements to fit in with his tank.

These builds are more challenging than similar Lego builds. For me there is an additional challenge as I am color blind and I have some issues reading the instructions. For my son who is now 15 and graduating from the standard Lego lines (don't tell him that.) These are a decent challenge and with his love of military vehicles, I think we will keep getting the COD sets, at least the realistic ones. Personally I'm impressed with the builds.

While this set does not live up to the Desert Tank set, it was a nice little build. The details in the mounted guns is nice as are steering wheels etc. Gave four stars because the design of the front end of the boat is a little clumsy and less aesthetically pleasing.

title: Poseable and Collectible
text:
We got a couple of these and this is my least favorite, mostly because of the accessories. But in general, I am impressed with the interactive play that these lead to. We have recently gotten a couple collectible figurines and these are definitely made for play not just display. The kids have loved these and were excited to add one more to their collection. The price is decent enough to afford several and allow for extended play.

The manufacturing seems good and the quality is good enough that they should last through the play. They joints move well and the only thing I have questions about is the quality and design of the canon. Also, I was impressed more with the accessories from the other sets which is why this one only gets four stars. Also, I find Pinkie Pie rather plain.

title: A Kinetic Simon
text:
We have had a few Simon and Bopit toys and the kids love them and go back to playing them whenever they come across them. This game holds them as well as any of those others, but it is uniquely kinetic, which we totally love.

This game encourages movement and develops hand eye accordination. It's still just a game, but I love that it brings in this motion. Also I like that it is unique and intrigues kids to try it. It has been great watching the kids introduce each other to it.

title: Love the real firing projectiles
text:
Decent RC action and controls. It ate up the terrain indoors and the garage/driveway. The controls were very easy and can easily work for ages 6 and up. Our household is 9 and up and everyone loved it.

But the two things that really make this RC stick out are, first...it is Halo, and not only is it Halo, but it is the warthog. I can thing of very few gaming vehicles that is more beloved. It is almost a must for any gamer who plays Halo.

The second standout is even bigger. The fact that it shoots real missiles, even at underwhelming speeds and distances has made it so much cooler than even laser firing tanks. This has been a scourge to the pets, but totally engaging with young drivers. We've never had remotely controlled projectiles, but we are loving it.

title: Well Constructed, Well Visuallized Playset.
text:
This is a great play set that incorporates so many of the cute little ideas from the movie. I love that the jail bars has a large opening door for bigger animals and a smaller one for the littlest animals. Same with the elevator which is a wonderful idea observing the diversity of animals. The set brings all the originality of the movie to a toy.

Also strangely unique to the toy are the amazing little electronic touches, voices that reference movie characters and a projecting computer that brings up mug shots of animal criminals. these are such nice little touches.

The structure is made out of substantial plastic and I would assume this will hold up well over time. The only bad thing is that we will need to hunt down a couple more characters to truly enjoy the set, but love that Bogo and the Sky Squirrel are in the set.

title: An Interactive, Well Designed MLP Collectible
text:
I got this for my youngest who is a big fan of the Ponies and well on his way to becoming a Brony. Personally I like that this is articulated and can actually be played with, more like an action figure. Many of the Ponies toys are just collectible figurines that are more decorative than interactive. This seems to lend itself to play.

I also really like that this comes with several additional fun pieces, mostly the sunglasses and sword are nice but the Cockatrice is also a nice addition. Judging by my sons reaction, this is one of the better MLP collectible.

title: Holy Crap, High Performance, Very impressive physically
text:
This is a very big gun with a very big clip (so big that you can't even fill it with the balls that come with the blaster. So expect to want refills immediately.) It is packaged so epically, it would make an eye opening birthday or Christmas present. Very imposing. And even more imposing when it is unboxed.

We are a huge Nerf gun house and we have literally dozens of guns from over the years and darts behind every couch or chair in the house, but this is our first of the guns that shoot the little balls. Our first impressions are that they fire more consistently and don't get bent or chewed up like the darts do over a short time. our second impression is that they sting more when you are shot. Enough so that there are now house rules about not shooting people with it.

If it were not for Nerf, I don't think my kids would know what C or D batteries are. (in this case D) It is a minor investment to fill the gun with batteries but we have not seen any degredation in the workings so far after almost a week of regular daily play, although none of the battles were sustained.

All in all, we are very, very happy with this gun. They kids were in awe of it in unboxing and in test shooting. It has caused a few arguments about who gets to use it, followed by a bigger argument about who can be shot with it. Despite these small arguments, I'm still glad we got it.

title: Instructions are frustratingly cryptic
text:
I think this would be a five star quadcopter at this price if it weren't for the pain of needing to decrypt the instructions. If you were new to the hobby and didn't know about trimming the controls, you would find the device frustrating at best, if not unusable. Ours came with a strong forward drift that would have been very hard to overcome. And if you were familiar with trimming the controls, you are still on for a challenge that will take a few rereads to figure it out.

Ok, manual rant over, remember that this is a sub $50 quadcopter. For the price I am impressed with it. It is entry level and is rugged enough to take some abuse, but it is not designed to last forever. It's flight is fairly steady and once trimmed properly the hover function is fairly good. The controls are ok. I appreciate the one button take offs and landings which is easy for novices once they are calm enough to remember to push them.

The camera is ok, remember again the whole copter is $50 so don't expect go pro quality... It is fun and the kids have enjoyed exploring the world from above. They enjoyed shooting and filming from above. Note you will need a micro SD. (Not included, remember, sub $50) it is a fun although toyish.

All in all, it is fun. Perhaps it is not the easiest quad we've had out of the box, but once tweaked it has been stable and at a price point that is decent for novices.

title: My youngest loves this figure
text:
We got this and the princess celestia figure and I have to admit that they do make good counterparts to each other. They are dramatic sculptures and are rather impressive.

I do think that these are made far more for the collector than the young fan. Due to the design they are decorative and not great for interactive play. They look good on the shelf but they are not poseable nor can they be played with as figures due to the extra plastic around the ponies. So expect more of a collectible sculpture rather than a toy.

My kids are impressed with the figure, and I do appreciate the elegance of design. A great collectible.

title: My youngest loves this figure
text:
This is definitely meant for the collector rather than a play thing. It is not a poseable toy so much as a display piece. For my youngest it is a joy because it is his favorite character and he was in awe of it when it arrived. I don't want to jump to conclusions but he may be a future Bronie.

The design is elegant and the colors and shapes are dramatic as anyone familiar with the show might expect. But this is visually a step above the average ponies toy.

Personally I would rather put money toward a more interactive toy, but I can't knock it since my son loves it.

title: Kids liked it, the end product is ok
text:
Well my kids were excited about this craft kit although I can't say I'm that big on it. I think they saw it as a stuffed animal although it is more of a display piece that a cuddle toy.

As for construction it is kind of unique the way the cloth gets embedded into the body of the model. It took a little adult supervision and some practice to get the spacing and density of cloth strips right and some supervision on going. So it was not the self directed activity I was hoping for.

In the end, the figure looks ok, the kids had some fun and we got to work together. I'm giving it four rather than four stars because I am not overwhelmed with the end product of the kit. It is a static display that doesn't encourage ongoing play. But all in all it was a good kit.

title: A nice activity for the kids, bowls seem nice
text:
We got these on a rainy Saturday and the kids tore into the box to make their bowls. They had a good 45 minutes of preppy and building and now we are waiting for things to dry.

We made the biggest and smallest and they look good. The kids seemed to have had a good time but they are not overthrilled to do any more bowls despite having more supplies.

I do think these are going to be cute bowls for holding little desktop treasures but not my favorite end product for a craft kit. It's a nice little kit that the kids and I enjoyed but did not love.

title: Amazing Build, and that's Coming from a Lego Family
text:
Ok first let me say, we are a "it's Lego or its crap" family. My kids evangelize on the evils of Megablocks and other brands they consider knock offs. But this is such a well engineered and detailed set that my fifteen year old wasn't even grudging when he said, this is a really good set.

And he's right, the detail on this set is super impressive. My son loves it for what seems like very authentic design from a war historian rather than a gamer, so maybe a fan of COD would like it even more.

This is a very challenging build, filled with small parts and unlike Lego that pre bags parts so you can open a single bag to do the first couple pages of instructions, mega blocks has you open 80% of the bags for the first few pages. You end up with an impressive pile of pieces out there. Also unlike Lego, mega blocks will create molded pieces specific to a model so realism can be pushed farther than Lego does. In this set, the body is filled with parts that are not just molded to shape but also in color to seem camouflaged or dirty from use. This truly lends a wonderful realism to the model. We also appreciated that markings are screen printed onto pieces rather than using stickers. Kudos for doing that it makes it feel like a quality set.

I do notice a bit more brittleness in the blocks and brick for brick the quality does not seem to match lego, but I can do little but rave over this set. It is beautiful, it took my son and I working together to get this done in several hours. And once done, this is a beautiful set for display.

Well done Mega Block, you are doing what I thought was impossible, you are winning us over from Lego.

*** additional

My son wanted me to mention that the instructions were hard, I would use challenging. But one thing I did forget, I am partially colorblind and often found it hard to distinguish colors in the instructions if it was not daylight.

title: Cute figures, lots of fun
text:
We get a lot of craft kits, especially to entertain the kids over summer break. And we have learned that an inpermanent mess is better than a lame completed project that you have to keep and display somewhere. This kit makes wonderfully small and display able figures.

The kids had a blast spin molding and painting the figures. The set was bigger than expected and I have a little guilt that it took so much plastic into what will almost certainly be a one days use product (unless we order or find refills.) but this project did keep them busy for a couple half days, one molding and one painting and their figures turned out cute.

title: Another great Dino figure from Schleich
text:
Schleich has not always had the best dinosaur line. But I have been extremely happy with the improvements they have made in the last couple of years. This figure continues that new standard, the details are great, the pose is great, and it's heft in your had screams of quality.

The facial details are bold as is the color scheme. I'm not certain how closely they nailed the representation, but the unquestionable details like teeth and toenails are authentic.

This is a great addition to any dinosaur lovers collection.

title: Great Project for Young Builders
text:
We are a Lego family and we don't get many KNex kits but we do have one of their rollercoasters, this is our second. These make great and somewhat challenging builds and I appreciate the finished coaster as well as the constructon.

In this case it arrived during a summer day with a 10 year old looking for something to do. It took him about two hours to get it up and running with a few corrections along the way. He has played with it another hour since finishing it and seems very proud of it.

The coaster is not huge, less than three feet. Salk enough it can remain built. Our other one is a monstrosity that took forever to build then needed to be broken down to reclaim living space.

Highly recommend for young builders.

title: Absolutely the best craft kit we've ever gotten
text:
There was no stopping the kids once they saw this box. We get lots of craft kits for the kids and this one by far has received the best reaction. And on top of that, the finished product has the best chance of any to become treasured.

I can't say that it occupied them the longest, but it definitely had intensity. The girls quickly made great looking crowns out of a nice looking base wire and some surprisingly attractive paper flowers.

If you have girls who like to dress up, this is a must get. And I'll repeat again, this is one of the best craft kits we've ever gotten.

title: Similar to Spotit, good for kids of all ages
text:
We have never met a game from blue orange that we haven't liked. Mostly because the games are super easy to learn with simple premises but surprising complexity and playability. We love their games like Wink and Battlesheep which are great for wide age groups and easy enough to teach in a couple minutes.

This game is no different in ease of learning but not our favorite game from them. The game play is similar to spot it, and is on the same level of enjoyment. Which is good, but a step down from battle sheep and wink.

The game is well made, cards are decent, the tin is very nice and the cardboard tokens are solid.

title: Easy to pick up, fun to play
text:
I hadn't realized that we had bought or received so many Orange Blue games. I love that the have such simple premises, but end up being such wonderfully challenging games such as Battle Sheep or Wink.

This game might be the easiest, most straight forward of their games. To the good, the learning curve is instantaneous other than grasping the simple patterns of swapping marbles from one test tube to another. There is some mild spatial relations and some hand eye accordination to master but the basic rules are this easy. Match your test tubes to the pictured tubes by moving marbles back and forth like a mad scientist. If the marbles touch your hands or table you are out. First to match the pattern yells Eureka for a point. First to five points wins the game. That's it.

The test tubes and marbles are made well. There were some complaints from kids that the marbles are too slippery and don't always go into the tubes right, but then that is part of the point of the game.

We played a number of rounds with different mixes of ages. Almost anyone can be competitive and everyone can grasp the game. Love it for its inclusiveness and ease.

title: Hmm, Great Idea not Great Manufacturing
text:
I really had high hopes for this set. We opened it and I was a little disappointed with the quality of the materials. The idea itself is great and the parts are perfect for allowing for creativity. The boys love the set and are playing away with it right now. The little lights are genius, as their creation has been drug in and out of their closet for testing. That and the motor are perfect for exploration of simple circuits and electricity. The motor is pretty bare bones and could be better, but does the job. The cardboard, foam, and sticker elements are all fine, but again a little cheap feeling. It just seems like an extra step or two on quality of material would have gone a long ways towards making this a more satisfying set, although kudos for grabbing the kids imaginations with what is there.

What would be nice would be a pack of six of these for a birthday party. It's nice but maybe watch sales to get it at a price more in line with the materials. It is helping them pass a summer afternoon, fully engaged in their creations.

title: A decent T. rex. Wish they had continued to improve their Dino line.
text:
We are huge fans of the Papo series of dinosaurs which use Jurassic Park as their inspiration. Schleich has greatly stepped up their dinosaur line but hasn't quite matched Papo.

This one was a little disappointing in that it is nearly identical to their last TRex. It really would have been nice to have a different pose to have them sit together better.

The representation itself is well done, the moving jaws are nice. Details are nice. Wish they took another good step to the better, but their Dino's are good now.

title: Great Fun for the Kids
text:
We have had other string art kits and the kids loved them, so we looked forward to getting this set as well. Our youngest love crafts like this and we love having them settle down to make them and focus on non screen projects for a while. In this case it was an 8 and 9 year old doing the craft and they were able to complete everything without help other than finding scissors and getting a place set up for their work (well that and some nudging to clean up.)

The only reasons I did not give this kit 5 stars are, first, I didn't think the designs were as strong as others we have had. The bird and the word fun just didn't seem as strong as other designs they have (hearts, peace symbols, etc.) I guess shop around for the strongest designs. Second, these projects seem harder to display than others we have had. Craft-Tastic also makes a 3D string heart that we found far better for display after it is made. These seemed too good to toss, but not worth putting a hole in the wall to hang.

title: Nice Craft Set, Good End Product, Some Minor Aggravations
text:
There's not a lot to this kit, but it did entertain our youngest for most of an evening. It was basically completed within three hours of opening the box. I'm glad I read other reviews first and superglued the frame together. I do see how the frame would have been flimsy without being set together. But she had no problem getting it strung up once it set. We did have a little problem with strings tangling and we had an adult and a teen straightening the strings for an eight year old.

It is a nice kit, and I have to say that this is one of the better displaying kits we have gotten. We had the two dimensional string art kit and it was not nearly as nice to display. All in all a decent set. But might require a little help for younger, less patient crafters.

title: Surprisingly simple and wonderfully creative
text:
Such a simple yet creative little game. It literally takes seconds to explain the game and just a few rounds to master the idea. I love that it opens the mind to creative imagination.

The goal is to look at a simple glyph, then right doen as many unique things it reminds you of. For example, a simple square could be a sandbox, a sandwich or a corral. Each person writes as many of these as they can in a minute then take turns reading their list. If your idea is unique and no one else came up with it, you get a point. If someone else has it, you both cross it out. Ideas are juried by yhe players so you can't just say ridiculous stuff to be unique.

We played a number of rounds and they were boisterous and sometimes heated when people refused to count questionable ideas. But for the most part it was a great, quick game with more than a few laughs.

Only thing I wish was that it came with its own timer. We ended up grabbing one from another game.

title: Huge, Impressive, and apparently a good clone of the Halo Gun
text:
I got this because my kids love Nerf guns and have a smattering of BOOMco guns in their arsenal. What I didn't realize were two things. First this gun is pretty huge and second, that it is a replica of a gun from Halo. They quickly educated me of that latter fact. And apparently it is a pretty good replica and they are pretty excited about that.

The action seems pretty good on the gun, the darts fly true and we do not have a lot of jamming, in fact I don't know if I've ever seen it jam. We do have a general shortage of the BOOMco darts and I do have some issues with them. The biggest is that these really sting compared to the Nerf darts. The BOOMco sticking darts are nice but they only work on their special targets and I would prefer the softer foam darts Nerf uses.

But the big thing about this is that it's huge and impressive, and the kids love it. The pulsing colors in the stored darts is a nice touch. All in all a good toy, although I still prefer Nerf to BOOMco

title: Wonderfully Unique and Creativity Inspiring
text:
What a great creative art toy. You can do literally anything with this and takes your sketches off the paper and into three dimensions. I am amazed at the ways the kids put this into practice, and it kept them engrossed for hours with only a couple squabbles over people hogging this color or that. I'll get more into what we did below. But first, What you get and How this works.

This product is a hardening gel that can be squeezed into shapes using plastic forms. There are several forms that come with the kit, a flat sheet of plastic and a couple rounded forms for creating spherical shapes. The flat clear piece is great for tracing images so even young kids can achieve the shapes they desire. Also, we used it to make other curves to help flesh out animal shapes, but that proved a little more difficult.

Once you have drawn your shapes with one of the gel pens, you can use the UV flashlight to harden the pieces to make them retain the shapes you want. Then you can peel them off the plastic forms or sheet and cement elements together into three dimensional structures. The possibilities are endless and only limited by creativity. Our kids started out by tracing the provided dinosaurs and moved on to tracing other dinos from various books until they had a small forest of dinos and trees.

Warnings and caveats: I'm a little leery of the chemically nature of this toy. There are warnings to avoid skin contact in light. This put me a little on edge and I wanted to supervise our 8 through 14 year olds to make sure it was not getting on skin or other stuff. Also, this does take a bit of artistic ability. It can be as free form as you want it to be, but we did have some frustration when younger kids could not recreate the stuff the older kids were building. But for the most part it was very conducive to creativity.

Also, the end products are a little sticky. So they don't seem like you can play with your creations, but you can make wonderful visual art. We have a nice little dino diorama on our book shelf now and the kids seem pretty proud of it. The inks are also a little messy, so make sure your in a cleanable area.

Personally, I think this is one of the most wonderfully novel and creative ideas I've seen in a while. I will be picking up some for the kids on my Christmas list, and look forward to refilling our supply.

title: Great, fun,  easy to understand game for all age groups
text:
This was a wonderfully cute and unique game. We played it with a diverse age range and everyone loved it. The youngest were super sad when bedtime came and we had to call it a night and the adults were tempted for one more round.

The game play is deceptively very simple. Despite a lot of vigilance it was amazing how people were still able to get winks by us with regularity. The cards and pieces work great and the game flow is easy to follow. Basically it is kind of like go fish except there is incentive for both sides pair up with their random partners. You announce a card you are trying for, then it is your secret partners job to let you know that they have it. If their secret message is not noticed you each get a point when the round ends. If it is intercepted, the interceptor gets both points.

You decide the numbers based on a six by six grid of randomly placed cards. Simply select a card not in your hand and place your marker on it. Then look for your secret partner to ingle that they have the match, while also looking to intercept other sereptitious communication. It's that easy, yet super fun and with parity from eight to eighty. Great game.

title: A Great, Easy, but Engaging Little Game
text:
I love games that can manage parity across many ages. This is a lot like Spot it in that regards, where a 7 year old can compete fairly well with a 47 year old once everyone knows what they are looking for. The reaching for the bell is kinetic enough to engage kids to make them want to be the first to slam the ringer, and the rules are so easy they can immediately be digested. The action is fast and again engaging, and we had a lot of laughs with the came, and surprisingly few injuries and fights.

The game in its simplest form is almost too easy, but it lends itself to more and more levels of complexity. There are three variables, numbers, color (8 or more) and a shape. You can play complex combos like match a shape and a number, or two numbers must add up to ten and there needs to be a match. Instant ring it and visually similar don't ring it cards cause quick victories as well as quick penalties.

This is a perfect game to pull out for some quick games. The container holds all the pieces and makes it wonderfully portable. The parts are decent quality and I expect it to hold up well.

title: Great Details, Not that Great on the Whole
text:
Well, I'm having a hard time fully loving this toy. And frankly it is for the same reasons I am often disappointed with Hot Wheels sets like this. Like most, this is a beautifully sculpted model. I love that it represents the scene of Jakku that appeared in the Star Wars trailer. That is one of the most amazing movie visuals I have ever seen. Also, the included vehicle is amazing, much like every other hot wheels vehicle. In this case, the Falcon looks awesome, has a nice weight to it and exudes quality.

Where this toy fails is where many of these fail. The actual action of the "game" is...well horrendous. In this case, you basically have a button masher where you slam a control stick back and forth which puts the Falcon into a crazed 360 then slams down possibly knocking off an X Wing figure. Now in part, this is decently thought out idea. The X Wings circle slightly faster than the Falcon, so if you maintain low level flight they will bonk you in the rear. And this works well with the 360. If you time your loop correctly, you not only avoid being bonked in the rear, but you can turn the tables and knock the X Wing off it's mount. And there you have it, the entire game in one sentence. I seriously doubt this will have any lasting appeal to anyone. The set illicits some excitement at unboxing and set up, a little more while mastering the concept, but that's about it.

The biggest takeaway from the game is a nice model of the Millenium Falcon.

Pros
+ Great Miniature Millenium Falcon
+ Nice sculpture of the surface of Jakku
+ Nice sound effects

Cons
- The whole thing whips around during and after the loop
- The game is pretty one dimensional
- Probably will not have much longevity of excitement

title: A Ridiculous Toy, but my Kid Loves It.  Plus it's Chewie.
text:
Alright, first let me give the caveat that I think Furbies are the stupidest toy ever. The toy and its price seem ridiculous to me. So why the four stars? My youngest son loves this thing, as ridiculous as it seems. He has had other Furbie Mini's I believe they are called and he has played the app on his iPad and he truly loves them. Again, I'm at a complete loss as I find it kind of annoying.

I do like the Star Wars tie in, although I think that might be a healthy part of its $70 MSRP. But I do like my son and my childhood colliding like this. I also like that they have revamped the application to include a Han Solo character Furby. The app is not much of a game, there is a chance to kind of take care of your Furby...feeding him, bathing him etc. Which is kind of cute but I don't know that it will hold interest for long.

But like I said, my kid truly oves the little guy so it's a great toy.

Pros
+ My kid loves these things
+ Star Wars tie in
+ It was fun to explore the possibilities

Cons
- Annoying
- Expensive
- Kind of ugly

title: Easy to Learn, Fun to Play, Good Age Range
text:
Most of us had never played Fluxx before so this is our only exposure to the game, but the game play is amazingly wild. The changing rules make it possible to have victory snatched from you at the turn of a card, or suddenly find yourself holding the winning hand. I have never played anything like it.

We have played a number of games now and the kids truly love it. I can see how there could be a whole fleet of games created around this concept. For this one, there are some very Batman specific rules that fans of the franchise should like. For example, there is an Archam Asylum rule card that contains the villains in play. There is a rich collection of characters and equipment from the Batman world, which I am not a expert at, but I appreciate how they work the storyline into the game. Much of it must have been specific rules which change the game at least a little from the original game.

The art work is great, the cards and game are easy to read and understand, the quality is nice. All in all this is a really great little game that can be learned and enjoyed in a single hand. And due to the fluctuation in the rules, no game is the same and I have yet to discover a general strategy. You just have to play the cards as they lie.

Great Game

title: It's OK, Unfortunately Our Seems to have Broken and the Action Jams Every Time
text:
We are a nerf gun fighting family, so we were very happy to try out a new nerf gun. Unfortunately, it seems to have broken rather quickly. It is still usable, but there is a little stop pin that pops up into the action lever and stops you from being able to draw the sling shot back. My guess is that there was something that retracted that piece on the draw back, but now we need to push the pin down while drawing back the slingshot so you need two hands and a lot of concentration to get the blaster to fire.

Had that part been working, we are happy with the distance and accuracy of the darts. They are propelled well by the slingshot action and if it was not such a pain to get the device to fire, we would probably like it a lot. However it does not have a high rate of fire, even if it was working and requires a lot of manual loading per shot.

The other feature of this set is the secret message dart which turned out to be a little gimmicky. The dart works on a red dot filter that camoflauges the message. In our case there was a message preprinted on the dart and when you slip the dart into a red transparent tube, the red dots disappear and you get a simple one word message. We imagined the nerf equivalent to carrier pigeons to send messages covertly during battles, instead it is kind of a gimmick.

It will go into the arsenal, but we were not overwhelmed with this device. Especially since ours seems to have broken some how.

Pro
+ Good power for long shots
+ Nice Accuracy
+ Easy assembly

Cons
- Ours kind of broke
- low rate of fire
- Message dart is a low use gimmick

title: Fantastically Engineered, Slightly Simplistic Game
text:
Well right out of the box, I am super impressed with the quality of the pieces. The plastic coins feel a little light, but they are so much better than any other game coins I have seen recently. The characters and cards are thick and substantial, easy to handle and I expect them to stand up to game play very well. The quality is exactly what I expect from Melissa and Doug.

The game itself is very interesting. The way you pass different wave conditions under the boat to give different levels of difficulty is unique, and the boat rides above the waves well, pitching and swaying. The idea is cute and well thought out and well made. My only concern is that the game is a little simplistic, and while it truly held my kids interests while playing it the first time. I don't know that this game will hold long term interest.

My thirteen year old quickly found that you can pretty much guarantee the characters will stay on if you take care and was frustrated that whoever goes first gets a huge advantage in two player games. The game needs more complexity for older kids, but acts as a decent acoordination game for younger kids.

title: A Great, Well-Built Set of Paper Dolls, Packaging is a Plus
text:
The pieces of this set are nicely made and have enough substance to last a while. The biggest surprise is how beloved the purse like, feather topped carrying case was. That unfortunately will not last as it is made of a cheaper plastic. But it has been loved a lot for a general purse while the paper dolls were relegated to a ziplock bag.

So kind of the story of the box the toy came in being more popular, but the actual dress up dolls are very nice. They work very well on our metal wall that we have for magnetic toys and have been used quite a bit. The combination of girl and horse is perfect for prolonged play as well as random daydreams of owning a horse.

Both parents and kids love this one.

title: Great Idea, Mediocre Implementation
text:
Well, this was kind of educational, and it was kind of a frenetic, fun 15 minutes trying to put things back together, but the end comments were "This is ridiculous" and "Well they could have made that better." The ridiculous part was how they made decisions to cut the pieces. They do not follow international borders very faithfully and randomly cut larger countries into random parts. Pieces that include only one country do not resemble the country at all. the eastern united states is a irregular rectangle that appears to miss New England and average out Florida. France is a strange amporphous shape. Canada and Russia are random blotches of non interconnecting shapes.

I like the story that the first puzzle was a US map cut into pieces in a classroom to teach geography. This could have been similar except that the countries are so crudely hacked in shapes. But it does give an idea of location and cultural icons like the great wall of china, russian dolls, local animals are located on the map. I was very impressed that the Great Barrier Reef made the map as an entity. But it could have been so much better in the way it was handled.

As for how it was made, the pieces are small and found to be easy to misplace. The magnetism is weak but sufficient to keep the pieces loosely on the board. The backing is very flexible and all in all it does not seem to be a super well built product.

title: A Decent Craft Book for Tween Girls
text:
