I love giving these type of craft books as gifts, or having them around for visiting girls. When my tween niece visited, this book kept her engaged for a couple of hours. Although there was a bit of a rush to get the necessary markers, pencils and other art supplies that do not come with the book.

I'm a little underwhelmed with the stickers and stencils that came with the book, and the example art in the pages between the blank tshirt templates appear to depart from the supplied materials a lot. And from the templates too, which is probably good as it helps think outside of the box a little.

The paper itself worked well for markers and colored pencils and my niece added a some found items with glue which adhered well. I was very happy how well you could render on the page. All in all a very art book. Not the greatest, but definitely decent.

title: Kids Love it because it's Star Wars, But Oy....
text:
When I first saw these sets going into the stores, I thought, this certainly is not the golden age for Star Wars toys. The sets just don't seem to have the quality that seemed to go into the Star Wars toys in the late 70's and 80's. So I was shocked when my boys showed a ton of interest in the toys. Even the army men type figurines seemed of suspect quality.

The fact that this as a "remote control" vehicle capable of gunning down figures made this very interesting to them. I put remote control in quotes because the controls are limited, basically forward and reverse with a simultaneous twisting. So turning is accomplished by a series of forward and backward thrusts. It is awkward and to me, kind of lame. But boys enjoyed the interactivity. the third control is to pop the front of the star destroyer open to allow the fourth control to eject balls. This has been plenty fun for the boys, but I'm disappointed that you cannot reclose the destroyer (other than manually).

It is good that they took basic army men and found a way to interactively knock them down. But it's just an inelegant solution with a clumsy remote control. It is fine for a kids toy, but definitely less than expertly designed and manufactured.

The pieces are collectible and we are picking up the Endor expansion pack because my youngest loves ewoks. So there is some collectability. I think I'm coming off pretty harsh, bottom line is that the kids have enjoyed playing with this set, I'm just kind of underwhelmed.

Pros
+ The toys are based on Star Wars
+ "Remote Control" aspect brings interest
+ Somewhat Collectible

Cons
- Quality seems like a secondary thought
- Controls are difficult
- Overall, just a little underwhelming

title: A Great Game for All Ages (warning though, it is filled with internet references)
text:
Well first I have to admit, I do not have an internet saavy family. And this game is very much tied into internet memes from "I can haz cheezburgers?" to "Erhmahgerd." Luckily, I have spent a healthy amount of my life researching internet culture, but I ended up having to explain a lot of the cards to my kids.

But the reason I love this game is because of how engaged it kept the kids, and the amount of laughs that it produced. The selfies were ridiculous and caused laughter in itself and the cards played were even better. The game is pretty simple, pick a card from your hand to recreate in a selfie, then others play cards with scenarios that best fit your selfie. There are a lot of "Trying not to poop" type of cards so the humor is a little juvenile but perfect for keeping kids engaged.

Everyone willingly took their turns on the cell phone and everyone seemed to really enjoy the game. Scoring was pretty meaningless which was good. I was thinking that since the person taking the photo got to be the judge of who gets the point for the best caption that there would be hurt feelings and poorly awarded points, but the fun of the selfies and reading the cards trumped any controversy. Actually we ended without caring who scored points.

All in all this is a great ice breaking game.

title: A Great new Schleich figure
text:
This is an impressive dinosaur figure. My son has been a long time Schleich fan, but we have had discussions several times that Papo makes a much better dinosaur than Schleich. Papo's main advantage was that they created articulated, detailed replicas of the dinosaurs of Jurassic Park. Schleich's tended to be static, less detailed and just generally clumsier reproductions. This has drastically changed with this new series of dinosaurs.

The addition of the moveable jaw and finer details has really brought the Schleich dino line up several notches. We still favor the Papos but the details in the facial features on this T Rex are great. The Jaw action is good, but the teeth are a still a little crude in their molding. The body position is gook, coloration is somewhat bold with the tannish scales. But all in all this is a great figure. Definitely a figure deserving of the Schleich tag.

Probably still second best to Papo's two T Rex figures, but heads and shoulders above the older Schleich offerings.

title: Fast-paced, Inane, and Tons of Fun
text:
This is definitely not a cerebral or strategizing game. It is pure reaction, action, and laughter. We played a number of rounds as a way to break the ice between to families of children who had not met yet, and it was perfect. The rules are as simple as you can get, flip a card up, if it matches the color or shape of your mustache, hit it with your suction cupped mustache and claim the card. It you suction cup up one that doesn't match, you pay a two card penalty and he who ends with the most cards wins. Ok there are a couple more rules, but that is the gyst. There are also an all smash card and a none smash cards. But seriously, that is the rules right there.

The mustaches themselves are great. They are a blast in themselves as our kids giggled continually at the look of the mustaches touch to everyone's upper lip. They are made strong with decent suction cups below them. It is fairly easy to strike a card and pull it up with the suction cup. And the cards are well made to take the abuse.

As for game play, the rounds are short and exciting. Some feelings got hurt, but for the most part it was an uproarious game which put smiles on everyone's face. Scoring is easy...just count up the cards you won. Personally, I don't think this will be a classic game, but it willl be pulled out in our house many times.

title: A very decent beginner RC plane, with some small cons
text:
I have a thirteen year old with fairly serious interest in RC planes. We have got him several entry level planes and he is growing as a RC pilot. It has been great to watch him gain confidence and competence flying. I was very happy to get this RC flyer as another vehicle for him to cut his teeth on and it really seems to be doing exactly what I was hoping it would - hone his feel for flying.

I would compare this vehicle to the rather simple (and rather cheap) air hogs RC toys. They do fly and use a remote but they are more a general toy than a serious hobbyist plane. However, I was pretty happy with the flight and controls of this plane. in many ways it is even a simpler starter plane than the Hobby Zone Champ (which is an amazing entry level RC Plane.)

For the Fire Shot, everything is controlled by the twin motors. Lift is generated by the entire body, and ascent and descent are controlled by throttle, rising when you add power, descending when you throttle back. Side to side is controlled by the power given to the left or right props. This does make flight dependant on two good engines. There is a trim setting to finely balance the engines for straight flight.

The materials are ok and it is a shapely, elegant flying wing. The body is a compressed styrofoam that is lightweight while still rugged enough to survive a few encounters with the ground. The styrofoam does show abraisions and wrinkles from impact, but held it's shape enough to keep it airworthy. I think it will last a while. The engines were good and with very minor trim adjustments, it flew true. Spare propellers are provided which is nice. The remote is OK but not the greatest quality.

Flight was faster than my son was used to and needed faster reaction times. It seems to have a bit of a learning crew, and it did stall fairly easily when pushed too hard into ascent, but flight was very stable. The 50 minute charge time was a little long for an eight minute flight. Especially without the option to swap out batteries. We have a couple of planes so at least we could switch out to other, charged airplanes and rotate the charges. Otherwise charging and syncing were without problems.

Pros
+ Simple Controls
+ Decent Materials
+ Rigid foam
+ Decent intro to RC planes
+ Sleek Design

Cons
- Single enbedded battery, can not be hot swapped
- 50 minute charge time for 5-10 minute flight
- Materials show aesthetic effects of ground strikes

Summary: All in all, it was nice different feeling plane that added interest to the flight trip we took it on. We did not try out the amphibious qualities but hope to soon. There is no price at this time, but if it is in the ballpark of the Air Hogs ($50-$80, I feel this is a better value and probably a better handling vehicle. I don't know that I would pick it over something like the Hobby Zone RT Champ at $89.

title: A surprisingly good quality game.
text:
I was actually pretty surprised how well this game was designed and manufactured. The game itself is extremely easy. In three sentences, you have one dice that you can use to move or gather money. The winner is decided on who gets the most coins. So the trade off is to gather coin, or run from the ever advancing shark.

So the game is easy, but the real wow factor for the kids playing this game is the gameboard itself. You run down a gang plank, running from shark fin that breaks through the decking and tripping spring loaded shark heads that bursts through the dock plankings. The player pieces are four uniquely molded plastic pirates with lots of character. All in all, the "game board" itself is enough to engage children. We played with a wide age range from 8 to 46 and it was fun for all, although one teen found that he could hold the dice to allow the shark to knock out the slower pieces. But with a good crowd, the shark keeps the players moving to save their own skins if nothing else.

We were happily surprised with the quality and fun gameplay of this game. It is a younger game for sure, probably 6-9 would be a good range, but it was fun for all. I'm not sure how long it will be played, but has held the attention of groups of kids many times.

Pros
+ Super Easy Rules
+ Super Easy Set up
+ Very well designed, and manufactured, game board
+ Great, Molded Pirate Player Pieces
+ Loads of Fun

Cons
- The system can be gamed by someone purposely holding the dice.

title: Shock and Awe Followed by Less Enthusiasm
text:
Out of the box this toy really impresses. The idea of taking your pet dog for a walk, and interactively playing with it made it an instant hit. We spent time play with it, getting it to walk forward which was great for the 10 feet to the wall. We played with the interactive voice commands which were great. We downloaded the app and played with connecting to the little guy and played the rather simplistic games, and all was great.

At least it was great until we got to the end of new tricks. The excitement waned when we got to the end of the tricks and the second time through was less exciting. Sadly with most electronic stuffed animals, what you end up with is an uncuddly shelf piece. This one does have some advancements over other walking animals, like the remote control leash. However it would have been exponentially better if you could control the walking left and right. then you could really take it for a walk around the house and obstacles. As it is, to get maximum fun you put it on the longest straight away you can find and gently follow it. Otherwise it is a little tippy and can fall over.

The App has a lot of potential. Right now it is slick and professional with lots of transitional animation and nice clean graphics. Aesthetically it's beautiful. And the interaction brings a lot to the dog. One of the greatest things about Apps in general is that they can continue to be expanded and with a decent game platform, it can keep kids engaged with the FurReal Friends for a long time. Right now there is a point system where you can unlock items. This kind of game play really does have the potential of giving this toy legs. Right now the games we can play are pretty simplistic, but the simulated pet care is intriguing, and my kids really liked that part.

All in all we are very happy with the toy, but the excitement really dropped off after an initial burst of excitement.

title: A Nice Firetruck Set, Great Lights and Siren, but not quite up to our Playmobil Expectations
text:
bin of We are a huge Playmobil family and picked up every pirate and sailing ship that came out. We have marveled over every detail in every set we've gotten and have an ever growing bin of Playmobil. So my boys are connoisseurs who can give an instant critique.

They did like the details like the hose and equipment. They enjoyed the basics of the truck, but within a few minutes came "This truck seems kind of cheap." And I have to admit that it doesn't seem quite up to the quality we have come to expect. The details are there, but the feel is not quite what I would have expected. The moving parts, ladder and wheels etcetera seem less rugged. To get the driver in and out of the cab, you must pop off the roof which is held on by plastic tabs that I fear might be too brittle to last. But saying that, this is a decent toy and I'm sure will get played with.

And actually the one thing that really seems "cheaper" than I am used to with Playmobil is the use of stickers. Playmobil has always had details like cast plastic grills and graphic elements are factory painted on. On this vehicle, the details are printed on stickers and applied. Our Playmobil stuff is often taken into the bathtub. This is impossible for this truck since the stickers will quickly dissolve in water and look awful.

The lights and siren are a nice touch. They bring additional realism and the siren was surprisingly mellow. We've had our share of toys that have been banned on road trips or had to be put into time out, but this one is reasonably quiet for play in the next room.

Pros
+ It's Playmobil
+ Lights are nice
+ Siren is not loud
+ Interactive play
+ Multi-Cultural

Cons
- Not quite up to Playmobil's usual quality
- Questionable tabs on the cab's roof
- Stickers - easily the single biggest reason why this seems "cheap" from Playmobil

title: Decent Gun System with a Couple of Nice Points, but not quite Nerf
text:
As a caveat, we are a Nerf gun family. We have spent a lot of time in the basement setting up forts, donning safety glasses, and trying to nail each other with darts. So we were a little skeptical about a "copycat" gun system just as we are of Lego rip offs. But this gun had a few happy surprises, like the way the darts stick to the special target and the incredible range we were getting on the darts.

Quality - the plastic seems a little more brittle than Nerf guns, and in general, I don't feel that they are quite up to the same level of quality. However, they have stood up to a lot of firing by the boys and are still going. And the darts are rigid and seem to be holding up to the abuse better than the foam Nerf darts do.

Aim - These have fairly decent aiming and you can consistently hit the target if not the bullseye. During battles they are fairly deadly, especially since the dates have a little more zing.

Fun factor - It's up there with Nerf. We don't include them in our battles because they have a little more zing than we want. They are good for target practice although since the darts only stick to the magic targets, you are limited with what you can aim at to get a satisfying hit. The fact that this set comes with two guns is pretty key to fun. Shields are a little gimmicky, but the boys love to pop them open and closed.

Value - They are in line with the Nerf guns. We have an arsenal of Nerf and many refills of Nerf darts so we will probably not expand into the Boomco system. Also, the refills of darts are fairly expensive, but if they end up like Nerf, you should be able to shop clearances and sales to refill.

Summary - They are not bad guns, they just aren't Nerf. The boys have enjoyed playing with these, but I think that barring an amazing design on something from Boomco, we will stick with Nerf.

title: A Nice Set, Wish it had a little more flexibility
text:
I got this train set to use in the children's waiting room in our pro-bono counseling center and I couldn't be happier with the reaction. Kids play with it constantly while waiting up to 90 minutes for their parents and they rarely tire of it. I'm impressed with who engaged the kids get.

However, I've always had a huge tub of Brio and Thomas tracks at home and I see a few disadvantages of this set. The worst thing is that you pretty much only have one workable configuration. So unless you have other sets, it does not lend itself to creative track designs. Because of the uniqueness of these pieces, I think it would be hard to incorporate it into other designs unless you have a lot of them. Also, the tracks don't seem to be as interlocking as the wooden tracks and have a slightly cheap plastic feel in comparison, and the train does occasionally jump track. However, I don't want to rip this set because it truly has been a delight to see how much the kids love to play with the set.

title: Awesome, with a touch of Frustration
text:
This idea is absolutely amazing. My kids were in awe of it as we opened the box and set up the track. The first times around the track there were some issues with figuring out the controls but all in all it was an amazing experience. The cars eerily control themselves around the huge 4 foot by 8 foot track. The were mesmerized while controlling the cars in and out of lanes. They really do work like slot cars, but with a wide open track.

However, after racing for a little while, my kids started getting frustrated that the cars would occasionally go into a spin and shoot off the track or end up heading the wrong direction, which they would quickly notice and reverse, but it was frustrating when your car would spin and start going the wrong way. Often you would see a car fly off the track and be told to return the car to the track. It happens enough to be intrusive to the game.

The battling aspect of the game is great. The cars do seem to have a sense of aim when firing. But we did run into a little trouble. My older son ended up playing with his car for an hour, building up points and adding upgrades to his car. Now his car is heads and shoulders above my youngest's and there is frustration for my youngest since they are no longer competing on par.

We are still in awe of the technology and we still enjoy playing with it, but it is a little short of perfect.

title: Very High Quality Construction and Design
text:
My son was a big fan of Snap Circuits and these seem to take it a whole other step beyond that. The design with the snapping magnets is great. The circuits pop together far easier than the snap circuits do. And the individual elements, although small, are well crafted.

The instructions are easy to follow and educational. I learned as much if not more than my son by reading through them. And I love that the company has an ongoing design contest.

If I had any criticisms, they would be price and size of the pieces and collection. $200 is very steep for 18 elements, and the elements are somewhat small and I could imagine easy to misplace. Like I said, the design is great, but probably not enough to be $200.

Pros
+ Well constructed
+ Insanely easy to connect up circuits
+ Full of Creative Potential
+Expandable

Cons
- Expensive
- Small parts

title: Cheaply Made, Questionable Game Play, Big Disappointment
text:
Pretty quickly into construction I realized that this was going to be kind of a let down. The pieces snapped together fairly well but the materials and design is pretty flimsy. I gained a little hope once we had it all together and tried to launch our first flying ninja turtle. And that's when any remaining hope faded...

The point of the game is to either knock out all of the villains before they capture the pieces they need to win. However, with one single turtle 3/4ths of all the villains fell off. We read through the instructions as we tried to work out the rules, but 20 minutes later is descended into straight target practice and ended 15 minutes later and we haven't opened the game since.

Wish I could be more constructive, but both my boys panned this game outright, and I have to agree.

title: Fun Series, but this One is more of a Refill than a Stand Alone Set.
text:
We got the Crayola Create 2 Destroy Castles and my sons loved it. They really enjoyed playing with the set despite the issues with trying to get the clay back out of the mold and I was ok with the mild mess. However this set seemed more like a refill rather than a stand alone play set. Perhaps that is the best way to look at this. My boys were delighted to get more clay, but it was added to the castles rather than played with on their own.

My boys did have interest in the Dino Destruction sets when they saw them, but this dinosaur has a rather underwhelming tail flicking action that didn't live up to their hopes of a TRex or catapulting Ankylosaur. If you are looking for a self contained afternoon of fun, get one of the full sets and if you are looking to augment that set, get this one.

Otherwise, my boys have had fun with these sets, just wanted to give heads up that with just one dino and less clay and molds, this doesn't have the interactive fun the full sets have.

title: This Absolutely lives up to the Premier Designation
text:
I can't tell you how taken my six year old was with this set. He carried it with him for days and days with obvious pride. It encouraged him to keep drawing for weeks, which is fantastic. I like that the case is durable and can easily be refilled with new crayons and markers as they are used up.

Kids love these kind of organized art kits and it takes nothing to get my son away from electronic media to artistic medias with this set. If you have any budding artists in definitely considered this kit. If there is anything I could say that might be to the negative, it would be that the included pad of paper is small and could easily have been left out to make room for more crayons or markers.

Pros
+ Sturdy Carrying Case
+ Great Selection of markers,pencils and crayons
+ Kids love the briefcase.
+ Case makes it easy to keep the markers organized and clean

Cons
- The pad of paper is small

title: An Interesting Blend of Toy and Technology
text:
I'm impressed with the way the designers blended LCD screen, motors and sound in this toy. Coming from and age of pull strings and wind up toys, I'm amazed at how much can go into a reasonably priced toy. And it is very functional as a toy. Both the helicopter and dinosaur forms lend themselves to creative play (albeit of a inherently violent nature.) And the sounds and customizeable screen add a huge additional element.

I so have to say with the age 3 and up should also come a rough limit of 8 and under. My tween was only engaged long enough to run through the sounds and screens and one time through the transformation and came up with, "It's OK." But my 7 year old has played with it quite a bit.

All in all a decent toy.

title: A Engaging Activity and Ongoing Fun
text:
This kit was a huge hit with my 7 and 12 year olds. I was happy to see them walk through the instructions on their own and create one after another. In fact the only reason they stopped is because they wanted to save some of the fun for another day. They loved the chance to name and create their own colors.

I loved the satisfying click the markers give when pressed together and more than any other kit I can think of, you get a usable product in the end. Everything stores in the marker maker itself and it closes up into a compact package that stores well. The kit comes with two marker packs that kids can label and name so they can keep their creations separate.

The only bad things I can think about the kit is that the labels for the markers don't stick particularly well so we had to wrap packing tape around them and the bottom section needs a little wiggling to get the tabs to hold well. But all in all, This is a fantastic kit.

Pros
+ Engaging
+ Well constructed
+ Allows creativity in making markers and unlimited creativity using the markers
+Packs into a nice little package

Cons
- Label Stickers don't Stick Well
- Potential of stains
- Only makes primary colors, no black, grays or browns.

All in all, we absolutely love this kit. We will definitely be looking for refills.

title: Short and Intense Firepower...Till the clip empties
text:
My kids have had an absolute blast with this nerf firearm. I am amazed at the speed that it empties an 18 dart clip with startling accuracy. I am also impressed at the decent but manageable sting that the darts give you when your tween son unloads on you.

The construction seems very solid. It is amazing that it has sensors that will not allow firing when the chamber is open or the clip is missing. There are lock release buttons on everything from stock extension to a safety for firing (well maybe more just a button to engage the fly wheel more than a safety.) Also there are rails for accessories and clip loops for attaching a carrying strap. Perhaps the most superfluous feature is the fold down sight. I have never seen my boys aim. It seems to favor firing from the hip.

Pros
+ Absolute blast to fire
+ Satisfying click when slamming the clip home
+ Impressive accuracy
+ Well Constructed

Cons
- It does Jam, especially when trying to use the clips from other guns in the series.
- Bullets seem to burrow to freedom after shooting them, or turn invisible because they just disappear.
- Needs 4 C batteries
- Having just one causes sibling bickering

I do find it funny that they rate this for educational purposes. But I guess it is a great introduction into our gun culture. The false sense of strength and self confidence it provides is very self evident as you fire down on someone with only a pump action nerf gun, or better yet, an unarmed victim. We have lost a lot of darts in a short time, but that's what supplemental dart packs are for.

I feel like I'm putting in too many cons, because In the words of my boys, "This thing is awesome." I wish they had these when I was their age. Either that or I wish the office had a more lax view on noon-time Nerf battles.

title: Not quite the Farkle I remembered
text:
So I played Farkle a long time ago, and my family in another state has begun playing Farkle pretty regularly on family game nights. So I was excited to get Farkle Frenzy. But I have to admit we played the first four games with different rules each time as we figured them out (not sure that I have it completely correct now.) It is definitely not a true form of Farkle, but like I said, it's been a long time, but the scoring definitely is different. Not that that is completely bad. I just can't shake the feeling that I'm getting something wrong.

But as improvement to the game, the shared dice is great, the kids love to depress the bubble and can't wait for their turn to push it. The game board pyramid is also a nice addition in giving them somewhere to place the dice, but the score is difficult and beyond my 6 year old. But we had fun playing it in general and we are looking forward to taking it to Grandma's house where they fully understand Farkle.

Pros
+ Pushing the bubble on the shared dice was a big hit
+ Fast moving game
+ Captured the attention of the boys even if they didn't necessarily understand the scoring.

Cons
- A little confusing on the scoring

Summary
All in all a fun game, even if we are putting a bit of a spin on the game. The 3D game board adds to the interest of young kids and Farkle is a very playable and enjoyable game.

title: Great to Decorate and Substantial Enough to Hold Up
text:
This craft kit was put to the ultimate test - an 8 year old girl. The decoration captivated her for hours and kept her out of the hair of her brother and friends who were having a sleep over. Which is easier said than done. I liked all the decoration options to personalize the drawers and it took a couple of hours to complete the whole project.

The second thing that I am very happy to see is that it is still considered something of a keepsake a month later. It does not seem to be a disposable craft project. Although it is made of cardboard, I can see it being kept around and treasured for some time.

The one problem I have is the price. I got a free one to review, and it is nice but the current $32 list price seems a little steep for a cardboard craft kit. But I would have felt satisfied it it were under $20.

title: Track leaves a little to be desired, but a fun and entertaining race set
text:
This set got very high marks right out of the box (actually it got high marks even in the box.) The kids loved the set and played with it for hours after the opened it and they have returned to them several times in the next week. It was a real winner in the make the kids happy. I am very happy to see how much the kids have enjoyed the set. However, I have a few issues with the track and performance where I could see some improvement.

Quality.

The cars themselves seem pretty solid. We have wound the ratchets up well over a hundred times a piece and the car's performance seems unchanged, which was a concern. The cars also seem to be pretty rugged as they have hit a number of obstacles with no apparent harm.

Where the quality is a little lacking is in the track. The track is made out of a thin stiff plastic that seems like it might now hold up well. I noticed that other reviewers mention the risk of injuries or cuts which is interesting because that is exactly what I thought of when I was setting up the track, but I have checked all the edges and our set does not seem to have any real risk of cuts. The track is usable, and the stacking design is nice and organized, but the materials are a little on the cheap side for the raceway itself. Checkered flag function is nice although one of or flags is slow to rise.

I think it was pretty telling when my oldest boy said, "Lets get more of the cars, we don't need a track really, but I would like the other cars." He even said that the cars were well made.

Playability.

The one thing the cars lack is a little torque. The are slow to get up to speed but once they get up to speed they race pretty well. However, in the second or two that they are getting up to speed, they are prone to getting stuck, especially when one of the wheels contacts the side of the track or the other car. The causes a lot of false starts when a car's wheel rubs on the track wall and the car never gets going.

Also, the obstacles seem a little bothersome. Mostly they cause the cars to lodge together or jump track. Which does add some variation, but at times a little frustration.

The Ratchet action is great. Our five year old quickly learned to ratchet the cars up and could play completely independently. He quickly mastered lining the car halves up and stopping when the ratchet clicks. It is quick to prime the cars with potential energy and the single button control could hardly be simpler except that there are two states, one that allows ratcheting and one that doesn't. Not a big thing but sometimes you forget to hit the button before winding the car back up.

All in all I am very, very happy with this set. It has captured my boys interested and allowed them (5 and 10) to play together at something. Sometimes this age difference makes that a challenge.

title: The book won't win a Newberry, but the pillow pet has won my child's heart
text:
I don't completely understand the attraction for my son, but the pillow pet has a much stronger place in his heart than any other stuffed animal. We have had a series of them which have been drug everywhere. I was really excited when I saw there were book combos. Any chance to make my kids readers is a good thing. The book itself is fine. It does have a substantial amount of words and takes a while to get through which is nice. It makes a very bedtime story, although it is not Ernest Hemingway or Emily Bronte. The illustrations are decent although the characters are very noticeably pillow pets, with probably makes my little one connect to the book better, but the animals look a little strange and boxy.

I highly recommend this set to anyone with kids in the two and a half to five year old range. At least in our experience, kids bond to them quickly and the pillow pets end up being kind of stuffed security blankets that make going to bed a little easier - unless of course you leave them at Grandmas.

title: Great Wow Factor for my 10-year-old, mechanically challenging
text:
This toy gave my 10 year old an incredible holy cow moment when we opened the package from Amazon. He then proceeded to spend time over three days mastering the transformations from Semi to Optimus Prime.

I defer to his rating of four stars. He really likes it but noted that the transformation is kind of hard and at one point the arm popped off while torquing it to stow the arm. This is not a easy transformation, it is kind of like refolding a map, it takes a little thinking and the pieces don't seem to go back quite where they were. However, the overall design is an impressive feat of engineering.

My son was very impressed that he mastered this toy despite being listed 3 out of 3 for difficulty. It takes 22 steps to transform the semi to optimus, 20 steps to turn the trailer into body armor, and additional 9 steps just to get the action figure into the body armor. the instructions are a double sided poster with scores of steps.

He demoed the toy for an hour and was very excited, but when he found that it was $70 or so he was shocked. We talked about it for a while and he decided that dollar for dollar it was probably better off with a good lego set. Since the demo it has sat pretty much unused. He still likes it, but it does not get the day to day use of many of his other toys.

So all in all, it is pricey, well designed but somewhat difficult to transform. I see it more as a fan boy collectible than a day to day toy. Impressive, but not overly engaging.

title: Makes my daughter cry
text:
This is a horrible toy. My two year old daughter got it as a birthday gift from her godfather, who bought it because of the fantastic reviews. It arrived broken -- one of the paw pad sensors doesn't work unless you squeeze it just right, with two fingers. In the past Fisher Price has given me fantastic service, so I'm sure they'll take care of that problem when I get around to calling.

The really terrible thing about this puppy is that when you hit a sensor, the toy stops whatever it was doing and starts a new thing. The sensors are super sensitive, and will go off if you just brush up against the toy. My daughter wants to hear the songs all the way through, and sing along, but of course she wants to be able to hold or touch the puppy at the same time. So the song stops, then it takes like five tries to cycle around to the song she wants, then she hugs the puppy and the song stops again. After about ten minutes of this she was in tears. I've never see my little girl so distraught -- she's not a kid who gets discouraged or cries much, but she just collapsed into my arms in tears of frustration. I felt awful for her.

Other things I don't like about it:
1. The "this little piggy" chant is turned into "this little puppy," so now my daughter has started saying that, and I prefer the classic rhyme.
2. There's a whole part that says "blue ear," "yellow foot," "green hand," when you hit those body parts. But because it cuts off when you hit the sensors, it can sound like "blue -- foot," when the foot is actually yellow. My daughter repeated "blue foot," and I had to correct her.
3. It says "I love you". I generally don't like inanimate objects saying they love my child.

If Fisher Price just made the slight change of having this puppy complete what he's doing before starting the next activity, we'd probably love it!

title: The Oregon Trail Handheld Game by Uncle Milton
text: I completely missed out on this elementary and middle school game, I was born to early. The Oregon Trail is a series of educational computer games. The first game was originally developed by Don Rawitsch, Bill Heinemann, and Paul Dillenberger in 1971 and produced by the Minnesota Educational Computing Consortium (MECC) in 1974. The original game was designed to teach school children about the realities of 19th-century pioneer life on the Oregon Trail. The player assumes the role of a wagon leader guiding a party of settlers from Independence, Missouri, to Oregon's Willamette Valley via a covered wagon in 1848.  I am loving this toy for 3 reasons, first it's a toy, second I love history and most important I too traveled West from the Eastern US and live on the Oregon Coast just west of the Willamette Valley. I love the retro graphics!! I think this would be an ideal gift for anyone who was in elementary or middle school from 1978 to 1998. The only thing I would improve is make the screen twice as large.

title: Watch the perfect video (on the left side of this page) to show you how it works
text:
We got it, and he played with it all night. It's a little hard to set up. I kept thinking there is no way this is actually going to work. It took a few tries to make it run correctly but when we did, it's very cool! He's played with nothing else for the last two days. The 6 year old first grader and his buddies were a bit frustrated at mastering the technique to get the cars through the loop without falling. Then we watched the video and all systems were good. Playing as teams added playing time. They even had 'fun' putting the setup together (including stickers - woot!). Track isn't very substantial. I wonder why it only comes with one "rip-car" race car?

My advice would be to buy 3 more cars with the set or invite the tiny tots to bring their own rip-car (if they have them).

title: College dorm room fun
text:
My college freshman and his dorm room buddies have had plenty of fun using this and their erasable white board, proving that no matter how many years separate your young ones from childhood they will always be kids at heart. It was a perfect ice breaker when making new friends thrown together and looking for something to do. The soon to be out of their teens got a lot of laughs at the added element of the timer.

Mattel needs to get a focus group together to come up with simpler things to draw - they need to adhere to the KISS advisory - maybe even have a few versions: kids, teens, adults and classic for the 55+ set. I advised my boy to have some fun writing over the cards with things more appropriate for their age group.

title: As Mary Poppins would have said "Practically Perfect in Every Way"
text:
5 year old Jedi knight loved it
30 year old Disney nut loved it
40 year old married to Disney nut loved it too
50 year old who had the game thought the whole thing was priceless

Multiple choice questions (200 Cards with 1000 Questions) comparing Disney characters and theme parks, etc. Each question card has 4 Disney characters/things pictured on the front, with questions on the back. I really loved it that the cards were so large.

Even better it can played as teams (Number of Players/Teams: 2 to 6). There are also 'guess-my-answer' questions where you try to guess what another player's answer would be to a question, like "who would you want to go on an adventure with?" from a selection of 4 characters on the face of the card.

Cranking it up a notch the players use wager coins (kind of like the Final Jeopardy question on the TV show Jeopardy) where the more confident you are in the answer the higher you would wager.

FYI it comes with a free APP that has trivia you can play alone or with friends.

** Update 8/31/2014 - Still tons of fun after playing it almost every day since we got it (it helps that it is still summer vacation - lol).

Once we got him going on the software he was all set to use it on his own - We got this 5 weeks ago so we are still exploring. The 6 year old thinks the gadgets are fun. You down load the app to your touch and once it down loads you are ready to play with the neat things in the box.

You bring an image up on your touch. You then use the app and the pen to cut out or crop pieces of an image or draw on the image. Create morphing effects, like stretching & melting with the morphing tool. Design backgrounds to paste your picture on or you can paste the image on a background from the app. Use the stamp for general silliness. Then keep it all in a provided storage pouch.

text: Really fun little toy. Grandson loves pushing this around

title: Mediocre but fun
text: A little flimsy, but grandson likes it

title: Great puzzle
text: Granddaughter age 4 put this together pretty quickly. Fun and pretty.

title: Fun gift!
text: Grandson loves this. Only wish it was a little bigger.

title: Larger than expected...great buy!
text: Absolutely adorable and loved by our granddaughter. Folkmanis is the best in puppets.

title: Smaller than expected
text: Hopefully these are pretty. Still waiting for my grandson to break them.

title: Allright
text: Just o.k. Grandson loves Minecraft - so this works!

title: Fun Fun Fun!
text: Perfect for any little kid to play in.  My 2 year old grandaughter loves this!

title: Awesome purchase
text: Grandaughter loved her own sleeping bag!

title: Realistic puppet - great size!
text: This coyote is fantastic.  I got this for a Birthday gift for my grandaughter along with finger puppets (mouse) (rabbit) (turtle).  As well as a book about a Coyote.  Figured that while reading the book to my grandaughter we could act out the story with the puppets!  Folkmanis puppets are the best!

title: Adoreable!
text: Folkmanis puppets are simply the best.  If you like puppets these are the ones you want!  This bobcat is so cute.

title: Adorable Plush
text:
I got this cute little plush dog for my wife to brighten up her day and it did a good job at that. This is an adorable little plush and it's as cute as can be, though it's very small (will fit in a coat pocket) and there are minor issues with the quality.

I got the 5" Yorkie and it's definitely a very small plush that easily fits in my hand. It looks a lot like a puppy at first glance and it is hard not to find it absolutely cute as can be. The fur is exceptionally soft, too.

I did notice that the quality control is slightly lacking with this one. The stitching is a little obvious in a spot or two and looks like it was not sewn as carefully as it should have been. The fur is attached well but it's not thick and you can see the underlying fabric with little effort.

This is a cute little plush that will delight most people. It's adorable, small and very soft. Keep an eye on the fit and finish, though.

title: Better Quality than Expected
text:
I am a fidgety person and I look for gizmos that allow me to fidget without driving everyone around me crazy. I selected this spinner toy with low expectations, and I was quite pleasantly surprised by it - it is of higher quality than I expected and it works very well.

This is a mostly plastic spinner at its heart, and I assumed it would be a poor spinner. I was wrong. In spite of being fairly lightweight and having more plastic than metal, it apparently has good bearings in it because it spins very smoothly and quietly with little resistance. When spun fast enough it has a nice gyro effect that you can feel when you balance it right.

It does more than spin. It has clicky buttons, small thumb wheels that click, and small rotors on the edges that can be turned manually.

Although it is lightweight and mostly plastic, I am very pleased with this fidget toy. It works well and is sufficiently interesting to keep me focused.

title: Higher Quality than Expected
text:
Chess has been my favorite board game for many, many years and I have a modest collection of chess sets. I do keep my eyes open for nice sets that are suitable for playing and travel. I selected this one because of the size - a little bigger than a typical travel set - and so far I have been very pleased with it.

Most travel sets I have seen and used have been small and of lower quality. There's nothing wrong with that, as you would not want to take an expensive set on the road unless traveling for the purpose of playing chess. This is a larger set, measuring 15"x15", which is suitable for play in most situations. It is not a tournament-sized set by any means, though.

I was mildly surprised by the fit and finish of this set. I say mildly because this is a more expensive set than many other travel sets, so I was expecting this to be a step up from typical travel sets though I wasn't expecting this much of a step up... The pieces are well made without rough spots or cuts and they're finished nicely so they're smooth. The board is also well-made and has a very smooth surface so that pieces can be slid without difficulty instead of having to pick them up and set them down again.

Also included is a set of checkers so that either game can be played on the board.

This is a better travel set than most, and it is larger than most I have seen too. It is well made and priced reasonably with the quality.

title: Very Fun for Small Groups
text:
My family and I like to have game nights, and I am always looking for good games that will keep us busy for a while or will make us laugh. I selected this one with those thoughts in mind. It has proven to be a good game that we all like. It bears some similarities to Apples to Apples, another game we like but usually play with larger groups.

The object of the game is simple: using the cards available to you, select the one that most closely matches the two subject cards in some way – or at least is most likely to be selected by the judge. If you are familiar with Apples to Apples this game is very similar in concept except that you're matching against two cards instead of one.

Game play is as fast or as slow as you want it to be. And, depending on how you play, this can generate a lot of laughter and/or a lot of competition.

The only reservation I have with this game is that there are limited numbers of cards, both subject and matching. I am hopeful that expansion packs will be available eventually.

This is a fun family game that has a ring of familiarity to it. It's great for small groups and for us it gets us laughing. The rules are easy to understand and game play can be fast or slow. Based on our experience with it, this one's easy to recommend.

title: Lots of Parts
text:
As I kid I always liked models. I also liked erector sets. Those two things consumed a good chunk of my childhood free-time. This model is a bit of a hybrid between the two and is a lot of fun. That said, it might not be quite age appropriate for the lower end of the recommended age range.

This is a nice assbly-required tractor kit, made of plastic but with lots of moving parts. It takes some time to assemble but the end product is a workable toy that is well made and fun to play with. It has elements of an erector set - tools for assembly and plenty of nuts and bolts to fasten things together.

It is the sheer number of parts that give me pause when I see that this is recommended for children starting at age 5. Children that young are arguably going to struggle with not losing some of the fasteners, and there is the potential for limited patience. For children that are at the younger end of the range, it is probably best to work with them and make this a parent-child project. I suppose that's the point, though many children enjoy working independently and figuring things out on their own.

This is a nice assembly-required toy and it will definitely consume some time, both during assembly and after. I like the design and I like the way it comes together. I do question the age range, and that may be me being overly cautious.

title: Small Travel Chess Set
text:
I have loved chess for many years and I look for chess-related things that will work well for my family and me. A travel set is one of those things. I selected this set with the thought of it working well in the car. It's a decent little set and I like it but there is some room for improvement, especially when considering the price.

This is a fairly straightforward set - wooden peg pieces that attach to the peg board and hold well enough to survive some jostling while traveling. It's easy enough to see and it is large enough that the pieces can be moved without too much trouble. So far, so good.

The board itself is a cheap, heavy card stock insert that is attached to the inside of the lid. This is all right and is an efficient way to use the space. However, for the cost of this set ($25 as I write this) I would have preferred to see a removable plastic or particle board of some kind rather than a paper-based board.

The set comes with a simple rulebook to get a beginner started. It's a nice addition and is better than the basic instructions often printed on a single sheet of paper or the lid of a box. There's a fair amount of humor in the writing which makes it a more interesting read.

This is not as bad set at all and it will be fun when traveling. I think there should be a more substantial board in the box, though, considering the price of the overall set.

title: Fun in the Office
text:
I work in an office where there's a lot silliness and mild horseplay going on - nothing serious, but just enough happening to keep everyone wary and to keep morale up a little. I selected this little throw toy for this environment. So far, it has been well received and has become part of the mix. It's not perfect, and it probably missed the target audience a little, but for office props it works for me.

This is a very small finned football, about the size of a grapefruit though not round. It is soft and easy to grip but it is not as soft as a Nerf ball or a foam rubber ball with no fins. That's all right for us, but it's something to keep in mind. It is weighted so that over distance the head should drop and the fins point up towards the end of the flight time.

Because it is soft and pliable it is well suited for smaller kids, though larger children probably will find this to be too small. Indoors, though, it has enough weight to do damage if it hits something fragile like a vase or flower pot, so some caution should be used indoors.

Over farther distances, it doesn't fly quite as straight as I'd expect. I think the size and weight might be a little off?

This is a fun finned football toy and I like it as do my office mates. It's fun to toss around (carefully in the office) and it has a nice feel to it. I question, though, if it should have been bigger or if there is a problem with the balance that could be improved.

title: Satisfying and Inexpensive
text:
I am a terrible fidgeter and I am always looking for things to keep my hands busy so the rest of me will sit still, particularly in meetings. I selected this fidget spinner ring with that thought in mind. While it is not perfect, it is a good product at a very good price point.

I'll start by saying that the sizing is right. The ring I received fits properly. There's really little more to add on that.

This is a nice-looking ring and it matches the description picture exactly. I went with the black groove style and it is a very conservative, unassuming ring that does not draw attention to itself which is what I wanted.

The spinning portion did not spin smoothly on mine when I first received it, feeling like there was a rough spot on one or both of the parts. As I have messed with it, it has gotten better and now it feels smooth. It is possible that there was a small piece of debris caught in between the parts; I will keep messing with it.

It is surprisingly satisfying to mess with this ring, too. I have other fidget toys that do more and are more expensive, but this ring is just as satisfying and it costs a lot less.

For the price this is a very good spinner ring. The ring does spin as expected and it is satisfying to mess with it. It doesn't draw a lot of attention to itself and it is easy to play with it without being distracting. My particular ring caught slightly in the beginning, and I suspect it was manufacturing debris. Regardless, it's hard to argue with the price.

title: Flawed and Overpriced
text:
Being a terrible fidget, I selected this toy as something to keep me still while in meetings and to occupy a few spare cycles while at my desk. It's fun to play with but it is not made particularly well.

This is a gyroscope-type of toy that is meant to be spun. The concept is clear and it does work - briefly. The unit I received has some play in the first (largest) ring and it wobbles enough to slow down the spinning. The inner loop clicks as it spins, much like it is catching on something, and though it does not seem to have a drastic impact on the spinning action it is audibly clear that there is some imperfection in the joint.

I suspect part of the problem is that the whole thing is made of soft-ish plastic with visible seams.

As I write this, this unit sells for $14. That's higher than I believe is reasonable for this, without making improvements.

This isn't a bad toy, but it definitely is imperfect and could use some work to improve it, especially at the asking price.

title: Satisfying Fidget Toy; Expensive
text:
I am a terrible fidget and I am always on the lookout for toys and gizmos that will keep me focused so I can sit still and not distract everyone around me. I selected this thinking it would be similar to those blister-type pop toys. It's not, but it's still an effective toy for stress relief and focus. It's possibly a little too noisy for a meeting, though.

At a glance this thing looks like the sections might come apart. They do not. Instead, this is an accordion-style fidget toy that you pull and push on the ends to make it expand and contract. It can be bent, twisted slightly, partially expanded and completely expanded. The colors are soothing and the tactile feel is nice.

When expanding the toy the sections are not silent. They're not loud, but they have a noticeable popping sound that's lost in the background in a normal environment but draws attention to itself in a more quiet area like a meeting room. It can be expanded more quietly with a little thought. If in an area where making a small amount of noise is acceptable, the sound is satisfying.

As I write this, this toy is close to $30 which seems high. This is really my only reservation with it.

I like this toy and will get some good use out of it. I usually mess with it when I am sitting at my desk and I want to sit still. It has a satisfying sound when popped, it's easy to work, and it looks pretty. It's a little on the expensive side, though.

title: Quiet Fun
text:
I am a terrible fidget and I look for things like this to help me focus when I otherwise would be unable to do so. I have messed with a variety of toys, and this one is somewhat similar to the popular snake puzzle, though it is a little different in ways that set it apart.

The idea here is that it is basically a plastic chain that can be twisted and shaped without causing a distraction to others around. Most of the time I end up with "squiggles" - random irregular shapes that look like nothing but are the result of just mindlessly fidgeting, but with some thought I can make more interesting shapes that have some symmetry or are recognizable.

The links can be disconnected too, and so smaller shapes (or multiple ones) can be created.

I especially like that it is not distracting to others around. It can be played with quietly and not draw attention which is a very good thing.

I like this toy and will get some good use out of it while in the office. It's a lot of fun and it's quiet enough to avoid bothering others around me.

title: Good Concept but Perhaps Needs a Design Revisit
text:
I chose this game with family game nights in mind. We're always looking for ways to bring all of us together for communication and fun, and this game makes a valiant effort to accomplish both. It's certainly not a bad game, but it is not our cup of tea.

This idea behind this game, when boiled down and simplified as much as possible, is to communicate via pictures and Venn diagrams to get the other players to guess hidden words. By placing the art cards on the various zones of the Venn diagrams in front of them the clue giver communicates that the picture may relate to one, two or all three of the words.

The rules seem complex at first but the game is actually fairly simple to understand if you slow down and read the rules carefully. I had to read through twice before everything clicked and I understood. That's not a bad thing but it should be noted that this is not so simple a game that can be learned in 5 minutes.

We ran into problems with the art cards. The cards themselves are very artistic and there's a lot going on with them - too much, actually, and they complicate the game because they're too busy and have many irrelevant details. I supposed that's part of the game's challenge, picking out details that are important and dumping what isn't, but it is frustrating for us and we ended up stopping gameplay when frustrations got too high.

Perhaps with a larger group in a party setting this might prove to be a much more fun game, but in our small family setting it wasn't as much fun as we'd hoped. The game isn't all that difficult to understand and the play is reasonably straightforward, but the art clue cards are overkill and made the game much more effort than just a casual fun activity.

title: Leaving the Comfort Zone
text:
I wasn't sure what to expect when I selected Better Than Yesterday. It sounds like an interesting self-improvement daily challenge of sorts, and it seems to be something along those lines. It's an interesting idea and it has some good thought behind it. However, some of the daily activities are less practical than others and really require getting out of the comfort zone.

The overall idea is a good one - self improvement by pushing your boundaries and finding your voice a little more. We all can use a little of that. But, there are a lot of activities on these cards that are a little over the top. Many cards require interacting with complete strangers in less-than-comfortable way and that's not an easy thing to do. In my area, strangers are frequently downright rude and hostile and that makes completing these challenges a lot more difficult. Many of the challenges are a lot more benign and less threatening, such as keeping a hold on your tongue and leaving nice notes for others. Some of them are more personal such as exercising and meditation. It's a mixed bag.

This is an interesting activity deck that's designed to help users get more comfortable with themselves and to leave their comfort zones a bit. Some of the daily activities are easy, while others are exceptionally difficult to the point of being impractical. Your mileage may vary.

title: Defective Right Out of the Box
text:
I have wanted some of these CYM Cubes toys for a while and I was pleased to have the opportunity to work with this one. Unfortunately, mine was defective right out of the package.

The issue with these things is that the color layer is applied like a laminate and is not properly sealed. That is, it can peel off and once it gets started it is difficult to get it back in place. Mine came right out of the package already peeling on one face, where the laminate was not applied properly. I can smooth it out but this is temporary; a few minutes later it is peeling again.

Otherwise, this is a fun thing. The color sides work together to make interesting color combinations. As a conversation piece this thing is crazy fun, but for me it is even more useful as a subject for abstract photography.

While I like this thing, it bothers me that the color layers are already peeling before I even unbox the object at all. I think the QA department needs to take another look and resolve some manufacturing issues.

title: Great for Photography and for Office Conversation; Peeling
text:
I have wanted one of these CMY cubes since I saw an online ad for these some months ago. They look cool and I thought they would make a neat subject for photography. I got the 95mm version and so far I am very pleased with it. It's not absolutely perfect but it is more than adequate for my needs. However, mine has a big, big problem with it.

The idea of this cube is very simple. It is coated on each side with a color-reductive layer that allows certain frequencies of light to pass while hindering others. The cube is transparent so you can see through it, but the color coatings cause the appearance to vary depending on how the cube is positioned relative to the light source. While the colors are cyan, magenta and yellow (hence the name CMY), it is possible to get green, violet, red and other colors through the cube just by turning it. My camera picks up these colors and I get some great shots because of it. Shining a bright light through it casts a light smear on the surface where the cube is sitting.

This is a solid cube that has some heft to it. It's a heavy thing, weighing in at almost 2.5 pounds, and it is a perfect cube. Looking through it, I can see very slight distortions from the manufacturing process, probably relating to temperature changes during pouring. It's not noticeable unless I look for it, and that was exactly what I did.

As a conversation piece this thing gets passed around like a dollar bill.

Less than 24 hours after receiving it, and after minimal handling, one of the corners started peeling. I was able to smooth it out to a point but I think it's a matter of time before it peels and is beyond fixing. For the cost I am very unhappy with this; it should be covered and sealed a lot better than that.

This is a neat plaything and I really like it a lot, but it's flawed. It's great subject for abstract photography. However, the peeling color layers really take away from an otherwise really cool product.

title: Smaller Snake Puzzles
text:
Years ago I had a snake puzzle similar to this one. It was larger and it was an off-brand, not a brand I had heard of before. In fact, I still have it though I have not messed with it in several years. I was interested in these by Rubik and thought they would be comparable if not better than my older snake puzzle. They're good, though I was disappointed that they're smaller than I expected and in use they're not as quiet as I'd like.

This is a smaller snake puzzle, as I mentioned above. When twisted into a ball shape it's about the size of a tangerine which is smaller than I realized. My older one was much bigger and it would roll into something about the size of a baseball. The size really is the primary disappointment I have with it.

When first working with these, it is important to realize that they're tight and are difficult to manipulate until they have been worked with a little to loosen them up. After messing with one of these for a few minutes it became a lot easier to twist and shape and it felt a lot less like I was going to break it.

These make an audible click when the pieces are turned. This might make these less appropriate for messing with in an office.

There are two of these in the pack and they connect together to form a longer snake that opens up possibilities for new shapes that aren't possible with just one. The connection is via what I can best describe as a ball joint type of socket, and when connected they are difficult to separate so there's no worry that they'll fall and get separated. While this is a nice feature, so far I prefer messing with these individually instead of connecting them into one long puzzle.

This is a nice puzzle snake package that gives two in one package that can be joined to make one longer snake. They're smaller than I expected, and they're not particularly quiet when the pieces are being turned, but these are well made and a lot of fun.

title: Fun (and Mildly Frustrating) Trivia Game
text:
I look for games that we can play as a family, and this one looked interesting. This is a trivia-based card game, and while fun it's a lot harder than we expected.

The idea here is simple - the group gets asked a really odd trivia question and everyone provides an answer, right or wrong. Closest answer (within reason) scores. The questions range from quantifiable answers such as percentages, measures of distance or weight and so on, to location answers like cities and countries. Sometimes the answers are deducible and can be figured out to within a reasonable range, while others are so far out there that getting close is a matter of lucky guesses - hence the name.

Game play is fun, though the wide-open nature of some of the questions makes the game mildly frustrating at times.

This is a fun game for the right group of people. It's a fun way to learn useless trivia, though it can get tedious and mildly frustrating as well. It's a decent party game, especially among those who really like obscure factoids and useless knowledge.

title: Interesting Game Based on Deception
text:
I selected this game thinking it would be a good addition to family game night. I failed to take into consideration that my wife is not a fan of these types of games, and as such it doesn't work for my family. That's my fault, not a problem with the game itself. With that said, in a group where bluffing games are favored this is not a bad one.

The achieve the game's objectives, a player must keep their plans hidden and rely on deception to gain influence, money and muscle. The trick is to balance that with enough playing it straight to keep other players off balance.

This is a card game, and each intrigue card has a "Play it Safe" and a "Gamble" action. Choose wisely. Sometimes the object is to gain, and other times it's to sabotage others. There's a good bit of strategy involved.

This is not everyone's cup of tea. In my case it is a mismatch. However, for groups that like games involving deception and sabotage and like card games this one is worth consideration.

title: Very Different Kind of Game
text:
Family game night is important to my family and we are always looking for new games to play. We took a chance on this one and it has proved to be different (in a good way) than anything else we have played.

Most games have an objective that is quantifiable - be the last player in the game, have the most points, capture something that belongs to another player, etc. This game is very different in that there is no stated goal to win, because it's not that kind of game. Instead, the goal is to boost communication amongst the players, and it really does that.

The game consists of three packs of cards in three categories. Most cards have a question or statement that must be answered, and honesty is key here in order for the game to work. When everyone is very honest and open, this game leads everyone into more free communication and everyone is likely to learn something in the process about everyone else.

I said "most cards" have questions or statements... There are some "wild cards" in the three decks that require everyone participating in an activity together. Again, this is building communication and comradery.

This is a different kind of game, but it works exceptionally well for families wanting to communicate more and draw closer. It's one that my family and I will play regularly.

title: Beautiful Board, Forgettable Pieces
text:
Chess is probably my favorite board game of all time and I do have a modest collection of chess sets that I have acquired over the years. I have never seen a leather board set before so this one is a new one to me. This is a nice set for travel and I like it, though I think it could be improved just a bit.

The most obvious feature of this set is the board. It is a wooden box board that folds for travel and is of average size for a decent travel set. However, what sets this one apart is the leather outer shell which adds a measure of class to this board. It is a light, creamy color with darker black squares. The leather is smooth and velvety with attractive stitching around the edges. It appears to be attached to the box quite well though time will determine if this is actually the case.

The board has ferrous metal under the leather so magnetic pieces can stick, even when the board is folded. This is perfect for travel, whether on a plane or in the car.

The pieces are nothing special and represent the one area where I think this set needs some improvement. The pieces are a plastic/resin material that really lack detail, and though they are recognizable they just aren't particularly interesting. I would rather spend a little more and get nice-looking pieces that do the board justice. Dull pieces on a board like this are akin to having a candlelight dinner on paper plates.

This is a nice travel set and the board stands out as something really special with the leather shell. It's attractive and seems to be well made. The pieces are nothing special, though, and it would be nice to have better pieces even if it means spending a bit more.

title: Easy to Understand, but Complex Under the Surface
text:
Family game night is important in our house, and I am always looking for games that the whole family will enjoy and will keep us laughing (or at least keep us entertained). I selected this one thinking it would be simple to learn and fun to play, and I was right. It has been well-received.

The idea behind this game is very simple. Given five bad scenarios, how would you rank them, from bad to worst? And, just as important, do the others players in the game agree with you (or at least know you well enough to figure out how you'd rank these)? Points are awarded based on how well your fellow players can figure out your ranking. At the end of the game, the player with the most points wins.

On the surface, this sounds very simple and straightforward, but it's a little more complex than it first seems. Yes, the rules are easy to understand and gameplay is as simple as described, but what is not so simple is how the players interact and how well they know one another. Often the game breaks into side discussions about why something is more terrible than another possible scenario, and often this leads to a lot of laughter but also some learning about the others around the table.

Replayability is good for the most part, though I think an expansion pack in the future would be a nice addition to the game. I suspect this isn't likely though.

Overall, this is a fun game and will entertain most groups. A big part of gameplay is the discussions that erupt and the humor that plays into some of the scenarios. Looking for a different game that will get the group laughing and enjoying themselves (over admittedly dark scenarios)? This game is very much worth a try.

title: Good Value
text:
When I was a kid I used to love Hot Wheels cars and I had a nice collection of them. These little cars have been around for a long time and they have changed some but they're still a lot of fun, even for adults. I selected this set not so much for playing but for photography and so far I am pleased with them.

These are a set of three themed packs of 5 cars each. The cars are reasonably well made (though there is a lot more plastic than when I used to collect these as a kid) and they seem to be painted cleanly as well. They roll straight right ouf the package too. For someone interested in little cars like these, this is a nice set to get started or to rapidly expand a collection.

The one car in the set that I do not light is the skateboarder. I would rather have had another little truck or a rally car or something. Even a beat-up old truck with primer would have been more fun for me, but I digress.

Price-wise these are quire reasonable. As I write this, the set is about $32, and that translates to just over $2/car. When comparing individual cars priced against this collection it's clear this is a decent value.

I like these and they serve my purpose quite well. These seem to be made well and they're priced right. If you want to start a collection or want to expand one quickly, this is a good collection.

title: Fun Variation to Uno
text:
My family and I look forward to family game night and Uno has been the game of choice on more than one occasion. It's a fast-paced game that requires luck as much as strategy, and that works well for all of us. We have a couple of Uno variants that we like, and with two adult sons that grew up with Mario games this is a good fit for our family.

This game plays identically to regular Uno in almost every way. It has all of the expected elements of the game - 4 colors, skip, reverse, wild cards and more. However, it also has a special card that changes the game in a fun and often unexpected way, allowing a player to dodge attack cards and send them back to the one who played them. It's powerful enough to change gameplay but not enough to ruin the game.

The cards are decorated with the familiar characters of Mario Brothers games - Bowser, Mario, Luigi, Donkey Kong Jr. and more. Fans of the Mario Brothers franchise will like this deck.

The game is packed nicely in a metal tin that protects the cards and keeps them together.

I am not the least bit unhappy with this game and my family and I have been enjoying it. We look forward to game nights and this game will be a part of those nights.

title: Decent Digital Chess Clock
text:
I have loved chess for decades and in my teen years I did play in a couple of tournaments. The clocks used when I played were analog and were a lot simpler. I have wanted a chess clock for years even though I have not played in a tournament since high school, and I was pleased to work with this one. So far I am happy with it even though I am still learning how to set it up and work with it.

This is a large-display digital countdown clock that allows for setting up various time controls. The instructions are a little on the sparse side but are clear enough to figure out how to set up the desired time controls, including adding time per move. When one player runs out of time, both timers stop.

I like the rocker button used to control the timers. It has a soft touch and it works very much as expected. The older timers I used were single opposing buttons that would pop the other up when one was pushed. The rocker is a little smoother and is actually very quiet which can be good or bad - if you rely on the sound of the button as an audio clue that the timer has been touched then this clock probably will not give that expected feedback. Then again, if you need absolute quiet then this clock will help.

It's not a perfect clock but it works well and I'm happy with it. It seems to be well made, the controls are easy to operate, and the price is reasonable.

title: Fun Cooperative Family Game; Lacks Replayability
text:
Several years ago there was a British series about Robin Hood, and my family and I have been hooked ever since seeing that series. This game seemed like a good fit for my family based on our interests, and so far it has been a good addition to family game night. That said, this game tends to be on the easy side and the replayability isn't great if you want a varying experience.

In a nutshell, this is a basic move-around-the-board game at its heart, though it requires cooperation instead of competition and it relies on a story book to further the game along. Some real time and attention to detail went into the design and it shows.

Though the game does not require following a path without turning to the left or right, it does follow a basic flow and the story book is designed to help guide and direct. That said, it essentially is a map of how to get through each step and it does not vary from game to game so once the game has been played the book could potentially slow down a game instead of moving it along at an interesting pace since previous players will know what to do.

This is certainly not a bad game. It's a good family game and is worth running through as a group. However, for those looking for replayability, this one lacks variety.

title: Revisiting the Old Arcades
text:
I love the old console games and I looked to this handheld to revisit some of the older games I remember enjoying several years ago. For the price this is a decent little console and I like it, though there is some room for improvement.

In the past, playing the older games required downloading a ROM and putting it into an emulator, and if you knew where to look for ROMs you could find hundreds of them, many familiar and even more that were very unfamiliar. I expected this little console to be something silimar to the old emulator, preloaded with old ROMs, and it seems to be fairly close to that. There are many games I recognize that are a lot fo fun to revisit, and there are a lot of games that are unfamiliar.

This console comes preloaded with several hundred games of varying types and quality. As mentioned there are quite a few that are familiar, but many that I never saw in an arcade. Some appear to be Asian releases that never were released here.

Navigation is a minor pain. If you want to play a game that is far down the list, you have to navigate there every time. There doesn't appear to be any memory for last games played.

Another minor disappointment is that several titles are listed more than once in the menu. This suggests to me that there are different versions, even if I can't tell what the differences are.

I'm thinking this is the same thing as the old emulators that can be found online and it just packaged in a handheld and preloaded with ROMs. That's fine by me, I like those old games. It would have been nice to provide better navigation, though, and maybe reduce the versions of each game to the latest or most bug-free? For the cost, it's a worthwhile system if you love those old games.

title: Nice Mini-Pens for Small Hands
text:
Note: There are multiple products attached to this listing. I am specifically writing this review for the mini gel pens.

I selected these pens for use in my office, not realizing these are mini pens (a detail I missed in the description). These are indeed very small and short pens - way too small for my large hands to use comfortably, and that's my fault for selecting them. However, these are a good option for children and for people with small hands. There's not much in the way of smell to these, though.

I love the colors. There are twelve different pens in the pack and they write with bold, bright colors that kids will love. These are not full-sized barrels so they are very likely to run out sooner than normal pens, but that's to be expected.
