These are advertised as having a cinnamon scent to them. My observation has been “not so much”. It's there, but it's not strong at all.

These are nice little pens that are probably best suited for kids and for people with small hands. For people like me with the hands of a gorilla, these are way too small to write comfortably - just keep that in mind when selecting.

title: Fun and Fast-Paced Card Game
text:
I selected this game for family game night. The premise sounded interesting and I thought it would be fun. It has proven to be a decent game though it was a little confusing at first.

The idea is simple. There has been a murder and the goal is to find the culprit. The whole group (all players) either wins or loses together, there is no individual winning or losing. So, it requires cooperation and careful strategy to win. It's a fast-paced game and a complete game can be played in just a few minutes after you get the hang of it.

The deck consists of 24 cards, each representing a different character in the game. There's the murderer, which of course is the target of the game. There's a gossip card which is highly useful when used properly, a witness card, informant card, and many more. The cards in combination with one another can determine the end of the game immediately, or they can cause player actions which move the game along.

The gameplay is pretty confusing when starting out. Certain events occur that require immediate actions, while others can trigger and end of game (winning or losing). Each card behaves differently. Fortunately, the actions are printed right on the card so it is easy to learn. Once a couple of rounds have been played it starts to get a lit faster and easier.

This is a different kind of game that is a lot of fun. There's a brief time of confusion while figuring out how to play but once through that it is a very replayable game that really is a fun addition to family game night.

title: Looks and Feels Unfinished
text:
I do not play Mancala regularly but it is something I do enjoy, and I looked to this set as one I could take to the office to enjoy with coworkers. It's a decent set up it lacks some fit and finish that would make it better.

Included in the set is the Mancala board and a plastic bag with multiple colored stones. There is also a concise rulebook on how to play one variant of the game - overall, a decent starter set.

There are several things about this set that make it less than ideal. The most serious problem is the board which has multiple issues. First, it feels unfinished with several very rough spots that are actually visibly rough. This doesn't make the game unplayable but it does take away. My board is not routed properly and it looks like the design was routed by hand and wasn't cleaned up properly with wood shavings wedged in the grooves. The reservoirs are shallow and it is easy to spill the stones while playing.

The stones are another matter. There are enough stones to play. However, there are no extras at all and if one or more are lost the game cannot be played correctly without replacements. And, there's no container beyond a cheap plastic zipper bag for the stones; a cup with a snap-on lid, or a cloth pouch, would be so much better.

This is a playable and functional set, lacking in finishing touches that differentiate it from a good one.

title: Super Fun!
text:
Ok, now this is a FUN toy! My family and I have been playing with this for a couple of weeks now and it has turned into a near-obsession.

This is a cross between badminton and ping pong. Players bat a koosh ball back and forth with two rubberized paddles that flex enough to give the ball some momentum and they make a satisfying sound when the ball is hit.

It's [relatively] safe to play in the house and it can be played in enclosed spaces as well as wide-open places too.

We've been having a blast with this and so far have no complaints. It's great fun and it is versatile enough for indoor or outdoor play.

title: A Balance of Strategy and Luck
text:
My family and I are always looking for ways to have fun on family game night, so this game seemed like a good fit. The problem with most games is that they often favor the most cunning strategist or the most knowledgeable trivia buff, so a game like this has enough luck mixed in to make the game much more unpredictable.

The idea of this game is relatively simple - end the game with the highest point value. This does not mean you have to have the highest value card in the whole deck, but rather the highest valued card among players. This means that a middle of the pack value can be a winner or a loser.

The rules are simple. Collect your salary. Draw a ticket. Play a ticket or swap performers. Go until there are no more tickets, either in your hand or in the draw deck.

There is some strategy involved, but luck of the draw is just as central to the game. If you have the ability to keep track of cards you can follow cards that you know about through swaps and discards. This can get tedious with more players though, so it isn't necessarily easy.

This is a fun game that does not require a lot of brain power to be successful. Game play is relatively quick and the rules are very simple and easy to follow. If short and easy games appeal to you, particularly ones that don't require extensive knowledge of useless trivia or require mastery in strategy, this is a good one to try.

title: Fun for Family Game Night
text:
I remember when Trivia Crack was the game everyone was playing online and I enjoyed it myself though I was no expert. This board game is a physical adaptation of that game, and it's a fun family game. It is not without its drawbacks, though.

This is a team game and the object is to travel a path on the board to win. Players move by answering trivia questions correctly. However, there are some other nuances to play - players can bet on how many others get the questions right as well, and there are power-up cards like Skip (pick a new question) to better your chances of winning - not unlike the original app. There are quite a few trivia cards of two types - multiple choice or single answer.

There are two basic issues with this game, neither of which are deal breakers but both of which should be mentioned. First, the board is relatively short so the game usually tends to go quickly which may or may not be a problem. If you like fast games that can be over and done (or have limited time to play) this is fine, but if you're looking for a trivia game that can go for a while like Trivial Pursuit, this isn't it. Also, at least for many, the questions tend to be on the easy side, which just makes the game go faster still.

As this is a new game, there are no expansion sets available at this time.

This is a decent game and is good fun for family game night. It plays relatively fast and it tends to end quickly. Fans of the original online app will particularly enjoy it.

title: Large, Yes; Mondo, not so Much.
text:
I have had different koosh balls over the years from the smaller ones to the giant ones. For me they're great for fidgeting - they're quiet and they're not likely to break anything if they're dropped or thrown. I was interested in this koosh ball for the office, thinking it would be a good fit for stress relief there. It has served its purpose well so far. I would hesitate to call it "mondo" though.

I received exactly ONE koosh ball. There has been some confusion of how many come in the package, based on the product pictures. To be very clear - you get just one and it's a random color. The one I received was a turquoise color; had I had the ability to choose I would have selected orange but that's another discussion entirely.

This koosh is somewhere between the size of a baseball and a softball. Yes, it is a little bigger than the original but I would hardly call it "mondo". I would have been much more understanding of the designation had the ball been even bigger (softball sized or larger).

This particular koosh is a little different than any of the others I have ever had - it actually has a tag in the middle of it, too short to pull or even cut. It doesn't affect anything and most of the time it's easy to forget it's there. But, it is there if you look for it.

I like this koosh ball and I am pleased with it. It lives in my office now and it has been tossed around quite a bit. It's a fun toy that's safe for the office as well as indoors at home.

title: Great Puzzle for Hoosiers Fans
text:
I selected this puzzle because my house is full of Hoosier fans and my son loves working puzzles like this one. I thought this would be a good fit and address two passions at once. So far this has been a good choice for us.

This is a 1,000-piece puzzle so it isn't one that will come together in an afternoon. This one will probably take a good bit of time to put together, and because the pieces are on the small side and the scene is very busy (a full Assembly Hall), this one will take several hours and probably will span over several days or weeks depending on the speed of the person(s) working with the puzzle.

When finished it is over 3' long and over 1' high. So, plan your workspace accordingly.

The puzzle isn't quite finished yet but it has proven to be good at occupying time.

So far this has been a good puzzle for my son who hasn't yet finished but is getting there. It's a good-sized puzzle that will eat up a fair bit of time, the picture is very detailed so there's some care required to get it right, and as of yet there hasn't been any issues with missing pieces, damaged pieces or duplicates. If you are a Hoosier fan or know someone that is, and you like jigsaw puzzles, this is one to consider.

title: Well-Made Folding Chess Set; Larger than Average
text:
Chess has been my favorite board game since I was a child and I have collected chess sets as a hobby over the years. When I selected this one I expected it to be on par with typical portable wooden sets which are usually cheaply made. This one was a pleasant surprise in that it is a step up from most portable wooden sets I have seen and used.

This is a fairly straightforward set. The case is a clamshell design that folds open into the board. There are magnets in the rim of the underside of the board to hold it closed when the set is not in use, ands the manufacturer did a decent job of concealing the contacts (though they are visible if you look for them). The squares on the board are smooth and while the seams between the squares can be felt when you run your hand along the board, the seams are smooth and are less pronounced that what I have seen on some other boards.

The pieces are decently made though are nothing special. They are machine cut pieces and have been smoothed, sanded and varnished. They are weighted nicely and have felt on the bottom to avoid scratching the board. They're a fairly average design but they look good and are very recognizable.

The main feature of this set is that it is larger than most fold-out boards I have seen and used. While this might not be the best for packing and portability, I really like the size. I am less likely to knock over pieces accidentally and I can see what's going on a little better.

This is not just a chess set but includes wood chips for playing checkers as well. The chips are small and are nothing of note but they are sufficient.

I really like this chess set and will use it as my main travel set moving forward. I like the size of the board, the feel of the pieces and the overall quality. There are better sets out there but they cost more. There are less expensive sets too, and the chances of finding one that is of the same quality as this one for less is small.

title: Nice Set of 7 Landscape Puzzles
text:
I selected this pack of puzzles for my son who has been spending time working on puzzles when he is not at work. This looked like a decent set of nice puzzles and so far they have worked out well.

One of the complaints that other reviewers have made is that the puzzles pieces are on the small side, and I tend to agree - these are not typical puzzles when it comes to piece size. They're not terrible by any means, but if you are expecting large puzzles that fill up a table top, these aren't it.

The pictures and landscapes are quite pretty and are very relaxing. The colors are a little unnatural in a couple of them, but the scenes themselves are very settling. If you like landscape pictures these will be pleasant to assemble.

Being smaller puzzles (in terms of piece count) these do not take an exorbitant amount of time to put together. Four of the puzzles have 300 pieces while three have 500.

These come in a set of seven and are bundled together well in a nice box that is suitable for gifting.

This is a nice set up puzzles, a little on the pricey side but with pleasant landscape images that are quite pleasing to the eye. The puzzles seem to be about the right difficulty level and don't require a large time investment. If you have a puzzle lover in the house, this is a nice set to consider.

title: Low Contrast Makes these Harder to Read
text:
I have a few “collectible” decks of playing cards, this one among them. These are fancy cards that are made well and I like them, but the color scheme is a bit off for the black suit cards due to the background.

I'll start with my main complaint with these first. These are dark cards, using a dark gray background for all suits, and using a dark purple for spades and clubs. This creates a low-contrast scheme that is more difficult to see in low light, and is less than pleasant even in brighter light. This is an unfortunate choice that could have been handled better. A bright purple, or even a strange color choice like orange or blue, would have worked better.

The artwork on these is impressive. A good bit of detail went into each design and it shows. The number cards (2 -10) have small designs on them that are at times hard to see and look at without a magnifying glass, though.

This are well made cards, coated and designed so they will not stick together even in damp climates. They come in a beautiful tuck box with reflective highlights in purple.

These are not bad cards at all. They're beautiful and they're well made, and they have some incredible artwork. However, the color scheme is not the best and these cards would be even better if the background and black suit colors were chosen a little more thoughtfully.

title: Fun Game; Minor Issues with Rule Clarity
text:
I selected this card game for our family game nights, as we're always looking for fun ways to spend time together and this one looked like fun. It's a really fun game with good replayability. There are a couple of places, though, where the rules are not well organized and could use some clarity.

The idea of this game is simple - build a flock of hens that lay more eggs than that of your opponents. Avoid predators and diseases if you can, and on occasion take action against your opponents to either slow them down or make life difficult.

In actual play, the game is not quite so simple. There are actions you can take every turn, plus you can play hen cards every turn to expand your flock, and your hens each lay eggs. So, a single turn can result in multiple cards getting played, and in some cases additional cards get played when the player finishes his/her turn and draws more. In one game, one of our players drew three “instant action” cards that required immediate play which extended the turn even more.

Gameplay continues until all the cards are drawn and one player goes out.

We found a shortcoming in the way the rules are written, particularly when it comes to action cards played against opponents. One card in particular limits the size of the flock you can have to three hens. In the rules, there is nothing in the description of this card that states that there's any way to remove that limitation; the remedy is described for a different card, and it is in a paragraph that almost reads like an afterthought. So, in the first game we played, this card was a game breaker because the player saddled with it didn't know there was any way to get out from under it. We found the solution after the game was almost over and it was already too late for the player to recover.

Another question arose with this particular card that wasn't addressed in the rules at all. If the flock was limited to three hens, if it is played against a player who already has more, what happens? Does the player have to surrender hen cards, or do they simply stop laying? This of course is a minor sticky point and we resolved it ourselves, but it can cause some discussion when the issue occurs the first time.

Games last about an hour (give or take).

We have had a lot of fun with this game. It's different than other card games we have played, there's plenty of humor involved, and the game is ultimately replayable while retaining the fun factor. There are a couple of areas where the rules could be more clearly written and fine-tuned, but overall this is a well-designed game that is a good addition to family game night.

title: Good Variety and Inexpensive; Small Puzzles
text:
I like puzzles and I also have a very bad habit of fidgeting. This set is right up my alley when it comes to meeting both of those traits. I would not call it perfect, but it is a good set that I think makes a great gift or a group exercise set in an office.

There are 28 puzzles and gadgets in all, 4 wooden 3D puzzles and 24 twisted wire puzzles. The wire puzzles are all packed in bubble packs to keep them separate, and the wooden puzzles are shrink wrapped.

The wire puzzles are all different, but they often follow the same solving techniques. Some are easy enough to figure out just at a glance while others are more difficult and require a good think or even a little trial and error to solve. These puzzles are small, and with my larger hands I have had some difficulty working with some of these. Most puzzles of this type I have seen have been larger, making them a lot easier to work with (though no easier to solve) but also more expensive. This is the trade-off.

From the standpoint that these puzzles are inexpensive and provide a good bit of mental stimulation and an outlet for fidgeting, this is an impressive and well-priced set. The downside is that these are small and are more difficult to work with if you have larger hands.

title: This Game is a Hoot!
text:
We picked up this game with the thought of expanding family game night. It has some elements of Apple to Apples (the game to which it seems to have most in common) as well as a handful of other games, and it has provided my family with a lot of laughter.

The game is actually pretty simple to play. Every player has a handful of cards with captions in three different categories, and the “judge” for the round plays a picture card and rolls the die that chooses the category. Players each play the caption card that they believe is the funniest, and points are awarded based on the judge's opinion (highly subjective) as to what's funny and what isn't.

Play requires a minimum of 4 players to really be effective, but in larger groups it gets even more fun.

The picture cards are often of people doing really bizarre things, or of redneck ingenuity, or of really back-woods scenery types of places and objects. Often, just looking at the picture is enough to make the room out break out into laughter, and when paired with the captions (which sometimes fit and sometimes do not), it gets even funnier.

Hopefully, there will be some kind of expansion pack down the road – more pictures, more caption cards, or both.

This game has been a hit with my family. If you like Apples to Apples, and if you like redneck humor, this might just be the game for you.

title: Refinement on the Old Elimination Game
text:
When I was in high school my senior class played an elimination game that was vaguely similar to this (and has been around for years and is still played across the country). Each person drew a name and that was the "target", and there were only loose rules on how to "eliminate" your target (most memorable weapon was a seltzer bottle), and graduation was the time limit. TAG is basically a formalization of that game, with fewer players and more specifics on elimination.

My graduating class had over 500 people, and not all of them played the game. Still, with 50+ players and months to play, it was unwieldy then. TAG limits the game to 10 players max, and the time frame can span anywhere from an hour or two to several weeks. Though the rules are flexible enough to allow for playing for months, this gets a bit cumbersome when having a small player pool.

Each player gets an ID card ("credentials") and a target name. Unlike the more informal version of the game, players are given specific instructions on how to eliminate their target. It might be luring the target to a location or lying in wait, getting the target to do something, or more. Nailing the target with the squirt gun or "poisoning" their food with salt might be fun but if it's not on the specific method card, it doesn't count. Once you've eliminated your target, your next target becomes whoever your original target was stalking. Gameplay continues until there's only one player left.

I like the way this game refines the elimination process, and I like the smaller, more limited scope. This makes it a good game for family events, fun in the dorms at school or even a company morale booster.

If you've ever played the old elimination game, this will be familiar territory. If you haven't it's a fun introduction. There's reasonably good replayability and there's enough flexibility to either play quickly or draw it out for days and weeks.

title: Fun Do-It-Yourself Project for Minecraft Fans
text:
I have two sons that have taken to Minecraft (more so when they were younger but they still play some), and one of them in particular still enjoys playing with Legos. This seemed like a good fit for him.

It took him a few minutes to assemble both, which he did over breakfast one morning. The look just like they do in the picture, though there is some opportunity for slight variation in appearance by virtue of some colored pieces having the same shape and size as others (not a bad thing).

Lots of little parts here, so some care is needed to make sure nothing is lost. Working on a table or work bench, instead of shag carpet, is obviously a good idea. The final units are actually a little bigger than I anticipated, about twice the size, so they're easier to play with when they're all done.

There's not too much I can find about these that are negative, to be very honest. They look like what's in the game, they're relatively easy to assemble, they're of good size and the price for this kit is not unreasonable. If you have a Minecraft fan in the house that happens to like Legos or do-it-yourself projects, this is a good gift option.

title: Simple and Straightforward All-Plastic Digger
text:
Note: There are multiple products attached to this listing. I am specifically writing this review for the CAT excavator.

When I received this item I was a bit surprised at how large it is, bigger than I expected. I was thinking this would be approximately the size of a bread loaf pan (a testament to how terrible my sense of measure is), so when the box arrived I was surprised when I opened it to find this large plastic truck.

This truck is all plastic which has some pluses and minuses about it. It's not all that expensive, which would not be the case if it was metal or had metal parts in it. It's completely waterproof, and it is made well enough to handle some limited abuse. It is not made of heavy-grade plastic, though, so if it is thrown or stood upon it could break.

There are moving parts but everything is manual. No levers, no buttons, no wheels other than the tires, so play isn't as automated. This may or may not frustrate a young child, though that depends on the child and not the toy. It's not a toy for the impatient.

This is a decent toy though there are some trade-offs. For the price it is a good unit that will keep a patient child busy. It is not the sturdiest nor is it the most technologically advanced, so it can be broken if handled very roughly and it may prove frustrating for a child who expects some automation.

title: Good Kit, Less-Than-Good Instructions
text:
I am a software developer by trade and I have an interest in small processor architectures like the Arduino, Raspberry Pi and BeagleBone. This seemed like a good kit to experiment with and learn. It is a nice kit but it does come with some built-in frustration.

This kit comes in a plastic box with all of the parts organized and packaged to make it easy to find everything and work through assembly. Some of the other reviewers have mentioned having a defective box that broke. Mine seems to be fine and has maintained its integrity. What really startled me was the sheer number of very small components. Be very careful to keep track of the parts as it is easy to spill them and lose some if working in a carpeted area.

Another surprise to me was that this car is about twice as big as I expected. That in itself is a good thing as it means it is easier to work on. I have the hands of a gorilla and it is difficult to cram my fat fingers into tight spots like computer cases, so having more room than anticipated to work was a pleasant surprise. That said, I made good use of a pair of carbon-tipped tweezers while working to get in the tighter spots and maintain control of the screws and posts.

Assembly took some time because of the number of parts, but this was complicated by the less-than-stellar instructions that accompany the kit. The print is small and the directions are not always clear, so I found myself redoing a few steps along the way because I misread or misunderstood the instructions. On the plus side, I did not need to break out the soldering iron or special tools beyond the aforementioned tweezers and a better screwdriver than the one in the kit.

Once assembly was finished, I ended up with a nice little car! It works as described with the remote and it does seem to be "aware" when it approaches a structure. The remote isn't particularly good though it is sufficient.

I have not yet started playing with reprogramming the Arduino. That will come in the next few months as I get more time.

I would not say this is a suitable kit for younger children (even when the car is finished). However, it is a great starter kit for older children interested in robotics and programming and it's even better for those who are interested in working together with their parents.

I like this kit though there is room for improvement. My main complaint is the documentation, which is a bit unclear and printed a little too small for comfort. The kit itself is an interesting start kit for those with an interest in robotics and small-architecture programming, and for parents and children looking for a project they can do together.

title: Snowball Fight in the Summer? Yes!!
text:
I like a good snowball fight, though I am not a fan of getting cold and wet. The closest I have come to an indoor battle with snowballs was with Nerf balls, and while fun it isn't the same. These artificial snowballs come a lot closer.

These are plush balls, about the size of a snowball you would pack with actual snow, maybe the size of a small apple. They look like they'd be lightweight and airy which would make them too hard to throw any distance, but these are surprisingly dense and have a little heft to them (though still less than a regular snowball). So, they can be thrown a reasonable distance.

Some thought went into these. When they are squeezed they make that familiar scrunching sound you hear when packing wet snow, which is probably the most interesting aspect of these. They are very densely packed and they do not lose material even when played with a lot which is surprising. They're heavy enough to travel a fair distance but light enough that even if you get nailed in the face they won't hurt you.

I really can't find too much wrong with these. They're somewhat realistic, they're fun, and they're inexpensive. They are a good option for having a snowball fight without making a wet mess. And, unlike real snowballs, these can be picked up and thrown right back...

title: Squeaky
text:
I have always liked fidgety things like this spinner, and I was excited to have the opportunity to mess with this one. It's a neat toy and I do like it, but mine could use a bit of fit and finish improvement. I am hopeful that this is a case of just getting a bad sample.

To look at, this is an attractive and aesthetically pleasing toy, about the size of an avocado pit. There are three colors from which to choose and the one I have is the gold. When spinning it is somewhat mesmerizing and it is relaxing to watch.

However, it makes a very faint squeaking noise reminiscent of needing a little oil or something in the bearings. At slower speeds it is not so noticeable, but when spun fast it is definitely not silent and it slows down a little more quickly than one would expect. I am not sure if it actually needs a drop of light lubricating oil or if it has some debris from the manufacturing process in the bearings. Either way, it is a disappointment as it takes away from an otherwise fun desk toy.

This is an interesting desk toy and it is relaxing to watch and fun to play with. Mine isn't quite perfect and it makes noise when it is spinning; hopefully it's just a case of a bad unit.

title: Fun Game with Many Small Parts
text:
Family game night is a big deal in our house when we're all together and I have been looking for new games to keep things fresh. We have Jenga, a fun game in its own right, and Kozo on the surface appears to be very similar in concept. It's a bit trickier, though it's great fun. The one reservation I have is the sheer number of small parts – easy to misplace or lose if care isn't taken with storage.

The concept is very similar to Jenga: stack and arrange your pieces and build your tower up without knocking it over. In concept, this is about as simple as it gets. However… Unlike Jenga, there are different sized pieces of different types, and as a result the placement is a lot trickier. Also, there are more rules to gameplay regarding what to place and when, and you don't necessarily lose when the tower falls as there are multiple rounds to play (if you follow the rule set as specified). Overall, it's a lot of fun.

My concern is that there are a number of small pieces and these can easily get lost or misplaced. If the tower falls, it doesn't take much for some of the smaller black cubes to skitter away and end up under furniture where they're more difficult to track down. This is unfortunately the nature of this game; making the pieces bigger would increase the cost.

Overall, fun game! It takes a little more strategy and effort than Jenga and the replayability is high. Be careful to keep track of the little pieces though.

title: Very Relaxing, Well Made
text:
I am a terrible fidget and I find myself messing with things on my desk all the time. It does help to keep me focused, though it can be distracting for others around me. I have seen these magnetic spinning balls online and have been curious about them so I was pleased to have the opportunity to try this one out. So far I am pleased with it.

This is a little bigger than I expected, being roughly the size of an avocado pit. I was expecting something more about the size of a golf ball. This is good for me as I have large hands so a smaller ball would be less comfortable for me to mess with.

The ball itself is smooth with a machined groove in a corkscrew pattern that runs from the top center to the base. There are no sharp edges and nothing to catch on which is a big plus. It is flat on the bottom and has a base that remains in contact with the table when it is set down, and it spins smoothly on the base. The mechanism is smooth and mostly quiet and it spins for quite a while. As it spins the machined groove gives the illusion of perpetual traversal from top to bottom.

As a straight fidget toy there isn't a whole lot to this. It is designed to sit on a table or desk and simply spin and be watched. For me, that's not as helpful as a worry stone or a fidget cube, but it is very relaxing and it is a good conversation starter.

title: Challenging Puzzle
text:
I don't work on jigsaw puzzles often though I do enjoy them. This is a large puzzle – 1000 pieces – and is a challenge. So far I am pleased with it.

This is a round puzzle, which presents a different kind of challenge than a square or rectangular one, as there are no corners to work from. However, the round edge does provide a starting point in its own right. The pattern and solid non-gradient colors makes this a tough puzzle but it is doable and I am making progress on it. I'm in no hurry but I'm looking forward to seeing the finished puzzle.

I haven't seen any pieces that are damaged, printed incorrectly or duplicated. I won't know for sure that none are missing until I'm finished (I've seen this issue with another puzzle I worked some time ago), but I have to assume for now that it's complete.

This is a big, time-consuming puzzle that will take a while to complete. The pattern is pretty, the pieces are made well and the puzzle itself is not unreasonably priced.

title: Cute, Well-Made and Not Expensive
text:
I have not played Exploding Kittens but I am familiar with the game and I have seen some of the cards. This is the first plush toy I have seen that is based on the game. It's cute, it includes a bonus card for the game and it appears to be made well.

This is not a very big plush toy, maybe the size of half a loaf of bread? It's an all-white cartoony kitten, and it has a 4-color barf rainbow that can be pulled out or rolled up and tucked into the mouth.

I looked this little guy over and looked for flaws and couldn't find any. The stitching along the seams is straight, there aren't any pills or snags, and there are no loose threads hanging out. Overall, it seems to be made of decent materials and is assembled well.

Finally, it is not particularly expensive.

This is a cute little accessory if you're into Exploding Kittens. I brought it to the office and set it up on a coworker's desk as a gag, and so far he hasn't mentioned it although it is impossible to miss it. It actually brightens up his work area a little, which is a bonus.

title: Good Addition to Family Game Night
text:
My family and I are always looking for good games for family game night and we decided to try this one. It's a decent game and a lot of fun, though there are some limitations that make it less than perfect.

Another reviewer commented that it is similar to Scattergories. It has some vague similarities, mainly in that there are topics that require answers with specific letters, but that is about where the similarities end. Instead of category cards, there are 9 six-sided dice and each of them determines the category when rolled. There is also a timer, though it is unconventional – it is a farting brain that emits a “depressurization” when the time is up.

Roll all the dice and each person takes a turn shouting out an answer that corresponds to categories on the dice, and takes one die away. Whoever is taking their turn when the time expires gets a chip. There are 25 chips, so there are (under typical play) 25 rounds, though there can be more if the players are fast. At the end, the lowest number of chips wins.

Overall, it's fun and a complete game takes maybe 30-45 minutes.

There are a couple of problems, neither of which are deal-breakers but are worth mentioning regardless. First, the dice are very lightweight, and as such it is very easy to knock them and make them turn without meaning to when playing. That is, when you grab one of the dice, bumping one of the others can make it turn which is disruptive to the game. Heavier dice would have helped with this. Second, there is a limited number of categories – 54 to be exact – and in 25 turns you get the same ones over and over again. Though the letter changes, the game feels very repetitive as a result.

This is a fun game and it is a good edition to game night. There's some room for improvement, but most will find the limitations livable.

title: Well Made and Well Thought-Out Features
text:
I have not one but two Minecraft nuts in the house and when the Enderdragon showed up on my list I snapped it up, knowing it would single-handedly boost my popularity in the house. It's a well-made toy and it definitely will please any Minecraft addict.

This is not a small item. Rather, it is quite big and it will take up a good bit of table or shelf space when it's not being played with. With the wings unfolded and the tail straight out, this takes up about as much space as a trash can lid, so if this is going to be something just for show, plan your space accordingly.

It's more than just a simple model or action figurine – it does stuff. There is a row of buttons along the spine that trigger different actions. One makes this thing roar and makes the eyes glow. Another makes the wings flap, and another causes it to shoot plastic disks from it's mouth. As a word of reassurance to those who remember the problems with toys that shot things in the 70's, the disks do not shoot out at an especially high speed and they're a little large to get caught in the throat so the choking hazard is miniscule. In addition, it has a handle that than be raised along the back that make this thing a lot easier to pick up and carry, and the button that controls the wings flapping just happens to be placed so that it can flap its wings while being carried.

It seems to be well-made and unless it is abused and mistreated it should last a long time.

So far, I can't find anything wrong with this toy. It is large, and it is a little on the expensive side, but it is well made and it is more than just a simple silent action figure. If you have a Mincecraft fan in the house, especially one that loves to collect merchandise related to the game, this should be on your short list of gift ideas.

title: Keeps Me Busy
text:
I have always enjoyed puzzles, especially the kind that require a little bit of logic and reasoning, so this is right up my alley. So far I have been happy with it and it keeps my mind occupied in the evenings. For the price, though, there is room for some improvement.

The object is simple. There are 200 game cards and a bunch of two-toned magnetic rectangles. Fit the rectangles on the game cards without overlaps so the colors on the magnets match the grid. As you might expect, this is not as easy as it sounds and you'll likely spend a good bit of time reworking puzzles to get them right. That's ok, it's forcing you to engage and think (which is the whole idea).

There are two problems with this product, neither a show-stopper but considering the cost these shouldn't be present. First, the cards are a bit flimsy and it is a matter of time before they either get torn, bent or show lots of wear. The second issue is that the magnets are slightly larger than will fit neatly on the puzzle card. It's not enough to ruin the experience, but it is enough to be mildly annoying.

This isn't a bad product by any means. It's a creative puzzle game that will keep you busy for hours (depending on how many you do in any given block of time, of course). It's a little expensive though, when considering that there's room for improvement in a couple of areas.

title: Upscale Playing Cards
text:
I had not heard of theory11 playing cards up to this point and I was intrigued when I was offered a chance to look at these. At first blush these seem like just an expensive deck of cards in a fancy box, but they're definitely more than that. While they are a little pricey compared to most, they're a bit more upscale than the typical deck you'd get for playing with.

Each of the cards in this deck is beautifully detailed with modern artwork, though they're not so detailed and busy as to overwhelm. I'm actually a little hesitant to use them for playing as they're fancier than any other playing deck I have ever had. They have a nice feel to them too, different than a Bicycle deck but slightly superior.

This is the type of deck of cards that a collector or a serious fan would get, and I would not hesitate to recommend for those people. For someone just looking for a nice deck to play with, though, I'm a little more reserved - these are a bit more expensive than the average deck and they're fancy to match in comparison.

title: Adorable, Well Made and Not Expensive
text:
I have always liked squirrels even though they are a nuisance at the bird feeders (and they chew on stuff like aluminum john boats and vinyl siding). I was delighted to have the opportunity to review this squirrel hand puppet. It is adorable and surprisingly it actually fits my hand.

It is made of very soft, plush material that feels like (but doesn't look like) rabbit fur. The tail is a little different, being longer fibers and feeling very lightly more coarse. Looking this little guy over, the stitching is straight and I found no loose threads or blemishes in the material.

Surprisingly, I am able to get my hand in this puppet and fit it properly. I have huge hands, so I was a little pessimistic that I would even be able to get my hand in this puppet. There are finger holes for the upper legs so you can wiggle his “arms” as well as move is head. There is no mouth to move, which is ok but is something to be aware of if this is something you are looking for.

It is not designed to look realistic but it is recognizable as a squirrel. It is very suitable for use in a classroom or children's puppet show.

If you are looking for a squirrel hand puppet that is great for children, this is a very good choice. There are other puppets out there that are more realistic looking, but they're also quite a bit more expensive. If you are content with something that is recognizable, works well and is not going to break the bank, keep this little guy on the short list.

title: A Good Alternative to More Expensive Brands
text:
I have always enjoyed coloring though I will readily admit I am a poor artist when it comes to drawing and illustration. I am learning as I go, though, and I am getting better. When I was a child I had a cheap set of colored pencils but I did not know the difference between those and good pencils until much later. I have a set of Prang pencils that has been my go-to as they compare very favorably against more expensive brands like PrismaColor or Staedtler. These colored pencils are a brand with which I was not previously aware and they also compare well against the more expensive pencils.

I have the set of 48 pencils. There are larger sets and there are also smaller sets. For my limited abilities this is a good number of pencils and I can usually find a color that's close enough to what I want. For the occasions when I cannot get the color just right, I can blend and get the shade right. More experienced artists may prefer a larger set, while absolute beginners are likely to be perfectly content with a small (beginner) set.

Coverage with these pencils is smooth and somewhat creamy, though a little waxy. I have been able to get very sharp, fine line detail as well as wide, smooth coverage when shading. I appreciate that these have slightly hard cores so they do not break or crumble like cheaper brands (Crayola comes to mind), and on very smooth paper the coverage is very uniform.

This is a nice set of colored pencils. They have good coverage, the cores are hard enough to resist fracture and are soft enough to give nice shading coverage. There are several different pencil counts available, so choose the one that suits you best – if you are a beginner and are experimenting, consider the 24 count. If you are a very experienced artist, the 72 count might be a better choice. For me, 48 seems about right. These are a lot cheaper than the big names, but they seem to be quality pencils and I am pleased with them.

Disclosure: I was provided a sample of this product in exchange for a fair, honest and thorough review. Even though I received this product at no/minimal cost I have rated and reviewed this product without bias, based solely on my experience with it.

title: Slow Gameplay, Repetitive
text:
I like board games and I am always looking for a good addition for family game night. I was given the opportunity to try Fauna. It's a different kind of game that has some appeal to it but it is slow and a bit repetitive. This is not my cup of tea, unfortunately, but I cannot deny the educational aspects of the game.

The game board is double-sided and uses imperial measures on one side and metric on the other. So, there are some preference choices that can be made right out of the box. The board is very colorful and attractive. So are the game pieces – colored wooden blocks that are used in gameplay. And, there are lots of playing cards, the meat of the game, that have various animal species and information about them. The physical design of the game is nice.

Each player gets the opportunity to bet on animal weight and location, knowing only the name, and there is a point scale associated with the betting process and getting the answers correct. The winner is the first to reach a certain point value (which of course is adjustable for “house rules” if you like).

Gameplay is slow. The betting process takes a little time but so does reading each card and finding the information sought. According to the rules that come in the box, the game can usually be finished in 10-15 card draws; that may be true with the right crowd, but this can vary based on who is playing and much they already know. The cards are educational though and for the players who do not know a lot about the different species, this game becomes a learning experience.

Games of this type (all the information on cards and the players have to know the answers) suffer from the same shortcoming – replayability. There will come a point down the road when all of the cards have been memorized, all of the facts have been learned, and there is only the luck of the draw separating the winner from the rest of the group. It may take a while but it will come.

This is not a bad game. It has some value to it educationally and some players may find it great fun. I personally don't care for it and the gameplay is a bit slower than I like. And, once you have burned through all the cards it becomes a game of recall, not a game of speculation. If you like games similar to Trivial Pursuit or if you really want to learn more about animal species, this one is worth a look. If you want something fast-paced or very replayable, you might want to consider other options.

title: By Grabthar's Hammer...
text:
I will start by saying that I would not call this a “game” but more of a toy or an accessory. There are no rules, no win conditions, no time limits, nothing that would define this as a game in the traditional sense. That does not mean that this isn't a lot of fun. It arrived on the day my son graduated from high school so it immediately had a steady stream of people playing with it and having fun.

The concept is very simple - whack the hammer as hard as you can and try to get it to give you a high strength rating. That's it, nothing more. When you whack it, it makes a sound like shattering glass, then it calculates the strength of the hit. The strength can range from 000 to 999. I worked very hard to get a very low reading and was able to get it as low as 42; a guest of ours maxed it out at 999.

This hammer has an oversized foam rubber head and a hard plastic handle. It will break fragile things like glass, but it can be used almost with impunity on desks, tables and counter tops.

I see two very good scenarios for this item. The first is to entertain drunk college kids that are looking for excuses to express bravado and drink more. (C'mon, you know you thought that too). The other is to engage bored/frustrated office and lab workers.

This is an interesting toy that works all right in groups. Yes, it is silly and is a one-trick pony but it's fun.

title: Great Variation on Chess; Includes Both Edition 1 & 2 Cards
text:
Chess is a great game that has been around for a long time. Most people have some basic familiarity with the game though it is more uncommon to find someone with a good grasp of the game and the strategies involved in playing effectively. There is opening study, tactics, positional understanding... All of these are good aspects of the game but ultimately the game can be very predictable and one can be forced to make certain moves at various points in the game. Knightmare Chess is the answer to the monotony.

Knightmare Chess is simple in concept and easy to play. The basic rules of chess apply and a chess board is required to play (unless the two players are able to memorize the board). Each player gets a certain number of cards and these cards are used to tweak the rules of the game. Some cards are played at the beginning of a player's turn, some at the end, and some actually are the turn. For example, a card can be used to convert a pawn to a knight before reaching the 8th rank, or force the opponent to take back a move, or even steal pieces from the opponent and conscript them into one's own army. The goal is still the same - checkmate the king - but now the path that otherwise would have been clear may be a lot more difficult.

There is a rule book that explains the basics of play but there is room for variations in the way cards are distributed and played. Some variations even call for two sets of cards, one for each player, while other variations consider point values and limits. Personally, I like setting up a draw pile and a discard pile and allowing cards to be drawn or discarded on each turn.

There is a total of 158 cards in the deck comprising the original Knightmare and Knightmare 2 sets, merged into one super set. Each card is plastic coated like high-end poker cards. The artwork on these cards is just beautiful and the artist who created them all took some time to make each one a miniature artwork.

I was introduced to Knightmare Chess a couple of years ago by a coworker who happened to have both sets of cards and I was hooked from the start. I was delighted to find this set with all the cards for a reasonable price and pounced on them before they go out of print again. If you have never played Knightmare Chess (either set) you don't know what you're missing. If you have played and wanted a complete set of your own, this set is a great option and is priced very well (about $23 as I write this).

title: Fun Game for a Crowd
text:
I am always looking for fun games that my family and I can enjoy together on game night and having not heard of Selfie I decided to give it a shot. It is a fun game but seems based on some other popular games that have been around for a while.

“Selfie” could just have easily been called “Apples to Apples Meets Charades!” which is a fairly concise way to describe it. Each player is dealt a set of cards describing a scenario where one would make some kind of facial expression, and then takes a selfie shot of that expression. After looking at the selfie shot, everyone else then plays one of their own cards to describe the expression, from which the original player selects a winner he/she likes most. Each person takes a turn taking a selfie and selecting others' cards.

The game can be played without a phone or camera but it's a lot easier with such a device which will help eliminate disagreements.

It should be obvious that this is not a game for the self-conscious individual.

Though I don't think this game is all that original, it is a fun game and works in a crowd. This is the kind of game to break out during a party in the dorms or on a Saturday night with the family. It's fun, gameplay is lively and fast-paced.

title: Very Well-Made Toy
text:
I have a son that loves to play Minecraft so he was particularly excited when Diamond Steve arrived to our house. Though it's called an action figure it is simpler than many other actions figures I have seen (right in line with the online game's graphics), and it's certainly better made.

The main thing about this toy that draws my attention is that this is well-made. It's made of good-quality plastic (not the cheap stuff that breaks when you try to do anything with it) and is very solid. There are moving parts like the arms, legs and head and even these feel sturdy. With a little effort Steve can be partially disassembled but he's not falling apart on his own.

The diamond sword fits nicely in either hand where there is a perfect groove for it. It snaps in firmly so it stays tight but it's not so tight that it's difficult to remove again.

I can't really find anything negative to say about this toy. It's solid and well built and it's a good gift idea for a Minecraft nut.

title: Great Fun - When it Doesn't Jam...
text:
Nerf has made some excellent toys over the years and I had high expectations of their RapidStrike CS-18 Blaster. While it's a good toy and a lot of fun, it had a bad tendency to jam up when firing.

As is typical with almost every other Nerf toy I have ever seen, this is a sturdy and rugged toy that should hold up under heavy play. It is made of heavy plastic that is of higher grade than typical toys and it has some weight to it, so it should manage well under being dropped or being stuffed in a bag and transported.

Aside from being an 18-shot magazine-loaded toy, it includes an accelerator that makes the projectiles fly farther. When activated via a separate trigger, the gun makes a sound reminiscent of Sci-Fi blaster weapons, which is a nice touch for playing. The projectiles fly far enough that I am a little concerned about shots at windows - while we have not lost any windows because of this toy I am a little wary of pointing it in the direction of a window regardless.

Unlike Nerf's Rayven product, the two-trigger mechanism on the RapidStrike works well.

There is really only one flaw with this toy, and it is significant. It jams. My kids discovered this issue almost immediately and complained about it, and sure enough it did not take long for it to jam up on me too. When in the middle of playing, it is discouraging to have to pop out the magazine, unjam the blaster and reassemble. I am not sure what causes the jamming, but it's fairly consistent and it's impossible to ignore.

My kids and I really do like this toy and it has been moved all over the house. If it did not jam so easily it would be an easy 5-star product. Unfortunately, it's a flaw significant enough to require a mediocre rating. It's really unfortunate - when it works, it's a fabulous toy, but when it doesn't it's just a disappointment. Hopefully Nerf will find a way to resolve this in the near future.

title: A Newfangled Scrabble
text:
I love word games and I particularly like Scrabble. I have seen Words with Friends online and though I have not played it online I suspected this game would be a lot like Scrabble. It definitely is. It's a good game and can be a great addition to family game night.

Words with Friends is a crossword game where the goal is to create words and score points by strategically placing the words on the game board. The board has a number of bonus squares where extra points can be had - double word, triple word, double letter and triple letter. The player with the highest score at the end of the game wins. Each player gets 7 letter tiles (with point counts printed directly on the tiles) with which to make words. Play continues until all the tiles are used and all of the scoring opportunities are expended.

Game play as described above is just like Scrabble, but there are some differences. The score assigned to individual letters varies is little bit. The bonus squares are laid out differently too. Using all 7 letters in one turn results in a 35-point bonus, not 50.

The tiles are a glassy-looking orange color and are very aesthetically pleasing, even though they are simply plastic. The board itself is a two-piece creation and it clips together into one larger board. Assembly is simple.

I noticed a couple of flaws in this game, though these are not enough to lower my opinion of the game enough to matter. First, the board does clip together and turns nicely - on hard, flat surfaces. On carpet, the board can be a little uncooperative and can come apart. My second complaint is that the rules are so general that there is a little room for interpretation. People who have played Scrabble have a slight advantage - the unspecified rules are easy to fill in.

I especially like something printed on the box: "Your Smart Phone Unlocks Digital Features (phone not included)" Sorry, this made me laugh - I hope it's clear to everyone that there's no phone in the box...

Other than a touchy board and some slightly incomplete rules, this is a very fun game and is sure to be a hit on game night. My teenager and I have been playing and he's learning that I know more than he thought I did...

title: Fun But Repetitive Game, Could Use Expanded Rules
text:
I bought Dread Pirate at a store I found when I was on travel. I had never seen it before then and I did not know much about it but it looked like a fun game to try with the family. While it is indeed a fun game, it does tend to be somewhat repetitive and the novelty can wear off quickly.

The game rules are simple. You get a ship and a bag of treasure and you have to collect more treasure by raiding ports and attacking other ships. Once you have sufficient treasure you can visit the central island where, if you're the first one there, you become the Dread Pirate with special attack and movement bonuses. The game ends when all of the treasures have been collected from the ports, and the player with the highest number of treasures wins the game.

There are modifier cards that are pulled when a ship crosses certain areas of the map. These cards can add or take away combat bonuses and treasure. My observation with the cards is that there are really only a very few variants: +/- one or two combat, +/- one or two treasures, +/- moves, and gain a turn/lose a turn. Every card is different, though, in its description of how the bonus or penalty is assessed, and these variations on the cards serve as entertainment.

Play is driven by dice. Roll the dice to move, roll one die to attack/defend. That's really all that drives gameplay. There is some strategy involved but it's limited in scope - a player can decide what route to take and what other players to hunt down but that's about it.

The very best feature of the game is actual physical game pieces and map. This is a very well-made and beautiful game and it should last for a long time with proper care. The ships are metal as are the doubloons and the jewels are glass beads. The map is a very attractive cloth fold-out and the box in which the game came is solid wood. I have no complaints about the workmanship or materials.

The game does tend to get very repetitive. Unless something particularly unusual happens during a game the play is fairly predictable, all players racing to ports and attacking each other repeatedly. To help offset this, we developed a couple of house rules to make the game a little more interesting though additional rules (or variations on the rules) would be welcome.

We broke out this game on a game night when we had a house full of teenagers. With the exception of the kids living in this house, none had ever seen the game before. It was absolutely the hit of the evening and we heard from parents the next evening that most had asked for a copy of this game.

Dread Pirate is most notable for the excellent game set. However, where it is weak is in the rule set and in the repetitiveness of gameplay. I have seen a movement online to generate expanded rulesets and hope that these new rulesets will add a fresh spin to the game. This is a decent game regardless and is worth a look.

title: Fun Nerf Gun, With One Flaw
text:
I have two energetic boys that love to rough-house and play war games so a Nerf gun is a perfect toy to keep them busy for a while. This Nerf gun is great fun for kids and adults but there is one problem with it that keeps it from being truly great.

Putting it together is actually fairly straightforward. In fact, it is more difficult to take it out of the packaging than it is to assemble. Once it is out of the box, loading the ammo and slapping in the magazine takes no time at all. There is that matter of batteries; this toy takes 7(!) AA batteries, 4 for the gun itself and 3 for the magazine. It seems a little excessive but it does not weigh down the toy as much as you'd think.

The magazine needs batteries to power the blue light within that gives the gun a glow for night-time play. It didn't seem to add too much to game play but it didn't hurt either.

There are two triggers on this gun, one of which handles the accelerator motor and the other that launches the foam projectiles. When the accelerator motor is engaged, the gun makes a noise reminiscent of a sci-fi blaster-type weapon that is being armed - really cool.

This two-trigger approach is actually where we have found the one issue with this toy. Both have to be pulled for anything to happen and the placement is a bit awkward. Having larger hands, I have no trouble with it. People with smaller hands, however, are likely to have some difficulty with this setup. It is workable as a two-handed weapon but that (obviously) ties up both hands even though the gun itself is light enough to be easily carried with one hand.

This is a fun Nerf gun for kids (or perhaps for cube-farm after-hours fun in the office) and it is well made. It works well and it does have a pleasing sound to it when it is used. The trigger configuration is the only reason why I give it 4 stars instead of 5. If two triggers is not an issue for you, then this is a great toy that's worth the asking price.

title: Great fun - turn the yard into a war zone
text:
I am a fan of Nerf stuff and so are my children. I really was excited by the opportunity to play with this Nerf gun.

It arrived in an immense box which was the first surprise. I misjudged the size of this toy, thinking it was a bit smaller, so pulling it out of the box and the packaging was a bit of a surprise.

Within a few minutes I had the gun out of the box and all of the clips loaded. I popped one clip in, turned the gun to the door, pulled the trigger and then realized that it needs batteries... I should have read the instructions, which clearly explained that it required batteries. The problem - it needs 6 D-cell betteries, which adds a lot of weight.

Once I had everything set and batteries in place, I pulled the trigger and emptied one clip in less than 10 seconds. The gun has a firing rate of roughly 2 rounds per second. I was pleasantly surprised when the noise was not overly loud, in spite of a battery-driven mechanism for firing. I popped the empty magazine, inserted the next one and kept rolling.

The gun comes with a stand, so that play can include simulating sniper fire from a nest, and there is a mountable shield on the front. Both of these pose some slight issues. The stand tends to fall if any pressure is applied to the gun while the stand is clipped on, which is better than breaking but it's still mildly frustrating. The shield also does not stay in place, and it interferes with the sight on top of the barrel. While it's not likely kids will need the sight, it's still a minor consideration.

This is a rugged toy! The main gun assembly is built to hold up to rough play and it can handle some knocks and drops.

It comes with 60 foam bullets/darts, exactly enough to fill all 4 clips. That's a generous number of shots, and I believe there are replacement available when needed.

This Nerf gun is a lot of fun and will keep the kids busy for quite a while. The weight with batteries is a consideration and will affect play on occasion, but with the ability to set up the gun with the stand this becomes a less important factor.

I did not immediately tell my children that I had this Nerf gun. They found out about 0.5 seconds too late...

title: Fun basketball dice game!
text:
We gave this game to my son as a birthday present, thinking it would be a good rainy-day activity for when he cannot get outside to shoot hoops. We had never seen it before and were hopeful that it would live up to the description on the packaging, and it has exceeded all of our expectations (not just his).

The premise of this dice game is simple - you roll several specialized dice and based on the outcome determine if you score, get fouled, get the ball stolen or some other outcome. There's a printed rulesheet that explains what to do for practically all outcomes of a roll, leaving little ambiguity during play. Each player gets a total of 24 possessions, 6 per quarter, and there is a stack of scoresheets for keeping track of the game.

For a dice game there is a surprisingly comprehensive coverage of the real rules of basketball. There's even a possibility of getting a slam dunk!

A complete game can be played in about 15-20 mintes, even when referring to the rules frequently.

The game is very well made. The dice are all made of hard plastic that are large and easy to read, and the throw cup is equally sturdy. The pouch in which the cup and dice fit for travel is a little on the cheaper side, being made of imitation vinyl, but this is not a serious concern if the game is cared for properly.

The rules sheet is on the small side, so to account for the possible loss of the rule sheet I made a scan of it and printed it out as an 8.5"x11" page.

All of us have had fun playing this game! For the basketball nut, this is a fun and well-made game that is not overly expensive and can be played in a reasonable amount of time.

title: Fair tactical problems, decent organization, bad interface
text:
I selected this product over its competitor, CT-Art, due to the number of tactical problems and price differential. I have used ChessBase programs in the past and have had good experiences with them, so I thought this would also be a good package. In some respects I was right, but in others, not so much.

Intensive Course Tactics (ICT) boasts over 4,000 tactical problems to work through and practice, which is very respectable. The sheer number of problems is enough to merit attention, but what is not clear is that a lot of these problems are very basic and suitable for beginners. Many, many problems in this collection are simple one- or two-move tactical finds, which are important even for more experienced players to know but they do not "feed" advanced players the kind of practice necessary to advance very far. Without question, less experienced players will glean the most knowledge from this collection. That's fine, but it should be made more clear in the packaging.

ICT is broken up into a multitude of databases which at first seems a little overwhelming, but the organization is actually reasonably good. There are databases for tactics relating to forks, windmills, pins, skewers, material capture and a whole lot more. There is naturally some overlap in theme but overall the organizational layout is logical.

The interface that is included with the ICT databases is not good. It is an old ChessBase reader and it is clunky, unattractive and a little awkward to use. The databases themselves are in ChessBass format though, so if you have a more recent version of Fritz/Hiarcs/Junior/etc., I would strongly encourage using that instead of the included reader to access the databases.

ICT is really not a bad product. It has a lot of good tactical training broken into very logical areas of practice, but mostly for players working their way up from the lower end of the class rankings. It is unfortunate that the reader with it is poor. While I can recommend this product for certain players, I would encourage stronger players to look at more challenging options.

title: Fun game, though the rules are somewhat ambiguous
text:
I picked up this game recently when I was on travel and I found a copy in a gift shop. I picked it up because of the name and I thought it would make an excellent conversation piece. It has proven to be more than that for my family.

Morgan's Revenge is a form of gambling game, similar to craps though using a spinning top instead of a die. It's a game for groups, where everyone antes up and then each player takes turns spinning the top. How the top lands determines what action to take - put more in the pot, take some out, take all, etc. It's a lot of fun and even includes some "silver" pieces of eight and "gold" doubloons.

There are a couple of problems, though. First, the rules are not very clear. Apparently this is intentional, as the rules explain that you can make rules up as you go. Well, ok, but a good starting point would be to mention how much of an ante to start with... More of a problem though is the limited number of coins in the box. You get 6 pieces of eight and 6 doubloons, so even though the rules state that any number can play, there's not enough coinage to go around unless you add some. That's all right, though, since you can play with pennies, marbles, rocks - whatever. If you can find more tokens/coins, you're in fine shape to play. I disagree with the notion that any number can play, though, from a practial standpoint - if you have 10-12 people at the table, it's going to be a long, long game with some frustrated players. We play it with 4 and it seems to be about right, though I could see up to 6 without too many headaches.

The game is exceptionally durable. It comes in a metal tin, with a wodden block holder for all of the metal game pieces.

As for its educational value, there are some piratey things you can learn from the tin and from the booklet, though once you have read those there isn't much else. It was not meant as an educational game, though.

This is a fun game for groups, and it makes an interesting gift.

title: Perfect gift for a toddler!
text: Purchased this as a gift for my three-year-old nephew. He loved it! It's a fun product and keeps kids entertained for hours!

title: Great toy for play or bath time
text: Purchased for a gregarious male toddler who is extremely happy with the Tugboat. Makes a great gift too.

title: A great buy that your child will love and the toys will last
text: I purchased this fantastic toy carrier truck set by Green Toy company a year ago, and it is still going strong. My grandson is now two, and he still loves it. It has lots of livable cars and is nicely colored, so it keeps his attention, and I think it's the perfect gift for durability and the environment.

title: Ok, but need an end cap
text: This is lightweight, and mostly effective. My only issue Is that there is it does not come with an end cap to cover the bottom and prevent dust particles from getting into the unit. If I can find an end cap, it will be much more useful. My suggestion is that you look for a different spacer with an end cap or be prepared to use a zip lock bag to protect the chamber and block dirt.

title: Fantastic toy for little ones
text: This is a cute and well made toy. The colors are perfect to keep a little one's eyes focused and alert. It is a great item for children and it keeps them engaged. We purchased a second one for our nephew & he loves it!

title: Great toy for the crawler in your life!
text: Purchased for our little one and he totally loves it. The little moving green turtle is a great touch and it helps keep his attention. This is a great item for gift giving too. Highly recommend this product!

title: Cute accents and party decor for baby shower 4 pack
text: Light blue engaging fun colors added nice decorative touches to the tables for our baby boy shower. Small and easy to place around the room and can be resumed. These matched the gift bags we used and everyone commented on the quailty and festive decor of the shower.

title: 5yr old loves this kit
text:
What a fun craft kit for a 5yr old. She loved it so much. Spent a couple of hours happily completing all 4 key rings. Once she was shown how to apply the gems, she was able to do it on her own.

This kit is well thought out. Each once is stamped with color coded gem placement guide, making it really easy for kids to follow. Highly recommend

title: Perfect size for a 5yr old
text:
Omg, this black cat with the large green eyes is adorable. Great gift. The smaller size is perfect for a “take-along”. My 5 yr old grand wears her on her shoulder, loves petting/brushing her & slips her into her cross body bag to take with.
Excellent construction & attention to detail.

title: Excellent set
text:
I have been searching for a Magnetic Alphabet with lower case letters & multiples of all letters. This will be wonderful for my 5 yr old granddaughter who is learning to sound-out/read/spell beginner words. I like the small size of the letters, which will make it easy to fit many words on the fridge. Alternately, we can lay these on the floor.
I have 2 pre-K grands, so when they both come to visit there are plenty of letter for them both to have fun.
Multi-letters with lower case is a rare find. I highly recommend this set.

title: Best craft, ever for pre-schoolers
text:
My granddaughters are both 4.5 yrs old & we love this craft kit. I have bought it 3 times & will be ordering it again. The great thing about this is, the design possibilities are limitless, so we never get bored. My grands make a totally new design, every time.
The spongy bead clay is super easy for them to spread on the vase. The buttons are easy to slide onto the wires & I add the final tule petal for them.

Quality is great & there is more than enough materials in the kit. We always have left overs, which I am saving until I have enough to make another one - all I will have to buy will be an inexpensive vase.

Here is a pic of the first one they made.

title: Simply A-Dorable
text: These are the cutest finger puppets I have ever seen. So soft & adorable faces. The ‘bodies' are a bit longer than traditional rubber finger puppets, which makes them easy for young ones to keep on their fingers. My grands are both 4 yrs old & love them. So cute, they inspire all kinds of little finger puppet adventures. Bonus - they are perfect Easter Egg stuffers.

title: 4yr old loves this game.
text: What a great game for pre-schoolers. Easy for a 4yr old to learn to play. I love that the name of the animal is printed on the card & there are 2 of each animal on the full board. It's  a great game to help young ones learn to take turns & follow simple rules. I have already ordered the other Sequence with Letters version of this game. Perfect birthday gift for boy or girl.

title: Perfect craft for Birthday party
text:
Really bright colors. Nice shiny flexible material. Wide elastic band( it's not just a thin elastic string that would break)
The stick on jewels are a good size & the crowns have recessed ovals & circles to use a optional placement guides. Note, there are not individual sheets of jewels - the kids will have to share. (individual sheets would be a great feature)
I cant wait to watch the kids make their own crowns at me granddaughter's party.

title: Nice large beads
text:
These pop beads are nice & large. Easy for a 4yr old to pick up. The colors are vibrant & this kit includes a lot of different shapes. The headbands, bracelets & rings are really cute & easy for a preschooler to put on. The storage box has 2 locking clips, a handle & a nice square compact shape. Great storage piece. All in all, this is a good quality set.
One CON:
I will say, they are not easy to pop together, right out of the box. The adults had to spend time popping them together & apart to try to loosen them up. (I was struggling with a lot of them). Once they loosen up, 4yr old will be able to do it herself.

title: Super fun for pre-schoolers
text: What a fun game to play with pre-schoolers. It's a pretty fast pace game & little ones catch on right away, needing no help when it's their turn. The bonus is, they can play this by themselves. Nice compact game, easy to store in the box it comes in. High quality glossy cardboard that will hold up to kids. Nice & colorful. This will be a great gift for upcoming birthday party invites.

title: Just like when I was a kid
text:
This is a well made toy, that is not going to break. The beads are brightly colored & make beautiful designs. It's easy for small hand to turn the end to change the design. The eye hole is large, which is great for pre-schooler.
This is a great price for a quality toy. Kids love it.

title: Super cute kit
text:
This was a big hit with my 4yr old, mermaid obsessed granddaughter. The colorful beads have large holes which made it easy & fun for her to string. There are a variety of beads; round, flower, transparent & opaque. I love the larger size of the character beads. The colors are bright & she can easily tell who each character is. The rubber necklaces are great, too.
Once her necklace was complete, I glued the end so the beads wont fall off. It's stretchy rubber, so she can put it on over her head.
I ordered the “princess” kit, too.

title: Preschooler quickly lost interest
text:
The first 10 minutes were fun, then our 3.5 yr old got bored. This repeats the exact same pattern every time it restarts. I expected it to be randomized. I would say this would be best suited for a 2 or 1 yr old.
Nice size. Bright colored panels. The lights shine brightly. Good quality construction. Nice little take-a-long toy for the carseat or stroller.

title: Wonderful
text:
My 3.5 granddaughter loves these. So many ways to stack them, unlike square or rectangle blocks. She has fun making then balance, so I have ordered a 2nd set to add to the challenge. Great quality. Really fun facial expressions on each one. Smooth edges. Nicely painted. We even hide them for her & play find the robot. She is learning how to set them up as dominos, too. So many people ways to have Fun Fun Fun
The box they come on has a flip open top which makes for easy-peasy ‘clean up time' Sturdy box is great for flat storage.
These would be a great birthday gift.

title: Pictures of cates are too simular.
text:
I bought this to play with my 2 pre-school grands. They love the concept of the game & giggle like crazy when either of them picks the “stinky cat lady” 🤣
However, as they dont read yet, they rely on the cat pictures to match the cards. imo, there are too many pictures of the same cat breed in a slightly different pose. It's very confusing & challenging for a 4 yr old to recognize the slight variations.
I would give 5 stars if all the matches were distinct & easily identified by pre-schoolers not quite ready to read, who I assume are the intended audience.
The sliding lid tin case is wonderful. The card size is perfect for small hands.

title: Tiny tiny tiny blower
text: Bought multiple bottles for a party. The blower circles are so tiny, no one, including the adults, could get any decent bubbles out of these. Sorry I bought these & put a damper on the party. Kids don't understand why they cant blow bubbles, no matter how hard they try 😟

title: Broken in 3 places
text:
