title: Hate this as a parent
text: My kids, ages 3, 6 and 8, have now played with this for several days for 2-4 hours at a time. They have made a giant rocket, an igloo type structure, a pretend volleyball net, and more. And they have had issues with all of it. At first they had a lot of problems pushing the connectors on tightly so it didn't immediately fall over. They got better at that, but it still remained a problem because even when one or two weren't tight enough, the whole thing would fall over. They remained determined after the first few fails, and I helped put together a pretty large “igloo” we covered with two full size sheets. It was large enough the 3 of them could all fit inside, but after I left the room for 30 min, I came back to find the whole thing had crumbled and only a small portion remained standing. (And of course I have to mention the 8 million pieces this comes with - if you get annoyed with crap all over the place, this is not the toy for you.) So even though my kids thought it was fun, if they cannot use it themselves, and if it isn't stable enough to stay up even when I build it for them, I have to conclude it's not for us. I don't want to have to continually be there to make this set function as you would hope it would.

title: Perfect for 8 year old daughter
text: Even though we are partial to Legos, not Mega, sometimes you gotta settle for the characters your kids love. My 8 year old loves Pokémon, so she loved building this. It's definitely not as well designed and constructed as Legos - these fall apart more easily and take more effort to assemble, but she loves the design. The instructions are clear enough she could do it herself.

title: Large notebooks for lots of fun
text: These 4 notebooks are very large, not in terms of the number of pages, but in terms of the actual height and width of the pages. They are much bigger than most scratch art I've seen, which is fun. The stencils are actually pretty fun too. We had to use a toothpick to get in some of the tiny spots, but it worked well. Overall it still seems a bit expensive since each book is only 10 pages - my daughter went through 5 pages in about 30 min - but all scratch art seems expensive to me.

title: 2.5 hour build for my 6 year old
text: My 6 year old loves this set! Even though he hasn't seen Black Panther, he enjoyed the set and minifigs. It was about a 2.5 hour build for him.

title: Fun colors with not great packaging
text:
I got these to give to my 3 year old for Christmas. The crayons themselves are awesome, but the packaging is a bit lacking. There are 7 cardboard sleeves laying down in the main box. After seeing this, I know my daughter will end up just mixing them all and they will all float loosely around the big box.

There are
32 metallic (2 sleeves of 16 each)
32 Pearl (2 sleeves of 16 each)
24 confetti (1 larger sleeve - lots of white crayons for some reason, see picture)
16 neon
16 cosmic

I prefer the design of the normal boxes where the sleeves all stand up vertically inside the box and kids can view the colors at the same time and store them easier. Even though these colors are great, I feel like the box cuts down on the fun.

title: Fun Barbie twist
text: A fun twist and interesting surprise that make this more fun than a typical Barbie.

title: Awesome set for 3 year old
text: My 3.5 year old loves this set!! She has loved Duplos since age 2 and has even started some of the 4+ Legos, but I think she will still love this for the next year. The animals are huge and plentiful. The quality is great and they will be passed down to her younger sibling when she's ready.

title: What basketball team do Koopas cheer for?
text: The Shelltics.

title: Minifigs!
text: This set is tiny, but worth it just for the minifigs. In fact, I got it for my 6 year old son who assembles 9+ legos regularly and is far beyond this 4+ set, but he wants the minifigs! So we appreciate the tiny sized set and therefore low cost. It would also make a great gift!

title: Great stocking stuffer
text: My first thought when seeing the little box this comes in was that it would be perfect for a stocking! My 7 year old daughter loves the Lego dots and the artist in her loves rearranging the dots over and over. This patch is perfect for her. There are also adhesive ones that are perfect for notebooks and journals, but this one is fun for attaching. She will likely use it on a canvas bag!

title: Fun stocking stuffer
text: This tiny Lego sticky patch would make a great stocking stuffer. It is perfect for sticking to a notebook or journal. It is priced appropriately for its small size.

title: Perfect for my 3.5 year old!!
text: My daughter started putting together the 4+ sets right after her third birthday. She is now 3.5 and definitely has gotten the hang of and loves building Legos. She isn't very fast, but she can definitely do it when she's in the mood to focus. This set took her somewhere between 3 to 4 hours to build. She really loves the minifigures in this set and the dragon too. Overall it's super cute!

title: Enormous variety of baseplates and bricks
text: My 6 and 7 year old love Legos, and as much as I would love to see them build sets and keep them intact :), they much prefer to scramble all of their pieces and free build over and over. This set is perfect for that, and perfect as a starter set or to add on to existing Legos. You really can't go wrong with this. It will get creativity flowing for all ages. The sorting box is cool too, but at the end of the day, our Legos all end up mixed together in a big container.

title: Fun for kids 5-9
text: The first and seconds graders at my kids school all love these bracelets. They are fun for boys and girls and make great gifts too!

title: 3 hour build for my 7 year old
text: I wasn't sure if my daughter would like this since she's never seen Avatar, but she loved it. It was fun to build and took her 3 hours, which is longer than other $60 sets we have recently purchased. It was a good level of complexity for her- not too hard but not super quick to build. The finished product is fun and can all be connected and displayed as one piece.

title: 4 hour build for my 6 year old
text: This took my 6 year old about 4 hours to build, which is way longer than most sets at this price point, so that was a big win for us. He has never seen Avatar, but he thought the beast and the robot were pretty cool, and the colorful landscape/background is really fun and bright. This ended up being way more fun than I expected because we normally stick with Star Wars legos and sets we are more familiar with.

title: Super thick and stiff
text: This felt, in fun fall colors, is extremely thick and stiff. It is great for crafting and a high quality.

title: Fun for 2-6 year olds
text:
My daughter had enjoyed playfoam since she was 2.5. Now 3.5, she really enjoyed this set and played with her 6 year old sibling. There is enough for 2 kids to play together and have fun making up games with the pattern cards and different colors of foam, cupcake liners, candles and flags.

We have had playfoam that we kept in a plastic bag that was still playable two years later. They do start to get a bit dry and more messy as they dry out a little - individual balls of foam are more likely to end up on the floor or table here and there. Fresh foam (new to 6 months) is most fun and moldable, but you could definitely keep using it for a couple years if you want.

title: 7 year old can do this with no problems!
text: So the box says 18+, which is crazy, because even though I got it for myself to do, my 7 year old did a large section herself with no problems. There are 6 bases that all connect in the end, so each section is not very large, which made it easy for her to follow the pattern. It took about 3 hours to complete (1/2 hour per base). It was enjoyable and fun to put together.

title: Awesome but freight train is more fun!
text: My 6 and 7 year old love this train. It was a relatively fast build for the price, about 3.5 hours. It is so fun and fast, and is a lot of fun to set up with and play with the Lego Station too. The only thing is, we like the freight train better. The freight train is more interactive and has more variety in the train cars. If you are trying to decide between the two, I'd recommend that one!

title: Fun gift for artistic ages 7 and up
text: Even though this says ages 10 and up, if you have an artistic kid or kid that needs a gift, 7 and up seems like the perfect age! Fun gift that takes some focus and concentration and will provide a few hours of entertainment.

title: Fun but a quick build for the price
text: This set is okay, but my 7 year old put it together in about 1.5 hours. For $40, that's a quick build, and there really aren't any phenomenal details, mini figs, or accessories that add value. For example, if it was a similarly sized Star Wars set that had a couple minifigs my kids were eyeing, it would make it a better value to us, but everything about this set is relatively generic. Or if you are willing to pay a bit more for the new Friends space set, or the accessory packed Horse trailer set, those are both more unique and have a lot of details that enable more play with the end product. This was still fun for my daughter, because all Legos are, but I don't see a ton of value in this set myself and would recommend finding a different Lego set.

title: Great for ages 5 and up
text: My 6 and 7 year old love this train, but ages 5 and up could easily enjoy it (even though the box says 7+). They had it put together in a a few hours and we all love the different things to do with this set. This train is definitely more interesting and interactive than the passenger train!! We really love the auto carrier with the car, and the gas pump too! Of course having more tracks would be more fun, so we will probably add more tracks soon. We also got the train station and that is a really fun addition as well. You could clearly spend $350 making a really awesome set up if you were so inclined, but even without any additions, this freight train is awesome and I'd recommend it over the passenger train since there is more to play with here!

title: Fun for 7 year old daughter
text: My 7 year old really enjoyed this set! It was about a 3.5 hour build for her, which isn't super long considering the price, but the thing we really love about all the Friends sets are the attention to detail and accessories that make it ideal for lots of play after the set is built. The space school building is just alright, but she loved the rocket and the space simulator. This set also prompted lots of questions and encouraged us to research space exploration and learn more about science, which was great.

title: Larger and more detailed than the pictures show
text: When I first looked at the pictures, this set looked fun but pricey for what I thought it involved. It turned out to be way bigger and more detailed in the best way possible. It actually is pretty huge, and it took my 7 year old about 4 hours to build. The camper is really fun and really designed for actual play after building. Lego Friends in general is really designed for kids who want to play with the end build and always provides a ton of accessories (like brushes for the horses, trophies for after their competitions, water hoses, buckets and a spray bottle for grooming, etc). Our favorite part is the top of the trailer where the puppy can sleep. :)

title: Fun for 7 year old
text: My 7 year old daughter has loved Lego dots for the past couple years, and they are perfect for her artistic/creative personality. She loves being able to create fun patterns with the dots and change up the appearance from time to time. My only complaint is that they can end up EVERYWHERE in our house, and they are smaller and there are more than the typical Lego pieces that get scattered, simply because they are tiny. I wouldn't give a Dots set as a gift to any kid, but for ones that love attention to detail and are more creative, this would be perfect.

title: Everything we were hoping for
text: We have been eyeing the Lego train and station for awhile now for our builders, ages 6 and 7. They love it. They had no problems with assembly, and the train is super fun. The only downside for me is that it is really meant to keep out and set up, and it is not as easy to put away as some other sets. My kids love destroying their Lego sets and building completely new things with the pieces from time to time, but the Trains are the one line where I feel like they really need to stay together, so I'm holding my breath for this awesome City to stay together!

title: Fun for my 7 year old
text: My 7 year old daughter has loved Lego dots for the past couple years, and they are perfect for her artistic/creative personality. She loves being able to create fun patterns with the dots and change up the appearance from time to time. My only complaint is that they can end up EVERYWHERE in our house, and they are smaller and there are more than the typical Lego pieces that get scattered, simply because they are tiny. I wouldn't give a Dots set as a gift to any kid, but for ones that love attention to detail and are more creative, this would be perfect.

title: A 2 hour build for my 6 year old
text: This set is a great size for a gift, best suited for 4-6 year olds. It's pretty simple and even the littlest builders should be able to complete it with a bit of help. My 6 year old did it in just under 2 hours. We love the detail and especially the Lego bunny!!

title: “Can you give it 5 stars?” -my 7 year old
text: This was about a 1.5 hour build for my 7 year old. She hasn't seen Ninjago, but picked this set over all of the larger Lego Friends sets I offered her. She likes that the wings can pivot back and forth by sliding the mid section of the jet. Overall a cool set at a good price point, even if you aren't a Ninjago fan.

title: Better than the double loop stunt arena
text: This set is a quick build and fun for actually playing with. My 6 and 7 year old had it together quickly, about an hour, and they could actually do the stunt (as opposed to the double loop stunt arena which was extremely frustrating and too hard to get the bikes around the loops). This would make a great, more unique gift for kids. My kids ultimately prefer the traditional building focused legos over the Stuntz line though.

title: Awesome attention to detail
text: My 7 year old daughter typically would prefer Star Wars, Technic or even Ninjago Legos over the Friends line, but she loves this particular set. There are so many small fun details - an air hockey machine, a soda vending machine, lockers for storing the bag, dance, dance revolution, the bowling lane, and more. The price of Lego sets (like everything else) has seemed to go up a lot with their latest release of sets this August, but it really feels like the value is still high for this particular set and that is more reasonably priced than others. This was about a 3 hour build for her.

title: A 5 hour build for my 6 year old
text: This new Ninjago car is pretty cool. It comes with 7 minifigures, a large car, and my son's favorite feature is a little drone that stores in the back of the car that you can pull out and fly around. He has never seen Ninjago, but he still really enjoyed this set. It took him about 5 hours to build it, which is a pretty good cost-to-time value for us when compared to other recent lego sets he has built.

title: So much fun for my 3 year old!
text: My 3 year (+1 month) old loves Legos and wants to be just like her older siblings, so the 4+ sets have been a perfect start for her. She was able to build this set in 3.5 hours (an hour per bag for the first three bags then 1/2 hour for the last small bag). It is so adorable with all of the animals, tractor, and barn. Also super weird, but it has Lego poop for the animals, which my kids think is hilarious. This would be an amazing gift for 3-5 year olds!

title: Good gift idea or add on for existing Friends set up
text: This set is pretty small, so obviously not a long or the most interesting build, but fun for actually playing with. It took my 7 year old about 20 min to set up. We like the mirror in the side of the boutique that the Friends can try on the lipstick and style their hair. It would be a good gift for 5-7 year olds!

title: Extremely hard to preform the stuntz
text:
[[VIDEOID:dc3dc1116d52d21155465514f1354fe6]] My 7 year old put this set together today in about 4 hours, and she really enjoyed building it. It looks really cool, but the stunts are really hard to do. The flywheel motorcycles are cool- you push the wheels hard against the floor once or twice to get it spinning, then you let it go (basically the opposite of pull back cars). But they are really hard to line up correctly and at the right speed to complete the loops. They are really easy to get them going too fast, and you have to let go of them quickly to keep the wheels inertia, so you can't spend much time lining it up well. And if you take your time to line it up and do it slowly, it doesn't have enough momentum. Also look at the picture of the monster truck… the motorcycle is supposed to go up the ramp and jump through the flames, but it has to be lined up so perfectly and the start of the ramp is hardly any bigger than the motorcycle.
So individually, the pieces of the set are all pretty cool, but it's really hard (even for the adults in my house) to use them together to do the stunts.

title: More durable than expected!
text: My 6 year old son has been in to Bakugan for the past 1.5 years. Originally, he needed a bit of help folding them, but he mastered each in a couple months. I first thought they were a bit frail and expected them to break quickly, but 1.5 years later and most have withstood tons of folding and even being chucked across rooms on a regular basis. They seem a bit expensive, but I've been pleased with how they've held up! My son loves this new set!!

title: More durable than expected!
text: My 6 year old son has been in to Bakugan for the past 1.5 years. Originally, he needed a bit of help folding them, but he mastered each in a couple months. I first thought they were a bit frail and expected them to break quickly, but 1.5 years later and most have withstood tons of folding and even being chucked across rooms on a regular basis. They seem a bit expensive, but I've been pleased with how they've held up! My son loves this new one!!

title: More durable than expected!
text: My 6 year old son has been in to Bakugan for the past 1.5 years. Originally, he needed a bit of help folding them, but he mastered each in a couple months. I first thought they were a bit frail and expected them to break quickly, but 1.5 years later and most have withstood tons of folding and even being chucked across rooms on a regular basis. They seem a bit expensive, but I've been pleased with how they've held up! My son loves this new set!!

title: More durable than I expected
text: My 6 year old son has been in to Bakugan for the past 1.5 years. Originally, he needed a bit of help folding them, but he mastered each in a couple months. I first thought they were a bit frail and expected them to break quickly, but 1.5 years later and most have withstood tons of folding and even being chucked across rooms on a regular basis. They seem a bit expensive, but I've been pleased with how they've held up! My son loves this new one!!

title: Pokémon stickers are great! The letters, eh….
text: I gave this set to my 6 year old who loves Pokémon and he was super excited. At first, I thought he probably wouldn't even finish one because the diamonds are tiny!!! We have done other gem art in the past with bigger diamonds/gems, and even some that had the size but the pattern was in rows, making it easier overall. These are tiny and there isn't any blank space on the sticker, so the diamonds really need to be placed in the exact right spot. This is better suited for kids that are a little older, probably 8-12 would be great. My 6 old has a lot of focus so did finish Charmander in one day after working on him for about 3 hours!! The time to cost value us definitely high. :) The letter stickers however will probably never be completed as my kids have no interest in those!

title: I'll say it again— overpriced
text: Yikes, this set is tiny for $90. My 6 year old lego fan loves it, of course, but this was about a 3 hour build for him, which is outrageous for $90.  On average, we typically pay about $20 per hour of build time if the sets are within a few years of his age, so any of the 5+ to 8+ sets. So going off that, this set is about 50% more expensive than virtually every Star Wars set we've bought.

title: Would be a perfect gift for a 3-5 year old!
text: My daughter and I have played pretend campfire with her Care Bears since she was 2.5 and we put marshmallows on kabob sticks. This totally elevates our pretend time. The set is awesome and well made, I just wish it came with more skewers/marshmallows. It would be a great gift for a 3 or 4 year old that likes to play pretend!

title: Don't break easily like the off brand kind do
text: My daughter has been in to Rainbow loom for a few years and used the original Rainbow loom brand and also huge off brand value sets from Amazon. These ones really do work better. There is nothing more disappointing than her getting it all laid out on the loom then having a band snap. This set has a ton of bands and is the about the same size and price as the off brand one we got, the off brand one just came with a case and some charms/keychains. I'd recommend skipping that and going with these higher quality bands.

title: Lots of textures to chew!
text: My babies always love chewing on textured things and it's great they can practice stacking as well.

title: Too wobbly for my Lego pro
text: My 6 year old has been very in to Legos for the past 2 years and can do sets well above his age range unassisted. These looked like a fun alternative to engage similar skills, but they ended up being a disappointment. He was getting pretty annoyed with the general lack of stability and the wobbly nature of these. If you push areas too hard, it often affected other parts of the structure and caused them to bend or become unstable. He was able to build a couple of the creatures himself, but had no interest in playing with them anymore after they were built and did not attempt anything of his own design. We will stick with Legos, which he will play with for hours and hours.

title: Really hate the star beads
text: My kids love creating with aquabeads so have tried many different sets. Our favorite is the beginner studio because it comes with a nice variety of beads, a storage container and tray, and a bead pen to help place beads (and had been around $16 the few times I purchased it). This is only a refill - no tray or storage container included, so you need to have those before purchasing this. As far as refills go, it's ok, but we have so many issues with the star beads every single time we use them, and we have mastered the art of spraying and flipping pretty well. The star beads often don't sit exactly right and if they don't make good contact when they're sprayed, they will fall off. And it's hard, if not impossible, to fix after they've been sprayed and flipped. So we prefer the Mega Bead set for the value, included case, and lack of star beads.

title: A refill pack in a bad container
text: This is truly a refill pack - you need to have some sort of storage container and tray to actually use the aquabeads (we love the beginners studio as a starter because it comes with the pen as well). This set gives a lot of colors and a lot of aquabeads, although I personally don't like the star beads AT ALL. They are constantly falling off/not expanding and sticking correctly to my kids' designs, and they make us all frustrated. I wish these were all standard spherical aquabeads. Also the container of pretty annoying. A cardboard box would've been better and more compact, instead of trying to shove the packs into the weird cube case that splits completely in half. I have purchased the Mega Bead set in the past and that is currently $16 for 2400 beads, comes with a nice tray and has no star beads. I'd definitely recommend that one over this.

title: Really cute, maybe a bit large
text: I love this toy with all of the sensory features. Good mix of things to crinkle and pet. :) Tge only think is it is pretty big - I wouldn't want it laying on top of a 6-9 month old in a car seat. It's size makes it best for 12-18 month olds.

title: 5 year old loves this
text: My 5 year old is excited to finally have this arena. So now instead of just throwing them on our floor, he can throw them on the arena, haha. He's still a little young to understand all of the rules about battling and the card values and such, but he loves this nonetheless. Bakugans are all the rage in his kindergarten class.

title: 5 year old loves it
text: Easy enough for my 5 year old to assemble himself. He loves this track!

title: Fun twist with Harry Potter theme
text: Love the original Sequence but love this one as well as a Harry Potter fan.

title: My kids 2-6 LOVE these drill sets
text: My kids are 2, 5 and 6, and they have been playing with different Educational Insights drills/bolts for the past two years and still love them. We have the classic board with the patterns, the design and drill garden and the dump truck, and they are all awesome. This one is awesome as well! It is simple enough that my 2.5 year old can do it herself, but my older kids still enjoy it too, and they spend a good 30 -60 minutes playing with them when we pull them out. I love how they are so simple but encourage fine motor skills and also a bit of STEM with the patterns and creativity involved. I think this would also make a great gift!!

title: Fun but not so sure what target age is for these
text: Magnatiles have been a most used and loved toy in our house for several years so we were excited to try these. I love them for their quality and the way they encourage creative play. These are fine, but ultimately my kids really prefer the plain, colored magnatiles. They weren't really a hit with either my toddler who likes the Hungry Caterpillar pillar book but wasn't big enough to paint them herself, and they weren't really enjoyed much either by my 6 year old who was big enough to paint them, but didn't care about the finished product. I'm still not sure what age this would be a most appropriate gift for…

title: Overpriced and very difficult to change the clothes
text: I like these dolls and they are cute, but they are overpriced in my opinion. They are very rubbery/flexible dolls and I'm not super impressed with the quality of them. Also due to the rubbery/silicon feel of the doll and the outfits, and also because they are very tiny with tiny little limbs, they are very hard to change the outfits. My 5.5 year old could barely get the skirt changed and gave up on changing the top of the dress. It took me about 2 minutes to change one of the dolls. Also they don't all stand up by themselves. Most of the dolls with the long dresses can stand/rest on their dress, but we couldn't get Pocahontas, Moana, and Jasmine to stand up unassisted. If you have an older child (maybe 6-7?) who can change these on their own, or a little one who really loves princesses and is fine without changing them much, these are still cute dolls that will be fun to play with. I just personally wouldn't want to pay more than $35 or so for this set (and be stuck constantly changing them for my child!)

title: Cute but lost its charm quickly
text: I gave this LuLu Achoo to my 2.5 year old daughter who loves baby dolls, and she loved it immensely for about 3 days. And now another week has gone by and she hasn't picked her up. LuLu is well built and a quality doll. She is interactive and you can take her temperature and feed her a bottle or a spoon for pretend medicine. She does not say any real words. She says “LuLu Achoo” and also makes baby noises. At one point my 2.5 year old said “Why [does she] say ‘ba ba ba‘?“ because LuLu primarily babbles baby nonsense noises. She is fun for small periods of time, but at the end of the day, she is a hard doll and not cuddly or cozy. I briefly searched for additional Baby Alive outfits to buy to increase her appeal/things to do with her, but I didn't find anything. So 9 times out of 10 my toddler is going to pick her simple, soft, changeable Corolle or Bitty baby. Which leads me to conclude, if this doll was only $20 and you could get a few hours of fun out of her here and there, I'd recommend trying her. But at $50, I would personally pass on this.

title: 6 Year Old daughter loves this
text: My 6 year old daughter has never even seen Monkie Kid…. But she saw this both online and in the Amazon toy catalogue and thought it looked super cool, and it doesn't disappoint in real life. I'm sure seeing the show would enhance the experience, but even without knowing anything about it, we like this set. She is pretty familiar with legos and this was about a 3 hour build for her.

title: Easy to use and shoot accurately (for a nerf gun)
text: This is a solid feeling nerf gun compared to the handful of others we have at home. All the parts move freely and smoothly. Also, it doesn't jam very often. I think this is a well designed toy. The 6 shot capacity is small, but that makes reloading quicker. My 5 year old has no problems using this nerf gun.

title: Exactly how I remember mine from the 90's
text: This is exactly how I remember mine from my childhood, even down to the color of the hook and the cylindrical yarn bundles!! The quality of the hook and canvas are the same too. I am so excited for my 6 year old to do it. She loves rainbow loom so I think this is a complimentary activity that will be fun and she is also old enough to do herself. It is great the yarn colors are printed on the canvas so that you don't need to follow a paper pattern. A great craft that will last many hours!

title: Not a “Big” Puzzle
text: This is a great quality puzzle, but I wouldn't call it big. We enjoy the Melissa and Doug giant floor puzzles and the Learning Journey big puzzles, and those are about twice the size of this puzzle. This one is nice, bright, sturdy and well cut, but for a child's puzzle I'd call it regular to medium sized, not big. We prefer the bigger ones!

title: Exactly how I remember mine from the 90's
text: This is exactly how I remember mine from my childhood, even down to the color of the hook and the cylindrical yarn bundles!! The quality of the hook and canvas are the same too. I am so excited for my 6 year old to do it. She loves rainbow loom so I think this is a complimentary activity that will be fun and she is also old enough to do herself. It is great the yarn colors are printed on the canvas so that you don't need to follow a paper pattern. A great craft that will last many hours!

title: Great for 2 - 6 year olds!
text: My kids are aged 2-6 and they all love these. We have enjoyed water wows for the past 4 years and these connect the dots are a fun new addition. Each page has 25 dots to connect to outline the picture and each page has the typical find and seek activities to give a little something extra to do after coloring the picture. Great for traveling or on the go activities!

title: Go with plain colored magnatiles!!
text: Alright these are cool because they are magnatiles. They stick flawlessly. They withstand hours and hours and hours of play, being kicked across the floor non stop and being stepped and sat on repeatedly. They are one of my kids most played with toys (ages 2,5,6) There is no question that they are worth the cost for my kids who love them to death. I'm not overly sold on the theme though. While cute, they are limited in how many times you can rearrange them, and then they throw off the aesthetics when tossed in with all of our colored sets. My kids were only interested in the cat in the hat storyline for a short period, then I was just bothered with them not matching, haha. I definitely recommend buying kids magnatiles for the creative, open ended play they provide, I would just recommend buying the biggest solid set you can. Or the glow in the dark ones are cool if you are looking for a small set. Really I wouldn't get these unless you just are an avid Dr Seuss fan.

title: Great for traveling, for kids ages 2-6
text: My kids, ages 2, 5 and 6, took these with us on vacation. It occupied them for hours and was a great activity for the times we had to sit around the hotel. There was no mess and they could reuse and reposition the stickers over and over. The quality is great, like all Melissa and Doug, and it will withstand many hours of play.

title: Enjoyed by 2, 5, and 6 year olds
text: My kids, 2, 5, and 6, have each been enjoying having their own book since this comes as a 3 pack! They have colored/scratched them for more than 2-3 hours, and there is still more pages to complete in their book. It is pretty messy, leaving big black chunks all over the floor or table, but that is consistent for all scratch art.

title: Fun for my 2, 5 and 6 year old
text: My kids have enjoyed playing with this for 20-30 min at a time. It normally ends with them coloring the entire surface then losing interest while it takes 10 min to dry. For less saturated sections, like when they use the stamper or color lightly, it sometimes only takes 5 minutes for it to dry and be ready to color again. It comes with a great amount and variety of accessories like the stamps and stencils and 4 pens, all of which are added bonuses over some other similar mats I've seen on Amazon. I debated between 3 and 4 stars since my kids do like it, I just don't see a ton of long term use since it is already showing wear after a few uses. If you have any Melissa and Doug Water Wows, you can probably picture how it starts to wear out with normal use pretty quickly. So overall fun but maybe not the best cost to entertaining-kids-for-a-long-time value.

title: Great for 2-5 year olds
text: My kids have enjoyed color wonder since they were 2, and they still enjoy it now at 5 and 6. We have never had issues with markers drying out and we love that there is no mess on their hands or the table. This is the first glitter one we have tried and it is pretty cute. Everything looks metallic! We love it!

title: Would be better offered as 12 colors for cheaper
text: I love the idea of these markers. It is great to have a variety of actual skin colored markers. However there are about 5 that barely show up on white paper, there are a couple very pink options that don't seem very realistic, and there are many that are extremely close in color to others. I feel this would be way better as a cheaper 8-12 pack and not a 24 pack. So great idea and I love to have some of these options, I just don't see my kids getting full use out of the entire box.

title: Too large for traveling
text: These are cute and fun, typical great M&D quality, but while I hoped to bring them on a road trip, they are the opposite of compact. It does all house nicely in the large cardboard box it comes in, but it is pretty bulky and doesn't fit in my toddlers backpack. I wouldn't recommend them for traveling.

title: Too large for traveling
text: These are cute and fun, typical great M&D quality, but while I hoped to bring them on a road trip, they are the opposite of compact. It does all house nicely in the large cardboard box it comes in, but it is pretty bulky and doesn't fit in my toddlers backpack. I wouldn't recommend them for traveling.

title: Worth $6-$7, fun add on to existing aquabeads
text: If you don't already have any aquabeads, don't get this set. (I recommend the Beginners Studio with 840 beads, plus a storage container, a layout tray, and a bead pen that I got on Amazon for $7.49 once and $14.99 a different time) If you already have all of the storage stuff/layout tray/etc and you are familiar with aquabeads, this set is fine and an ok addition, but considering that it is just straight up 600 beads and a couple pattern cards, I would only want to pay $6 or $7 for it myself.

title: Big enough for my 2, 4 and 6 year old
text: I bought the Easy playhouse garage for my kids for Christmas and they loved it, but I never intended it would be used for more than a few months. They colored it, played in it a few hours a week, and after 4 months it was time for it to go. It wasn't completely trashed, just losing its shape and height, and some of the doors and windows bent out of shape. I think they got their $30 of use from it and I'm thrilled to now try this dinosaur one which is identical except for the picture to color! I'd definitely recommend the extra large fat Crayola crayons for the easiest coloring!

title: Easy enough for 4 year old!
text: This set is easy enough for my 4 year olds to connect and launch his hot wheels by himself. You really need to gave other track/sets to make it fun since this is pretty small, but it's a great add on for any hot wheels lover.

title: Fun variety set for gifts
text: My 4 and 6 year old have been enjoying the Bic coloring for the past year, using the colored pencils, markers and crayons regularly. The crayons are cool because they don't break and the colors are vivid. The markers have also worked well for a full year without drying out. Overall we have been impressed by the quality of Bic coloring!

title: 4.5 year old not a fan of this letter set
text: We have played with the play foam pals and enjoyed those, this set was a bit disappointing though. My son is 4.5 and knows his letters already but I thought this may be fun for him. He made a few letters for awhile, but they didn't have much distinction and all looked pretty blobby. I showed him how to roll it out in to long cylinders and piece them together, but he really just wanted to play with the foam without the cards. Also our set is missing a card, we didn't get the Y/Z card. Also, this is definitely lacking for long term storage. The foam comes in a flimsy plastic tray that I guess you are supposed to reuse, but it's not durable or nice. Overall we enjoy play foam, but much prefer the Pals that come in hard plastic domes.

title: Stick well
text: Stickers stick well, *almost* too well. We put them on our clothes and they were a little tricky to get off but they came off cleanly with patience. We used them on paper too and they stick well!

title: My 4 year old loves these
text: My 4 year olds loves these and has learned how to fold them all with one practice.

title: Better than Secrets of the Dragons
text:
My 4 and 5 year old have been playing both Osmo math wizards for the past month, and this one is far superior to the Secrets of the Dragons set. This set, on its easiest level (there are 3), was a good challenge for my 4 year old to practice addition. The other set, which I gave 2 stars, was so simple that my 4 year old had mastered the one skill of measuring in about 10 minutes. Both of the Osmo Math wizard games are pretty simple in the fact that they don't have a lot of variety and you kind of just do the same problems over and over. But whereas the repetitiveness of this game teaching addition is alright for reinforcing the skill, the repetitiveness of measuring dragons in the Secrets of Dragons gets boring quickly and is unnecessary.
I still prefer all of the creative Osmos over this (like Monster and Super Studio), but my kids do enjoy this.

title: Ages 4-6
text: This Osmo game is beautifully built and packaged and has high quality pieces and food tokens. However after being very impressed with the game design of the Creative monster game and the two super studios we have, I can not say the same for this game design. It is so simple without much variation on things to do within the game. You basically open the beautiful game board/book it comes with, measure dragons with a ruler, then feed the dragons by lining up physical food tokens. That's it. My 4 year old can definitely do this. And I kept expecting my almost 6 year old to say she was bored and done before I turned it off. I guess if it was cheaper overall then maybe I wouldn't have been surprised by it, but for the price it doesn't seem like the value is there. I can teach my kids to measure and estimate lengths with tokens in about 10 minutes, I don't need a $60 game to help.... I definitely would not purchase this for a 7 or 8 year old. I think they'd be very bored quickly.

title: Quality play food
text: My kids, 4 and 5, love the Learning Resources play food for our play kitchen! The pieces are colorful and a really nice, thick, quality plastic. It's well made and a fun pasta set!

title: Really helpful but way overpriced
text: [[VIDEOID:47945c5e19f48704e8af3c22dd2227e2]] This bead pen is really helpful to pick the beads up out of the container and set them down in the general area on the board, or to clean up a board after it has been mistakenly knocked with an arm and needs to be started over. My 5 year old likes using it a lot. But I paid $8.50 for it and it's definitely worth about $3. On the manufacturers website the list price is $3.99 if you want a few and it may be worth it to pay the shipping cost. I wanted to get my daughter a pen to go with the Frozen set since it didn't come with it, so I purchased this. But I also at the same time bought my son the Aquabeads Beginners Studio for $14.99, and that came with its own pen. I should have just bought 2 of the Beginner Studios. I would recommend just buying a whole set that comes with a pen if you want one—it would definitely be worth paying the extra $6.50 to get way more beads and an extra tray to use while your first project is drying.

title: Great quality and fun design
text: I could tell when I first picked up the box that this is a quality product. The box is very sturdy and thick. The puzzle pieces are cut well and interlock as expected. I like how it includes a bag for the pieces and a poster as well for reference. Overall I'm very pleased!

title: Vivid, break resistant crayons for older kids
text: The Bic crayons are pretty cool! My artsy 5 year enjoys using them and has yet to break one. I bent one pretty hard without it breaking as well. The colors are vivid and write well. The long shape of them probably makes them more idea for older kids and not for toddlers since it may be too much to handle, but that's our only potential concern.

title: Fun but flimsy
text: We love the concept for the game, but the quality could be way better. It may break quickly, but it's fun for now!

title: Plain packaging, no launcher
text: I have no prior experience with Beyblades, but my kindergartner has seen them at school and talks about how cool they are. First, these come in a plain, non labeled brown box, so they wouldn't make a very exciting gift. Second, there is no launcher so you need to have an existing set up (launcher, arena). They look cool and will be a great size for my daughters stocking (once I find the other pieces I need for her to actually play with them!)

title: Mess free fun!
text: My kids and I love playing with this! The tools and idea booklet are helpful for us to create different projects. I'd recommend starting with the sculpting studio and then adding on the squish deluxe or rainbow pack later when you run out. The projects take a day to dry and then they are nice, foam-y/squishy material! And the absolute best part—no mess unlike sculpting sand or play doh!

title: Hard to write with
text: I'm sure these have a very specific purpose for an art project somewhere, but I personally won't be using them often, if at all. The tip is very, very soft and flexible, making it very hard to write neatly with. The purple, gold and silver are nice colors, I personally feel the blue is too silver-y and the pink is practically red. They did wash off my hands ok after I got a bit on them, so that was good. Also note there is no green marker included (although some of the pictures in the listing show green).

title: Other Bic markers are better!
text:
My daughter colors a lot, and we have been testing the various new Bic markers a lot! These are our least favorite.
First, they really aren't that much bigger of an easy grip. The barrel is the same size as the Child's First ultra washable Bics and the Brush tip Bics, it's only slightly larger than the Ultra Washable Medium markers. Also the box for these is really flimsy and was already coming open at the bottom when we received them. Most importantly, the tip is not great for large areas of coloring (like classic Crayola markers) or for details. My 5 year old was really impressed with the Medium markers and loved the detailing she was able to do with the fine tip on those. She also loves the brush tip line. Those have been great for both drawings and for practicing writing and numbers.
If you are looking for good first markers, I'd stick with Crayola. If you want something for more detail, give the Medium or Brush Tip Bics a try.

title: Super cute but kinda cheap- M&D is higher quality
text: Like most Disney Jr products I've had, this is really adorable and cute and my toddler loves it, but it's also pretty cheaply made. Since it's not too expensive it's not necessarily a bad value, it's just something to note. It comes in a cute box that would be great for gifting for a birthday, but I probably wouldn't give it to a child older than 3. My older kids (4 and 5) have the Melissa and Doug Cleaning Caddy and that is much higher quality and better for older kids!

title: My 4 year old is obsessed
text: My 4 year old is obsessed with this toy. So obsessed I've had to to take it away because he won't share with his siblings. He always loves vehicles and cars, but this is over the top fun for him with the drill and removable wheels. He loves putting the extra bolts plus any other small toys in the back to push/carry them around the house. The drill is easy for him to use by himself. I wish there was more to put together and take apart on the truck, but he loves it just how it is.

title: Fun for my 4 and 5 year old
text: We previously bought the Educational Insights Design and Drill peg board that comes with large cards and you can replicate the pattern on the board, or design your own picture with pegs. We love that one and we love this one and the recycling truck one too! While this flower one is cuter and more unique, I do feel that the other one encourages more complex thinking to replicate the patterns. My 5 year old is probably on the upper age range for this flower one, but I do see her using the peg board one for longer. Overall, they are all a great quality and very much enjoyed by my kids, but I would probably just go with the peg board if I was only going to recommend one!

title: Awesome, from a loyal Crayola user
text: We have always stuck with the Crayola brand we trust for the past 5 years, but these are really just as fantastic, although different. This cap is easier to get off and on - no more accidentally leaving caps only partially on. The tip is also smaller on this particular Bic marker (than a standard Crayola), but I'm seeing all different tip varieties from Bic available! The colors are bright and vibrant and they wash off skin about the same as Crayola. The large box is fun to set out and allow my kids to use the same color at the same time and pretend we are in an art studio.

title: TOO Hard, buy Sneaky Snacky instead
text:
The quality of this game is great. The cardboard pieces are thick, the box is sturdy, the buttons are nice. But it's just too hard and frustrating. Three of the nine options on the spinner are negative - either give a button to the player on your right, put one button back, or put ALL buttons back. This makes the game way too frustrating. I started playing this with my 4 and 5 year old and we quickly each had 2-3 of the 5 needed buttons, but for the next 15 minutes we kept spinning negative results enough to keep emptying our Pete boards and staying somewhere between 0-3 buttons. My 4 year was finally lucky enough to finish the game and I begrudgingly tried one more round to see if the first was a fluke. It went very similarly with my kids being frustrated that they often would get up to 2-3 buttons then have to put them all back, over and over for a long 15 minutes.
We also have The Sneaky Snacky Squirrel by this company. It's very similar in working fine motor skills and a great quality, and it is not frustrating at all!! Of the 10 spinner options for that game, only 2 are negative causing you to put acorns back. And my kids actually enjoy it. That one is SO MUCH BETTER!!! I would definitely avoid this Pete the Cat one!

title: 15 month enjoys them
text: As an adult, I find these avocados boring. They open and that's pretty much it. The pit is secured to one of the sides so that doesn't even come out. Each pit has two different emoji faces on it, one per each side, and you can spin the pit around. I would probably have given these two stars, except my 15 month old really seems to enjoy carrying them around the house and opening them. She has even learned the word avocado because of them. There really isn't much to do with these, (I'll probably add them to our play kitchen) but this is just another example that kids will randomly choose their favorite toys. :)

title: Great for 15 months +
text: Although this toy recommends 2 and up, it can easily be enjoyed by 1 year olds. My 15 month old can put the pieces on and off the antlers and can place them in the moose body storage and take them out too. She doesn't get the color sorting yet, but she will be able to enjoy this toy for a good year! The toy is a great quality and we love the storage space inside the moose for easy clean up.

title: My 15 month old enjoys this
text: All 3 of my kids have enjoyed playing with this, ages 15 months, 4 and 5. My 15 month old can remove the shapes from the holes herself without difficulty but needs some help putting them back in the holes since the peg is only on one side of the shape. She likes to put all of the pieces inside the fish body too and dump them out. My 4 and 5 year old love scattering pieces to things all over the house, so they enjoy it too. :)

title: Original (non scratch art) is better!
text: I was excited for the idea of using this on scratch art paper since I loved the original as a kid. While it is a cool idea, it ends up being kind of a novelty and just doesn't work quite as well / it doesn't include as many pieces as just buying a plain set. It is fun and my 5 year old daughter and I like it, but I'd recommend the original set!

title: Super cute and fun for my 1 year old
text: This bath toy is super cute, colorful and fun for my 1 year old! Like all of the other Munchkin bath toys we own, the quality is great too.

title: So simple it didn't excite my 4 and 5 year old for long
text: I played this with my 4 and 5 year old for about 15 minutes before we all lost interest. The set up and objective are so simple that it wasnt very engaging to us. Just laying out the noodles then taking turns removing them was not very interesting. It was like a much, much more low key version of Jenga. It's a fine game, but I wouldn't want to spend money on it myself because I don't see us getting much use out of it!

title: Unique design with fun colors
text: These are not traditional puzzle pieces, and there are shapes that go with the theme. For example, the sea puzzle has puzzle pieces shaped like a dolphin, a star, and a whale. However, this makes it a little more difficult for everything to fit together. It might be tricky for younger kids. My 3 and 5 year olds are pretty good with puzzles, but they needed some help with these.

title: Fun art project
text: My 3 and 5 year olds love these wax sticks. We opened a few packages since there are only 8 sticks in each package, and the kids had no problems twisting the sticks together or making shapes. They held their shapes well and were easy to take apart and make something different. I highly recommend these.

title: Works perfectly but has a strong chemical smell
text: These shoot just like the name brand darts, and you can get a lot more bang for your buck. The tips are actually softer than the name brand, so they might be more kid friendly (if your kids complain like mine when they get hit... and before you judge, they think it is funny to shoot me at point blank range, so they are the ones asking for it). Also, the tips were also glued on tight, so no issues there.  However, they have a strong pvc cement odor when first opened up.

title: Cute and well made
text: These scissors are cute and well made. The quality is very good and they are comfortable for my 5 year old. She loves the fun colors and design!

title: Another great track add on
text: This kicker set is another great add on to our existing track. Like all of the hot wheels loops, not every hot wheel will work on it due to their weight, but this works well with the right cars.

title: Great for my 3 year old
text: My 3 year old can assemble this track by himself. He also can fold it up to put it in a plastic container. It does come with some normal connections- they are not all foldable- but it works for our purposes. He enjoys the track; I like that he can clean up easily!

title: Great minion set!
text: I got these for my 4 year old who loves minions. The 6 cars came all packaged together in a fun box. They are exactly what we expected and similar to all other hot wheels size and quality.

title: Lots of fun and mid level quality
text: These are super fun, my 3 and 5 year old enjoy them and can work them themselves. There is nothing bad to say about the quality, but nothing overwhelming about it either. They were slightly smaller than I was expecting, which ended up being good for my young kids but there are bigger options that may be more fun for older kids. The paint is starting to chip a bit, but we are leaving them outside and in the sun.

title: Entertaining to 11 month old
text: My 11 month old enjoys this toy, especially the big bubble that lights up and the poms float around in. It tends to keep her interest for 5-10 minutes, which isn't very long in general, but she loses interest quickly in most toys. It is pretty sturdy and well made. I love how it isn't obnoxiously loud. The volume is pretty quiet, which is rare and amazing among toys. Overall we like it a lot!

title: Simple but fun addition to existing set up
text: These are great for my 8 year olds track. He is able to add these easily and he enjoys them.

title: Rusted within a month
text:
Update after one month: we used these as bath toys, and they got rusty on the insides where the magnet is already. They got wet in the bath about 3 times per week and then were air dried each time afterwards. I tossed these after I noticed the rust. I would not suggest them for water play!

My kids and I love magna tiles and Tegu blocks, so we were excited to give these a try. They are cute and my kids (3 & 5) enjoyed taking them in the tub, but after the first day of play they've been forgotten. Not only is the size of the set small and limiting, but really the shapes of the blocks limit the things that can be built too. The toy is ok, just not something we will keep coming back to over and over, and for the high price, I wouldn't recommend them. Check out Tegu!

title: Another quality Thomas train
text: My 3 year old loves all of the Thomas trains. They get played with almost daily and still look close to new. The quality is great and he loves the different characters, including this Ryan! They are a great addition to any train set.

title: Fun addition to existing track layout
text: This add on is a fun addition to our track we already have. It's fun to race the cars alongside each other!

title: Good quality for a decent price
text: This is a cute outfit for American Girl dolls or other 18” dolls. Adora is an Amazon exclusive brand that has good quality and the price is reasonable!

title: Great for 6-18 months, easy to clean
text: I got this for my 9 month old and she loves chewing on the animals. We dropped a few out of the car on to the road and I threw them in the washing machine to clean them. They are great for traveling, car rides and the diaper bag since you can easily store the animals in the pouch on the cover or on the hook and loop inside the book. It is colorful and fun!

title: Great fun
text: Great packs of cars for my 3 year old to play with! These cars are well made and pretty durable to withstand his playing.

title: 3 year old loves it
text: This is one of those toys I'm not particularly impressed with, but my 3 year old loves. To me it doesn't seem super interesting or to provide long term draw, but my son has played with it a lot over the past several weeks. Also the quality is nothing impressive, but he hasn't broken anything either. So overall it's more of a win than not. He loves Cars and I  think he will enjoy this for another year or so.

title: Colorful and vibrant fun
text: My 5 year old daughter saw this at the LEGO store and was immediately drawn to the colorful box and legos inside. She has only seen the original Trolls movie once, but still is really interested in this set. The pods hanging from the tree are really fun! The build is simple enough and a nice medium sized end product. She loves it.

title: Great for young builders
text: This set is perfect for my little LEGO fans. My 4 year old can assemble this since it is simple and not overly elaborate. The City line of Legos is our favorite since the sets seem most compatible for actual play and interaction between sets. This would be a great gift!

title: Tempted to steal this from my son
text: This is one of my favorites from the newly released 2020 Legos. I got it for my son, but I kinda want to build it myself. It looks extremely sharp and is super cool that it is functional in water. This would be an awesome gift!

title: Fun but a bit cheap
text: My 3 and 4 year old have really enjoyed this the past week. They love the Cars movies and have a set of Cars cars that goes well with this for them to race. The quality of the product is only so-so, with moving plastic pieces that don't line up the best. I'm often afraid my kids may snap something off the set because the quality isn't the best. But they love it (and connect it with the Cars tune up center for additional fun)

title: Fun and colorful for young builders
text: This would make a great gift for a 4 or 5 year old! My 4 year old daughter was very excited about this, even not having seen the movie. She loves all the Trolls sets!

title: Perfect compliment to LEGO city sets
text: I love how this hospital pairs nicely for playing with other LEGO City sets we have. It was simple enough for my 5 year old to build, and is a nice completed size.

title: Perfect for young builders
text: My 4 year old and I love the Lego City line because a lot of the sets seem easier for her and they all go well together to play with multiple sets at the same time. This race boat transporter is about a 1 hour build time for us, and is fun to play with when complete!

title: A small, inexpensive, fun set
text: This set is tiny, but fun. My 4 year old can do it by herself since it's not super big or complicated. It isn't the most impressive looking gift since it's small and whenever we get the small LEGO boxes, they always seem to arrive crushed, but it is a fun little set for Moana lovers.

title: Fun and priced well
text: We enjoy B Toys for their decent quality and price point, and this is another win. It's designed well to fully open (unlike the Green Toys boat) and I can clean it out periodically. I'm not sure what is lurking under the green toys boat we've had for several years! The purple octopus cup is fun for scooping and dripping water, and my kids like to open the green hatch on the boat and pour water in. Overall my 3 and 4 year old enjoy this a lot!

title: Only fun if adding to other trackmaster sets
text: This set is boring. I thought the whole point of Thomas Trackmaster sets is motorized trains that move by themselves (with batteries). This set does not come with a motorized train. It comes with a push train. (If we want to push our trains, we will build wooden tracks) Also, even if you bought a separate motorized trackmaster train, this still wouldn't be fun because it's a tiny straight line and doesn't have enough pieces to make a continuous loop. Only if you have other sets and you can add to them is this ok, but it's still not overly interesting. We have three different trackmaster sets that we enjoy and connect together and love, but this one is just not very interesting. Look for a different trackmaster set that can be looped and has a motorized train!

title: Awesome set for a 5 year old!!!
text: This set is awesome! It is simple enough for the youngest builders and is great for actually playing with when it's out together. We love the different cars and accessories. This would be a great gift for a 5-9 year old!!

title: Fun with lots of accessories
text: This Barbie comes with a lot of accessories that make playing more fun for my 4 year old! Her outfit is just ok, but she is fun to move and play pretend gymnastics with.

title: Simple for young builders
text: This set is perfect for my 5 year old. It is simple and small enough that she can put it together without much help. It took her around 30 minutes to build. It is also great because even though it is a smaller, less expensive set, it can still be played with (unlike some of the other options at this price point that really are best as add ons to other sets). This would make a great gift!

title: Tiny and fun
text: This is a simple, small set even the youngest LEGO builders, like my 4 year old, can manage. It's pretty small and is a good ad on to other LEGO City sets, but probably wouldn't be much fun on its own. The build time for my 4 year old was about 25 minutes.

title: Fun craft but this is for older kids
text:
My almost five year old loves art projects and is pretty self sufficient when it comes to crafts, but this glitter dot set required a lot of adult help. The dots were tricky for me to combine and roll out. They were also hard to cut out with the roller wheel because the layer of glitter dots would separate and tear easily. This was solved by kneading the dots thoroughly, but this made the colors run together (but not in a good way). However, the cookie cutter shapes were easier to cut out.

Overall, this is a good concept and it certainly cut down on the cleanup usually associated with glitter projects, but in reality the dots are difficult to work with. As long as you don't expect to be able to create anything close to the pictures on the box, this is a fun craft.

title: Huge set and lots of time to build (which is a good thing)
text:
This definitely is for 16+ as stated on the box. Maybe a younger experienced LEGO builder who is very patient could do this, but it really is designed for older LEGO enthusiasts. The details are amazing and the finished building is surprisingly tall. I also think it is cool how LEGO used plant based plastics for this set. They look and feel normal to me.

I highly recommend this set.

title: Fun but primarily plastic
text: My kids, 3 and 4, and I love Brio, and we have been collecting tracks, tunnels and bridges, and road for the past couple years. Probably everything so far has been 5 stars in our opinion, but for the price to wood ratio for this police station, it's just slightly less than perfect. The only wood involved is the dowels on the station, making this add on primarily plastic. My son will still absolutely love getting this for Christmas, but I'm not sure if the value is here on this one. The siren on the police car does add a touch of fun, but I recommend checking yours on arrival if it's a gift, because I actually had to replace the batteries (2 LR44) before it worked. Also it was delivered without an Amazon box, and simply had an address label on the Brio box, so I'm glad I saw it on the porch before my son did. Overall fun but pricey for just being plastic.

title: Adorable
text: My 3 year old will LOVE getting this for Christmas!! There are 36 adorable pictures of Mouse and friends, and they are a good quality too. The pieces are sturdy cardboard and the box is nice and generously sized too. Perfect for any If You Give A Mouse a Cookie lover.

title: Another great M&D product!
text: We love Melissa and Doug products for their quality and simplicity (no batteries required). This product is no exception. It's fun for my preschoolers and little artists! It would be great for road trips, doctors offices or anywhere you need a fun but contained activity.

title: Fun for preschoolers
text: My kids, 3 and 4, saw this at the Disney store and were asking for it because they love Toy Story. (Since this is pretty expensive, be aware you can purchase just the armor separately.) They both love this set. It is easy to assemble and get going and provides hours of fun. The blaster shoots the disks pretty far and is their favorite part of the set.

title: Great for preschoolers
text: My 3 and 4 year old are loving all of these new M&D puzzles! They have very thick, sturdy pieces that work well on carpet or hard floors. The picture is cute, it is a nice large size, and they come in a great sturdy box with a carrying handle. Another quality product from Melissa and Doug!

title: Great for preschoolers
text: My 3 and 4 year old are loving all of these new Natural Play M&D puzzles! They have very thick, sturdy pieces that work well on carpet or hard floors. The picture is cute, it is a nice large size, and they come in a great sturdy box with a carrying handle. Another quality product from Melissa and Doug!

title: Thick, sturdy design
text: My 3 and 4 year old are loving all of these new M&D puzzles! They have very thick, sturdy pieces that work well on carpet or hard floors. The picture is cute, it is a nice large size, and they come in a great sturdy box with a carrying handle. Another quality product from Melissa and Doug!

title: Fun game for 3+
text:
My newly 3 year old and I played this game and it was a good chance for him to practice number recognition and counting as he pushed the pig's head the number of times the hamburger said. The game is very simple and pretty short, maybe 5 minutes, so after we played 3 times he was able to do the puzzle which added a few additional minutes of fun. There are many other games we enjoy more and occupy us for longer, so while I wouldn't consider this game a must have or a top recommendation, it's a fun addition if your kids love games and you want more variety.
One thing to note, the die had a green, red, yellow and white sticker, but the hamburgers are green, red, yellow and purple. So any time we roll white, we actually have to pick purple.

title: Quality, thick foam book
text: This book is perfect for 0-2 year olds in the bath. There are four thick foam pages with a short rhyme for each animal. There is a turtle, whale, sea horse and octopus. The foam animals can pop out of the pages and be played with in the bath. Even my three year old was interested in this for a while, though it's probably ideal for 1 year olds! Overall, cute, fun and a quality product.

title: Love the 3 different options
text: We love building Legos by following the instructions, so this set is extra fun because we have more options to build. After finishing the first lay out, we can start over and have fun all over again with a different layout. This is a nice medium sized set for 6-10 year olds to build and keep engaged.

title: Great for even those who haven't seen Jurassic World
text: My kids and I haven't seen Jurassic World, but my kids are still thrilled by dinosaurs and the off-roader vehicle and trailer. This is a nice sized medium LEGO set that isn't too expensive yet still has things to play with when you are done building it.

title: Thicker and sturdier than Petit Collage and Learning Journey
text: Our favorite puzzles so far have been The Learning Journey giant floor puzzles. Those have big, sturdy pieces and work well on carpet and rugs. This specific ABC Melissa and Doug puzzle is even thicker and sturdier! My just turned 3 year old really enjoys this bright colorful puzzle with lots of animals, and my 4.5 year old likes it too! I'd say it is perfect for 3-5 year olds. I hope to see more puzzles in this size, quality and number of pieces. (And for reference, the Petit Collage puzzles are the thinnest and are hardest for my preschoolers to complete on carpet)

title: Fun toy, but needs improvement
text:
This version of the classic marble run is just ok. The pieces are interesting, especially the light up one, and they are made of nice, sturdy plastic. But there are a few issues that make this toy frustrating for my kids to play with.

The biggest problem is that the pieces do not have consistent tolerances for the connecting portions. Sometimes they snap together easily while other times it takes a lot of force. My 2 and 4 year olds cannot do this without help. They always end up knocking the sections over when trying to put the pieces together. This hasn't been the issue when they played with another brands' marble run.

Another issue is that there are not enough base pieces compared to the number of “action” pieces (like the ramps, slides, etc). This results in having to build tall, unstable designs that are easily knocked over, which makes the first problem even worse.

Also, the piece that shoots the marbles up is difficult for my fairly coordinated 4 year old to use. It requires a quick tap that is firm but not too hard. It would be nice if it was easier to use. Both of my kids like the idea of this piece, but I end up having to do it for them. And I can't always get this piece to shoot the marble properly every time.

Last, it would have been nice to have a couple of example layouts included in the instructions. This is not too big of a deal, but the pieces are difficult to connect and take apart, so for my kids' sake, knowing some layouts that use the different sections properly would be nice.

title: Fun but also frustrating
text: My 3 and 4 year old love Toy Story, and they do enjoy this toy, but they are also frustrated by it. To close the camper, you have the fold the back up and in to it, which my 3 year old can't always do. Also once it's closed, you can't really fit much/anything in to the back of the camper. So while my kids would love to drive around with all of the other Toy Story Little People they have from a separately purchased set, they cannot. So this toy ends up being cute but pretty limited in ways to play. I wouldn't purchase it for a child over 5 and really younger than 3 would likely need constant help to open and close the camper.

title: Not super interesting, would prefer a plain Paw Patrol watch without sounds
text: I gave this to my 4.5 year old, and we have both only felt so so about it. She likes to read the time on it, but she really isn't interested in any of the other “features”. It's pretty bulky too, so it falls off her wrist a lot and she needs help putting it back on. I personally don't love the two phrases it repeats over and over “Paw Patrol is on a roll” and “Paw Patrol to the Lookout!” At first I thought my daughter was intentionally pushing a button each time it would say that, but she wasn't. Whenever the watch cover has the slightest pressure pushing it down, it hits the inside button and the phrases sound. Its pretty annoying to hear over and over. My daughter would be just as happy with a normal watch that just told the time and had a Paw Patrol picture on it.

title: All 7 Characters included!
text: My 2 and 4 year old have a collection of Little People that have danced in castles, saved cats from fires, and ridden in trains around our house. They are the perfect size for their imaginative play and end up in all scenarios all over our house. These Toy Story characters join the ranks of loved Little People. My kids are obsessed with Forky and Toy Story and these are perfect.

title: Perfect for 2-4 year olds!
text: I have a 2 and 4 year old Toy Story fan, and this is perfect for them! They can push the toy around and pop Woody up easily. I have a feeling kids much older would be bored by this since there isn't anything else to do other than push it around, but it's perfect for my kids and they love it.

title: Fun craft for 4 year old
text: This is a great craft for my art loving 4 year old. It's simple and cute, but probably will end up being pretty disposable too. The 3 small wooden butterflies are pretty little with not much usefulness, and they will likely end up being thrown away soon. The trinket box is a better keepsake but still not high quality. Overall I see this as being a fun craft to paint, but we won't be saving the finished product for long.

title: Cute and small
text: These figures are perfect for any Toy Story fan, but I do wish they were a bit bigger! They are definitely on the small side, but they also aren't super expensive, so it still seems reasonable. I saw the same product at Target today for $6.99.

title: 2 and 4 year old love these aliens
text: My kids love the Toy story aliens. Even though these are hard plastic and don't do much, their arms do move. My kids love putting them in cars and driving them around or even just putting them on their dressers or nightstands.

title: Perfect first LEGO set
text: I got this for my 4 and 3 year old and it is the perfect first intro to Legos for them! It's not too large or complicated and they absolutely love the Toy Story characters.

title: Perfect first LEGO set
text: I got this for my 4 and 3 year old and it is the perfect first intro to Legos for them! It's not too large or complicated and they absolutely love the Toy Story characters.

title: Classic Thomas quality and fun
text: There is something about the colorful Thomas trains that my kids love, and the quality is the best. They fit well on our Brio tracks and through the Brio tunnels. The magnets are strong and they stay together well.

title: 2 and 4 year olds love it
text: My nearly 3 year son loves this. It's his first Hot Wheels track and he's been playing with it for more than an hour every day for the past week. The volcano escape is definitely the main attraction with the launcher and the battery powered fire arms that push the cars along the track. The other three smaller pieces are ok, but pretty small/limited in how you can play with them. (If they sell the volcano escape separately at a reasonable price, I would consider just purchasing that piece.) The included road tracks that connect the 4 pieces together are pretty frustrating. They aren't very secure and don't snap or lock in to place, so my kids are constantly knocking them apart and needing me to fix it. Maybe older kids would be better at keeping it all together, or maybe the classic orange tracks would solve the problem if you own those. Overall my kids really love this set, and it's a great start to a new Hot Wheels toys phase.

title: Another great playdoh set
text: My 4 year old and I love this simple but great set. Nothing beats fresh playdoh, and you get 3 little containers included. You also get tools needed to make flowers, seeds, a flower pot, and a watering can. It would be a great gift for a preschooler as well.

title: Hours of fun for 2 and 4 year old
text: After receiving this a week ago, my 2 and 4 year old and I have played with these for over 5 hours this past week. We have made everything in the book and variations of the book ideas too, mainly lots of different sized Ferris wheels. :) The book ideas are broken into 3 categories - easy, medium and advanced - and my 4 year old can do most of the easy and medium without help. The only problem we've had is once something is built, my kids don't want to immediately take it apart to have the pieces they need for a different build, because in most cases there aren't enough pieces to have two things built at once. A bigger set would be preferred for multiple kids to share!

title: 2 and 4 year old love this
text: My 2 and 4 year old love this. They can get the plate wet themselves to make the food reappear and they love to pretend to feed their animals. The milk bottle and bib are great too and the perfect size for baby dolls or small to medium stuffed animals.
